Explanation: For the first time, the 2010 Dietary Guidelines have an entire chapter devoted to addressing the impact of the broader food and physical environment on the public’s food, drink, and activity choices using the Social-Ecological model. Physical activity standards were included in the 2005 guidelines. MyPyramid was replaced with MyPlate. There was a shift in food intake patterns emphasizing more vegetables, cooked dried beans, fruits, whole grains, nuts and seeds.

Question: A community health nurse is educating a community group about the 2010 Dietary Guidelines for Americans. Which of the following information would be included in this presentation?
Choice 1: Limit consumption of dairy products.
Choice 2: Purchase organic fruits and vegetables.
Choice 3: Make at least half of your grains whole grains.
Choice 4: Consume fish on a daily basis.
Explanation: One of the principal messages for consumers is “make at least half of your grains whole grains.” Other messages include “switch to fat-free or low-fat (1%) milk” and “make half your plate fruits and vegetables.” There is not an essential message to consume fish on a daily basis.

Question: A person states to the nurse, “The guidelines for what we should eat as Americans is constantly changing, just when I got used to using MyPyramid they changed it to MyPlate. I wonder what will be next and if they really know what they are doing with all of this change.” Which of the following would be the best response from the nurse?
Choice 1: “The USDA is constantly making changes in order to decrease the alarming rates of obesity in our country.”
Choice 2: “MyPyramid was developed in 2005, so it was time for this graphic to be revised.”
Choice 3: “The creation of MyPlate has decreased the need for additional teaching resources for nutrition.”
Choice 4: “MyPlate serves as a better visual aid, reminding Americans what a healthy ‘plate’ looks like.”
Explanation: MyPate was released in June 2011 providing Americans easy to understand and useful advice. MyPlate visually “reminds” consumers what a healthy “plate” looks like using a familiar place setting. It is not meant to stand alone as a teaching tool.

Question: A person asks the nurse if it is safe to use dietary supplements. Which of the following would be the best reply from the nurse?
Choice 1: “It is important to be cautious when using any supplements.”
Choice 2: “All dietary supplements must be approved by the FDA before they can be sold and are safe.”
Choice 3: “No, dietary supplements have very limited regulations and should not be used.”
Choice 4: “Be sure to read the product label before using the supplement to see what health claims have been made by the product.”
Explanation: The desirable way for the general public to obtain recommended levels of nutrients is by eating a variety of foods. Low-dose supplements that contain the recommended intakes for micronutrients appear to be generally safe. Caution is advised when using supplements, as natural is not always better. Dietary supplements are unregulated by the FDA in the sense that they do not require premarket review or approval by the FDA.

Question: A woman has asked the nurse about the benefits and risks of using ginseng to control her hot flashes associated with menopause. Which of the following governmental offices would most likely serve as a resource to answer the woman’s question?
Choice 1: American Dietetic Association (ADA)
Choice 2: National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine (NCCAM)
Choice 3: Food and Drug Administration (FDA)
Choice 4: United States Department of Agriculture (USDA)
Explanation: The National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine (NCCAM) promotes and conducts the scientific study of the benefits and risks of dietary supplements, including medicinal herbs, in health maintenance and disease prevention.

Question: A 37-year-old woman asks the nurse if she should take a daily nutritional supplement. Which of the following would be the best reply by the nurse?
Choice 1: “Postmenopausal women should take a calcium supplement to prevent osteoporosis.”
Choice 2: “Many people use supplements as drugs instead of as supplements.”
Choice 3: “Supplements can enhance the medications that you take.”
Choice 4: “The best way to obtain nutrients is by eating a variety of foods.”
Explanation: The desirable way for the general public to obtain nutrients is by eating a variety of foods. Dietary supplements needs to be used cautiously so that excess amounts are not consumed, which could lead to possible adverse effects.

Question: A client who is taking Coumadin tells the nurse that she has started taking a vitamin E supplement as she has heard that this will help decrease the likelihood of her developing cancer. Which of the following would be the most appropriate response by the nurse?
Choice 1: “Vitamin E supplements are unnecessary, so I don’t recommend you use this supplement.”
Choice 2: “Vitamin E can interfere with the actions of vitamin K and enhance the effects of Coumadin .”
Choice 3: “Vitamin E supplements can interfere with the absorption of iron and create additional health problems.”
Choice 4: “Vitamin E must be used cautiously, as it is easy to experience a toxicity of this nutrient.”
Explanation: High doses of vitamin E can interfere with vitamin K action and enhance the effect of Coumadin as one of the anticoagulant drugs. Because of this interaction, she should probably not be taking a supplement of vitamin E while taking the Coumadin. If she continues on the supplement, it may be necessary to adjust the dosage of Coumadin the woman is prescribed.

Question: A nurse is investigating an outbreak of a food-borne illness occurring at a local school. Which of the following would contribute to a chemical contamination resulting in food-borne illness?
Choice 1: Unintended allergen added to food
Choice 2: Bacteria on the countertops
Choice 3: Pesticide on the fresh fruit
Choice 4: Metal shavings in the food from a dull can opener
Explanation: Food-borne illness is classified according to the source of its contamination. Food contaminants may be categorized as biological (bacteria), chemical (pesticides), or physical (metal shavings and unintended allergens).

Question: A school nurse is preparing to discuss food safety practices with high school students enrolled in a family and consumer science “foods” course. Which of the following information would be included in the presentation?
Choice 1: Wash hands thoroughly with running warm water with soap for 30 seconds.
Choice 2: Scrub firm services of all fruits and vegetables with a produce brush before eating.
Choice 3: Pay close attention to assure that meat is cooked all of the way through.
Choice 4: Refrigerate leftovers within 30 minutes of serving.
Explanation: There are four principles at the cornerstones of Fight BAC!, a national food safety education campaign (Clean, Separate, Cook, and Chill). Clean—wash all parts of hands thoroughly with running warm water with soap and friction for about 20-30 seconds. Scrub firm surfaces like cantaloupe and cucumbers with a produce brush, other fresh fruits and vegetables can be rinsed under running water. A food thermometer should be used to make sure that food is cooked all the way through. Leftovers should be refrigerated within 2 hours or 1 hour in temperatures greater than 90° F.

Question: A community health nurse is working with a low-income family who is experiencing food insecurity. To assist the family in getting nutritious foods in their home, the family should be referred to which of the following programs?
Choice 1: Nutrition Service Incentive Program (NSIP)
Choice 2: Supplemental Nutrition for Women Infants and Children (WIC)
Choice 3: National School Lunch Program (NSLP)
Choice 4: Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP)
Explanation: Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) supplements the food-buying power of eligible low-income households and is the foundation of the Nations’ nutrition safety net. The program is designed to help low-income families and individuals purchase nutritionally adequate foods.

Question: A school nurse is discussing the income eligibility requirements for free and reduced-price school meals with a family who is new to the school district. Which of the following statements would the nurse most likely make?
Choice 1: “If the employed member of your family earns less than $50,000 per year, your child will qualify for reduced-price meals.”
Choice 2: “If your family’s income is less than 185% above the federal poverty level, your child will qualify for free or reduced-price meals.”
Choice 3: “If you have more than five members living in your household, your child will qualify for reduced-price meals.”
Choice 4: “If your family has an income above the federal poverty level, your child will not qualify for free or reduced-price meals.”
Explanation: Children from families with incomes greater than 130% to 185% of the federal poverty level are eligible for reduced-price school meals. Children from families with incomes at or less than 130% of the federal poverty level are eligible for free school meals. Consideration is given to both income level and number of members living in the household when interpreting the federal poverty guidelines.

Question: A nurse is counseling a person with heart disease. Which of the following statements made by the individual would require the nurse to provide additional education?
Choice 1: “I drink skim milk on a regular basis.”
Choice 2: “I try not to eat foods that have added salt on the label.”
Choice 3: “I eat American cheese about once every 2 weeks.”
Choice 4: “I add salt to many of the food that I eat to enhance the flavor.”
Explanation: The 2006 AHA diet and lifestyle recommendations include the suggestion to reduce salt intake by comparing the sodium content of similar products and choosing products with less salt or sodium; choosing versions of processed foods, including cereals and baked goods, that are reduced in salt or sodium; and limited condiments. Sodium ingestion leads to retention of fluids and may be harmful to the cardiovascular system of someone who has heart disease.

Question: A 45-year-old man has been diagnosed with metabolic syndrome. Which of the following characteristics would this man exhibit?
Choice 1: Blood pressure: 146/88 mm Hg
Choice 2: Waist measurement: 36 inches
Choice 3: HDL: 48 mg/dL
Choice 4: Triglycerides: 140 mg/dL
Explanation: Metabolic syndrome is diagnosed when a person has three or more of these factors: excessive abdominal fat, as indicated by too large a waist measurement (greater than 40 inches in men); elevated blood pressure (higher than 130/85 mm Hg), low HDL level (lower than 40 mg/dL), and elevated triglyceride level (higher than 150 mg/dL).

Question: Which of the following individuals has a modifiable, nutrition-related risk factor for stroke?
Choice 1: African American man, age 65, who has a low salt intake
Choice 2: White woman, age 32, who follows the MyPlate recommendations
Choice 3: Russian man, age 40, who drinks 3 oz of vodka daily
Choice 4: Hispanic man, age 42, who exercises regularly
Explanation: Modifiable risk factors are those that the person can control. Race, age, and gender are nonmodifiable risk factors. Habitual alcohol intake is a modifiable risk factor for stroke.

Question: A community health nurse is providing education about the “Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension” (DASH) eating plan to people attending cardiac rehabilitation. Which of the following recommendations would be included in this presentation?
Choice 1: The use of this dietary plan has the same health effects as a daily exercise program.
Choice 2: The use of this dietary plan will eliminate the need for medication to treat hypertension.
Choice 3: This dietary plan is excludes the consumption of processed foods.
Choice 4: This dietary plan includes eating greater amounts of fruits and vegetables.
Explanation: Clinical studies show that blood pressure can be lowered by following the DASH eating plan. The DASH eating plan includes abundant fruits and vegetables, more fat-free or low-fat milk and milk products, whole grains, fish, poultry, beans, seeds, and nuts. Depending on the severity of hypertension, the plan may allow for a reduction or elimination of medication.

Question: A man states that he would like to change his dietary habits to decrease his risk of developing cancer in the future. Which of the following statements would be the best response for the nurse?
Choice 1: “Consume at least [PIC_20170114132026_0010.jpg] cups of fruits and vegetables each day.”
Choice 2: “Dietary habits have minimal effect in reducing your risk of developing cancer.”
Choice 3: “A glass of red wine should be consumed daily.”
Choice 4: “Dietary supplements of specific nutrients will maximize the effects of dietary changes.”
Explanation: Eating at least [PIC_20170114132026_0011.jpg] cups of a variety of fruits and vegetables can help protect against cancers at many sites, particularly for cancers of the gastrointestinal and respiratory tracks. Following the dietary recommendations included in the 2010 Dietary guidelines for Americans and MyPlate are consistent with those recommended by the ACS. Food appears to have a protective effect by itself that dietary supplements do not provide.

Question: Which of the following people is at greatest risk for a hip fracture secondary to osteoporosis?
Choice 1: A 66-year-old White woman
Choice 2: A 66-year-old African American woman
Choice 3: A 66-year-old White man
Choice 4: A 66-year-old African American man
Explanation: White postmenopausal women have the greatest prevalence of osteoporosis and incidence of hip fracture by gender and race.

Question: A school nurse is using height and weight measurements to calculate the body mass index (BMI) of the students. How will the nurse use these data?
Choice 1: BMI can be correlated to a specific percentage of body fat.
Choice 2: BMI can be used to determine if a child is obese or underweight.
Choice 3: BMI can be used to determine if a child will develop Type 2 diabetes.
Choice 4: BMI can be compared with others of the same ethnic background.
Explanation: Body mass index (BMI) is a helpful indicator of obesity and being underweight. Height and weight measurements are needed in the calculation to determine BMI. BMI is a good indicator of body fat, but it cannot be interpreted as a specific percentage of body fat. BMI is used to screen and monitor a population to detect the risk of health or nutritional disorders. In an individual, other data must be used to determine if a high BMI is associated with increased risk of disease; BMI alone is not diagnostic. The growth charts released in 2000 by the CDC more accurately reflect the nation’s cultural and racial diversity, but there is not a different chart for each ethnic background.

Question: A community health nurse is educating health care providers in a local clinic about steps to take to help their clients improve their health-related behaviors. Which of the following would be included as the nurse teaches about the acronym LEARN?
Choice 1: Explain how small changes can affect health.
Choice 2: Acknowledge that action needs to be taken.
Choice 3: Negotiate an agreement.
Choice 4: Refer to community resources.
Explanation: LEARN refers to the steps nurses can take to help the person who needs to improve health-related behavior. L = Listen with sympathy and understanding to the person’s perception of the problem, E = Explain personal perceptions of the problem, A = Acknowledge and discuss differences and similarities, R = Recommend treatment, N = Negotiate an agreement.

Question: Which of the following individuals would be at greatest risk to develop Type 2 diabetes?
Choice 1: White, 50-year-old woman, obese, second child weighed 10 pounds at birth
Choice 2: African American, 55-year-old man, hypertension, exercises regularly
Choice 3: Hispanic, 22-year-old woman, healthy weight, family history of diabetes
Choice 4: White, 75-year-old man, history of prostate cancer and high triglycerides
Explanation: Risk factors for Type 2 diabetes include: having prediabetes (impaired glucose tolerance [IGT] and/or impaired fasting glucose [IFG]), age greater than 45, being overweight or obese, not exercising regularly, having a family history of diabetes, a personal history of gestational diabetes or a baby of at least 9 pounds at birth, other risk factors such as high blood pressure, a low HDL cholesterol or high triglycerides, and one’s race and ethnicity. The White, 50-year-old woman who is obese and gave birth to a child weighing 10 pounds has the most risk factors of the clients described.

Question: A nurse is counseling a person who was recently diagnosed with diabetes about how to prevent the complications of this disease. Which of the following interventions would be stressed the most by the nurse?
Choice 1: Adjusting sliding scale insulin therapy as needed
Choice 2: Taking oral hypoglycemic medication as prescribed
Choice 3: Monitoring blood glucose daily
Choice 4: Adhering to medical nutrition therapy
Explanation: Medicine may be used to control blood glucose level, and measuring the blood glucose daily helps in controlling its level. But the key to maintaining diabetic control is individualized medical nutrition therapy, the purpose of which is to delay or prevent diabetic complications.

Question: A nurse is conducting an initial nutritional assessment on a person who is HIV positive. Which of the following questions would be most important for the nurse to ask?
Choice 1: What fresh fruits and vegetables do you like to eat?
Choice 2: Are you taking a daily multivitamin?
Choice 3: How often do you eat at restaurants?
Choice 4: Do you have any questions about your current medications?
Explanation: Evidence suggests that micronutrient deficiencies are common among those with HIV and that those not taking vitamin supplementation have increased morbidity and mortality. Thus, asking about use of a daily multivitamin is the most important information for the nurse to collect. A nutrient-dense, protein-rich, well-balanced diet should be stressed as well as vitamin and mineral supplementation. Because of an altered immune function, they get sicker when exposed to food-borne organisms, so discussion about how to avoid food-borne illness is also important.

Question: Which of the following causes of death is/are directly associated with diet? (select all that apply)
Choice 1: Diabetes mellitus
Choice 2: Cirrhosis of the liver
Choice 3: Stroke
Choice 4: Coronary heart disease (CHD)
Explanation: Four leading causes of death directly associated with diet are coronary heart disease (CHD), some types of cancer, stroke, and diabetes mellitus. Four more major causes of death—accidents, cirrhosis of the liver, suicide, and homicide—are associated with excessive alcohol intake.

Question: A community health nurse is preparing an educational brochure about improving the nutritional behaviors of Americans. Which of the following topics would most likely be included in the brochure? (select all that apply)
Choice 1: Increasing daily intake of milk and dairy products
Choice 2: Decreasing daily sodium intake
Choice 3: Increasing daily intake of fruits and vegetables
Choice 4: Decreasing daily intake of sugar-sweetened drinks
Explanation: Fewer than 15% of adults and 10% of adolescents eat the recommended amounts of fruits and vegetables every day. Sixty-three percent of adults and 84% of adolescents consume at least one sugar-sweetened drink each day. Most American adults consume more than twice the recommended average daily sodium intake level.

Question: A community health nurse is developing educational materials related to nutrition. Which of the following resources would be most appropriate for the nurse to use? (select all that apply)
Choice 1: Recommended dietary allowances (RDAs)
Choice 2: MyPyramid
Choice 3: Dietary reference intakes (DRIs)
Choice 4: MyPlate
Explanation: The most current food and nutrition recommendations are found using the dietary reference intakes (DRIs) and MyPlate. These two resources replaced the previously issued recommended dietary allowances (RDAs) and MyPyramid.

Question: A person has been diagnosed with salmonellosis. Which of the following symptoms would the person most likely exhibit?  (select all that apply)
Choice 1: Bloody diarrhea
Choice 2: Vomiting
Choice 3: Hypoactive bowel sounds
Choice 4: Abdominal cramping
Explanation: Symptoms of salmonellosis include abdominal cramping, mild to severe diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, and fever within 8 to 72 hours after infection. Bloody diarrhea is more likely seen with E. coli infection.

Question: Edelman: Health Promotion Throughout the Life Span, 8th Edition1.Activity that uses large muscle groups in a repetitive, rhythmic fashion over an extended period to improve the efficiency of the oxidative energy producing system and improve cardiorespiratory endurance is known as:
Choice 1: aerobic activity.
Choice 2: anaerobic activity.
Choice 3: flexibility.
Choice 4: muscular fitness.
Explanation: Aerobic activity is defined as activity that uses large muscle groups in a repetitive, rhythmic fashion over an extended period to improve the efficiency of the oxidative energy producing system and improve cardiorespiratory endurance.

Question: A nurse is working with a group of individuals to start an exercise program. Which of the following would require the most attention and assistance?
Choice 1: White man who works 50 to 60 hours a week as a business executive
Choice 2: Unemployed, obese Hispanic woman
Choice 3: Employed White woman with hypertension
Choice 4: White man with a high school diploma
Explanation: The number of adults with no leisure-time physical activity varies by race, ethnicity, gender, education level, geographic location, disability status, and age. Women are less active than men. Lower income and less educated people are not as physically active as those with higher socioeconomic and educational levels. In addition, African Americans and Hispanics are less active. The unemployed, obese Hispanic woman has three risk factors for inactivity: (1) she is unemployed and therefore likely has no or a low income level; (2) she is a woman, and (3) she is Hispanic. All of these factors place her at risk for inactivity.

Question: According to the physical activity and fitness section of the Healthy People 2020 report, what percentage of adults 18 years of age or older report no leisure-time physical activity?
Explanation: According to the physical activity and fitness section of the Healthy People 2020 report, 36% of adults 18 years of age or older report no leisure-time physical activity.

Question: A nurse is developing a primary prevention strategy to address the problem of obesity. Which of the following interventions is being created?
Choice 1: Encouraging an active lifestyle during childhood years
Choice 2: Prescribing orlistat (Alli)
Choice 3: Recommending the Jenny Craig program
Choice 4: Recommending gastric banding surgery
Explanation: Exercise is an important component of primary prevention. Less active children increase their risk of sedentary lifestyles as adults. Sedentary lifestyles lead to obesity. Therefore, a primary prevention method for obesity is to encourage an active lifestyle during the childhood years.

Question: A nurse is providing care for a 10-year-old child with a BMI at the 80th percentile. Which of the following best describes this child?
Choice 1: Normal weight
Choice 2: Overweight
Choice 3: Obese
Choice 4: Morbidly obese
Explanation: A child or adolescent is categorized as being overweight if his or her BMI is greater than or equal to the 95th percentile of age- and gender-specific BMI growth charts. Thus, the 10-year-old child with a BMI at the 80th percentile is considered to be normal weight.

Question: According to the 2009-2010 National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey, what percentage of 6- to 11-year-old children are overweight?
Explanation: According to the 2009-2010 National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey conducted by the CDC’s National Center for Health Statistics, 18% of 6- to 11-year-old children are overweight.

Question: A nurse is providing care for a 40-year-old adult with a BMI of 32. Which of the following best describes this person?
Choice 1: Normal weight
Choice 2: Overweight
Choice 3: Obese
Choice 4: Morbidly obese
Explanation: An adult 20 years of age or older is considered overweight if his or her BMI is 25 to 29.9, obese if his or her BMI is 30 or higher, and morbidly obese if his or her BMI is 40 or higher. Thus, the 40-year-old adult with a BMI of 32 is considered obese.

Question: During an office visit, a nurse meets with a woman who states she does not have time to exercise. Which of the following actions should the nurse take next?
Choice 1: Do nothing because she has already made the decision to not exercise.
Choice 2: Provide her with information on the benefits of exercising.
Choice 3: Develop an exercise prescription with her.
Choice 4: Schedule a follow-up in 2 months to see if she still feels the same way.
Explanation: The woman is in the precontemplation state and thus should not be forced into a plan at this time. However, exercise has many benefits and it implementation should be encouraged. The nurse should continue to ask at each visit because when individuals are counseled by clinicians they are more likely to increase physical activity. As a result, providing the woman with information regarding the benefits of exercising and bringing up the topic of exercise is the best approach at this stage.

Question: During an office visit, a nurse provides counseling to a 70-year-old woman with osteoporosis who is otherwise very healthy. Which of the following information should the nurse provide to the woman?
Choice 1: Avoid all forms of exercise because of the risk of fractures.
Choice 2: Walk with a partner at least 30 minutes a day 5 days a week.
Choice 3: Use a wheelchair to get around so that she can prevent falls.
Choice 4: Take a step aerobics class 5 days a week.
Explanation: Regular physical activity helps maintain functional independence and improve quality of life throughout the aging process. The benefits of exercise have been documented for both healthy and chronically ill older adults. Exercise improves bone mineral density, especially weight-bearing activities such as walking, aerobic, and dance. Women 30 to 40 years past menopause also need to consider decreasing the risk of fractures by preventing falls. Advanced age and osteoporosis should not exclude anyone from exercise. Therefore, walking with a partner provides the exercise that is needed as well as a companion to help prevent falls or notify someone if a fall occurs.

Question: A nurse is providing health education for a group of older adults about the risks of developing coronary heart disease. Which of the following group members is at highest risk?
Choice 1: Takes a beta-blocker for hypertension
Choice 2: Has a total cholesterol level of 201
Choice 3: Doesn’t participate in any form of regular physical activity
Choice 4: Has a family history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus
Explanation: Physical inactivity affects more people in the development of coronary heart disease than any other risk factor. At any level or combination of risk factors, sedentary individuals are at greater risk of developing coronary heart diseases. Exercise provides both primary and secondary prevention. Thus, the person who does not participate in any form of regular physical activity is at most risk of developing coronary heart disease.

Question: During a home visit, a nurse notes that a person with hypertension lives on the third floor of a subsidized housing project on a busy road with no sidewalks and few street lights. Which of the following would be the best recommendation for exercise for the nurse to make to the person?
Choice 1: Do not exercise because you have high blood pressure.
Choice 2: Use the stairs whenever you are entering or leaving the building.
Choice 3: Go for short walks around the block during the daytime only.
Choice 4: Purchase an exercise bike.
Explanation: Exercise decreases blood pressure and thus should be encouraged in those with hypertension, especially aerobic activity. Participation in physical activity depends on the availability of facilities and a safe environment. Walking in the road is not safe, and it is also unlikely that this person, who lives in a subsidized housing project, has the funds to purchase an exercise bike. Therefore, using the stairs as much as possible would be a safe, inexpensive form of exercise for this person.

Question: A 51-year-old woman has begun menopause. The nurse emphasizes the importance of a diet high in calcium and vitamin D as well as exercise for this woman.This recommendation is important because by the time the client is 56, she will have experienced another _ bone loss.
Explanation: The rate of bone loss accelerates rapidly during the first 5 postmenopausal years, with annual losses of 3% to 5% being common. Thus, if at least 3 % is lost over 5 years, 3%  5 years (56 – 51) = 15%.

Question: A nurse is educating a 35-year-old woman about the best exercises to engage in to prevent bone loss. Which of the following exercises would the nurse recommend?
Choice 1: Walking
Choice 2: Swimming
Choice 3: Weight training
Choice 4: Bike riding
Explanation: Weight-bearing activities have a positive effect on bone density, and walking is a weight-bearing activity. In young women, the goal is to increase bone mineral density; thus, walking is the best exercise to prevent osteoporosis in this woman.

Question: A nurse is developing an exercise program for a person with moderate osteoarthritis of the knees. Which of the following forms of exercise would the nurse include in this program?
Choice 1: Step aerobics
Choice 2: Running
Choice 3: Water aerobics
Choice 4: Bike riding
Explanation: Water activities are good exercise alternatives for people with musculoskeletal limitations who need some weight relief with exercise. The water provides buoyancy while also providing resistance to the limbs as they move. Studies have also demonstrated that people who participate in aquatic exercise experienced greater pain reduction than those who participated in land activities. Thus, water aerobics would be the most appropriate form of exercise for this individual.

Question: A nurse is providing care to a person who has lower back pain. Which of the following exercises would the nurse recommend to assist with pain reduction?
Choice 1: Walking
Choice 2: Pilates
Choice 3: Swimming
Choice 4: Bike riding
Explanation: Maintaining proper curves of lordosis and kyphosis in the vertebrae is important for sustaining the spring and shock absorption quality of the spine. Poor posture can increase stress on the back and lead to pain. Exercises that train the paraspinal muscles to improve posture (like Pilates) are effective for people with lower back pain. Aerobic activity is recommended to maintain endurance and prevent debilitation from inactivity.

Question: Which of the following statements about exercise is true?
Choice 1: People who engage in high-intensity exercise are at lowest risk for illness.
Choice 2: Aerobic exercise should be part of daily exercise routines.
Choice 3: Regular exercise may cause people to experience fatigue and increased susceptibility to mental health disorders.
Choice 4: Low-level physical activity may have a protective effect on gastric and pancreatic cancer.
Explanation: Low-level physical activity may have a protective effect on gastric and pancreatic cancer. People who engage in moderate-intensity activity are at lowest risk for illness, whereas those who engage in high-intensity activity are at higher risk for illness. Aerobic exercise is recommended at a frequency of three to five times per week. Every other day is a good frame of reference as it allows for recovery between training sessions. Cross-training is recommended as part of daily exercise routines. Regular exercise promotes positive well-being and decreased susceptibility to mental health disorders.

Question: A nurse is monitoring the exercise of a 42-year-old woman. Which of the following would be the estimated maximum heart rate (MHR) for this woman?
Explanation: A generic formula for determining MHR is 220 minus age: 220 – 42 = 178.

Question: A nurse is counseling a 40-year-old person who is going to start an exercise program. Which of the following heart rate ranges would the nurse encourage the person to maintain while exercising?
Choice 1: 70 to 140 beats/min
Choice 2: 80 to 143 beats/min
Choice 3: 90 to 153 beats/min
Choice 4: 100 to 180 beats/min
Explanation: The maximum heart rate for a 40-year-old is 180. Exercise should produce a heart rate that is 50% to 85% of maximum heart rate. This percentage corresponds to a rate of perceived exertion of 11 to 14: 50% of 180 = 90, 85% of 180 = 153. Thus, the range should be 90 to 153.

Question: A nurse is discussing exercise intensity with a client. Which of the following medications that the client is taking may limit the usefulness of heart rate as an indicator of exercise intensity?
Choice 1: Ciprofloxacin (Cipro)
Choice 2: Metoprolol (Toprol)
Choice 3: Atorvastatin (Lipitor)
Choice 4: Lansoprazole (Prevacid)
Explanation: Beta-blockers may alter the relationship between heart rate and the rate of perceived exertion. Metoprolol is a beta-blocker and thus may limit the usefulness of heart rate as an indicator of exercise intensity.

Question: The nurse is discussing an exercise prescription with a person. To help him determine the appropriate intensity, the nurse tells him that he should monitor his rate of perceived exertion. Which of the following should the nurse tell the man he should experience while exercising?
Choice 1: Talking and singing without difficulty
Choice 2: Feeling extremely fatigued
Choice 3: Having mild musculoskeletal discomfort
Choice 4: Being out of breath
Explanation: The rate of perceived exertion helps people determine a comfortable, beneficial level of exercise intensity. Being slightly short of breath, able to talk with difficulty, being pleasantly fatigued, and having mild musculoskeletal pain reflect a rate of perceived exertion that corresponds well with 50% to 85% of maximum heart rate, an appropriate target range for most individuals.

Question: A nurse is discussing resistance training with a 24-year-old woman. The woman is resistant to weight lifting because she does not want to get too muscular. She prefers a program that is strictly aerobic. Which of the following would be the most appropriate response from the nurse?
Choice 1: “Ok, just make sure you perform one hour of aerobics every day.”
Choice 2: “Lifting weights is a necessary part of exercise.”
Choice 3: “Weight lifting has many purposes and benefits; can we talk about them?”
Choice 4: “Looking muscular at your age is attractive.”
Explanation: Weight training helps develop healthy muscles that provide strength to perform activities of daily living (ADLs) without injury and it stimulates bone health. Additionally, the risk of injury outweighs the benefits of aerobic exercise more than 5 days a week. Not all weight lifting leads to a bodybuilder physique. Offering the patient the opportunity to discuss weight training will allow the patient the opportunity to open up and discuss fears and concerns. It also provides the nurse with the opportunity to discuss the risks and benefits.

Question: An inborn set of physiological changes that offset those of the fight or flight response is known as:
Choice 1: Self-efficacy
Choice 2: Catecholamine surge
Choice 3: Relaxation response
Choice 4: Metabolism
Explanation: Relaxation response is an inborn set of physiological changes that offset those of the fight or flight response.

Question: A nurse is caring for a man who states he is ready to start exercising. Which of the following actions should the nurse take next?
Choice 1: Do nothing because he has already made the decision to implement a change.
Choice 2: Provide him with information on the benefits of exercising.
Choice 3: Develop an exercise prescription with him.
Choice 4: Schedule a follow-up in 2 months to see if he still feels the same way.
Explanation: Working with a person to choose an activity that he likes will improve adherence. The person is displaying that he is in the action phase of change, and he should be given a prescription that promotes exercise and places him in the maintenance phase.

Question: A nurse is counseling a 19-year-old person who has recently been diagnosed with Type 1 diabetes mellitus. The person asks if there is anything specific that should be done before going to play tennis with a friend. Which of the following instructions should the nurse give the person to avoid hypoglycemia?
Choice 1: Inject the insulin into the abdomen.
Choice 2: Inject the insulin into the arm.
Choice 3: Inject the insulin into the thigh.
Choice 4: Skip taking any insulin before exercising.
Explanation: When insulin is injected in a muscle that will be active, it will speed up the absorption of insulin and quickly decrease blood glucose. Because tennis involves a lot of leg and arm movement, insulin should be given in the abdomen. Additionally, not all insulins have the same onset or duration of action. Changes in insulin dosage schedules should not be made without knowing the onset or duration of action.

Question: A woman is going for a 2-hour hike in the Grand Canyon and she asks the nurse how much fluid she should take along with her. Which of the following recommendations should be given by the nurse?
Choice 1: Bring at least 24 ounces of water.
Choice 2: Bring at least 72 ounces of water.
Choice 3: Bring at least 24 ounces of sports drink.
Choice 4: Bring at least 72 ounces of sports drink.
Explanation: If the weather is hot, 5 to 12 oz of fluid should be taken every 15 to 20 minutes during exercise. Additionally, if exercise lasts more than 1 hour, a drink that provides carbohydrates and electrolytes helps delay fatigue and improve performance.

Question: An occupational health nurse is trying to promote regular activity at her institution. Which of the following interventions would most likely be the most successful?
Choice 1: Educate all employees regarding the benefits of exercise.
Choice 2: Initiate a lunchtime walking group that employees can join.
Choice 3: Provide all employees with an exercise prescription.
Choice 4: Recommend that employees who do not exercise be terminated from their positions.
Explanation: Individuals are more likely to initiate and maintain physical activity if they feel competent doing the activity, feel safe doing it, perceive no negative financial or social cost, can access the activity easily on a regular basis, and can fit the activity into their regular schedule. Knowledge is not enough to sustain activity. Role models are helpful. Initiating a lunchtime walking group demonstrates enthusiasm on the part of the nurse, provides an activity that is easy and mastered by most and provides a social activity that can promote reinforcement by others who participate.

Question: A nurse is providing an educational program addressing the importance of being physically active. The nurse states that individuals should engage in exercise for a minimum of 30 minutes of activity on most days of the week. For which of the following individuals is that recommendation appropriate? (select all that apply)
Choice 1: A 54-year-old with hypercholesterolemia
Choice 2: A 66-year-old with hypertension
Choice 3: A 48-year-old with obesity
Choice 4: A 58-year-old with Type 2 diabetes mellitus
Explanation: The risk of CHD decreases with an increase in physical activity. Exercise positively affects lipoprotein metabolism and is a common part of the treatment for hypertriglyceridemia. Regular exercise also decreases blood pressure in adults. Exercise improves glycemic control by increasing insulin sensitivity in people with Type 2 diabetes mellitus. The Physical Activity Guidelines for Americans advise adults to perform at least 150 minutes of moderate intensity or 75 minutes of vigorous activity per week. Exercise also has a positive effect on obesity. However, the American College of Sports Medicine recommends a minimum of 40 to 60 minutes of exercise 5 to 7 days a week for those with obesity.

Question: A nurse is reviewing an exercise prescription for a person. Which of the following aspects should be included? (select all that apply)
Choice 1: Frequency of exercise
Choice 2: Intensity level of exercise
Choice 3: Time and duration of exercise
Choice 4: Type of exercise
Explanation: An exercise prescription should include frequency of exercise, intensity level of exercise, time and duration of exercise, and type of exercise.

Question: Edelman: Health Promotion Throughout the Life Span, 8th Edition1.A nurse is defining stress to a person. Which of the following statements should the nurse should make?
Choice 1: “Happy events, such as the birth of a child, are rarely as stressful as unhappy events.”
Choice 2: “An event that requires any change in behavior in stressful.”
Choice 3: “All stressors create a challenge to health.”
Choice 4: “Once stressors are identified, they can be controlled.”
Explanation: Any event that requires a change in behavior is stressful. Some stressful events are beneficial to health and not inherently harmful. Many stressors cannot be controlled.

Question: The nurse is conducting community education about stress. Which of the following statements should be made by the nurse?
Choice 1: “Stress always has a negative effect on the body.”
Choice 2: “A moderate amount of short-term stress can make a person more efficient and goal-focused.”
Choice 3: “Long-term stress is useful in helping one to meet goals.”
Choice 4: “Stress always has a positive effect on the body.”
Explanation: Stress may be either harmful or helpful. Long-term stress is harmful. A moderate amount of stress is a motivator.

Question: A nurse is discussing the various types of stress to a group of adults. Which of the following would be used as an example of eustress?
Choice 1: Increasing alcohol intake to deal with loss of a job
Choice 2: Avoidance of social activities because of anxiety
Choice 3: Severely limiting food intake as a way to control stress
Choice 4: Joining a cardiac rehabilitation exercise program after a myocardial infarction
Explanation: Eustress is useful, not harmful. Although a myocardial infarction (MI) is stressful physically and psychologically, joining a cardiac rehab program in response to the MI will improve cardiac and overall health and well-being. The other examples indicate unhealthy coping strategies.

Question: A nurse is caring for a person who has experienced a minor injury following a fall. Which of the following physiological responses to stress would the nurse anticipate?
Choice 1: Lowered blood pressure
Choice 2: Elevated heart rate
Choice 3: Lowered respiratory rate
Choice 4: Elevated blood supply to the gut
Explanation: Activation of the neuroendocrine system in response to stress results in elevated blood pressure, heart rate, respiratory rate, and an increased blood supply to large muscles.

Question: Which of the following statements concerning spirituality is correct?
Choice 1: Spirituality is a search for the meaning of existence.
Choice 2: To fully experience spirituality, one needs a religious affiliation.
Choice 3: Stress always strengthens the quest for spirituality.
Choice 4: Spirituality always prevents depression, which is common following a stressful event.
Explanation: Religion and spirituality are complementary but not the same. Spirituality is possible without a religious affiliation. Although spirituality can help one cope with stress, depression may still result.

Question: A nurse has stated that the person she is working with demonstrates stress hardiness. Which of the following individuals is most likely being described?
Choice 1: Refuses to see family members after the nurse practitioner tells him or her about test results
Choice 2: Conducts Internet research to learn about the latest treatment options for a health deviation
Choice 3: Calls in sick when faced with a personal relationship problem
Choice 4: Views stressors as negative life events
Explanation: Stress hardiness is characterized by feeling in control of situations, viewing stressors as challenging rather than negative events, and using effective coping techniques.

Question: A nurse is describing adults who are in the “sandwich generation.” Which of the following provides the best description of this term?
Choice 1: Middle-aged adults who are starting a family at an older age
Choice 2: Young adults who are beginning to find jobs, marry, and start a family
Choice 3: Middle-aged adults who are caring for children and aging parents
Choice 4: Young adults who have several small children
Explanation: Because of current trends of delayed parenting and increased life span, more middle-aged adults are in the “sandwich generation,” in which they carry the responsibility to care for their children and aging parents.

Question: A nurse is collecting health assessment data about a person’s coping mechanisms in relation to stressors. Who would provide the best source of this information?
Choice 1: Person’s primary care physician
Choice 2: Person’s spouse/significant other
Choice 3: The person
Choice 4: Expert objective analysis skills of the nurse
Explanation: People are the best source of information related to their coping skills.

Question: A nurse is assisting a person to cope with stress. Which statement by the nurse would be the most helpful?
Choice 1: “Most people in this situation feel the way you feel.”
Choice 2: “Tell me what this event means to you.”
Choice 3: “There are many support groups available for you to use.”
Choice 4: “Your family wants to help you through this stressful event. May I call them?”
Explanation: Self-awareness is necessary to evaluate the meaning of an event and can only be assessed by asking the person to think about the meaning of the event.

Question: A nurse is counseling a person on how to effectively deal with stress. Which of the following actions would the nurse recommend the person take first?
Choice 1: Recognize signs of stress.
Choice 2: Take action to reduce stress.
Choice 3: Connect warning signs with stressors.
Choice 4: Develop effective coping skills.
Explanation: To prevent negative consequences of stress, the person must first recognize signs of stress. He or she must then pay attention to these stressors, develop coping skills, and finally use the coping skills.

Question: A nurse is providing education to a community support group about ways to decrease stress. Which of the following would be the initial nursing intervention discussed by the nurse?
Choice 1: Explain how support groups function
Choice 2: Demonstrate deep breathing techniques
Choice 3: Practice guided imagery techniques
Choice 4: Help people to identify their response to stress
Explanation: The priority nursing intervention is to help the person become aware of the effects of stress on physical, emotional, and spiritual well-being. The other interventions are used after the person becomes aware of the individual reaction to stress.

Question: A nurse is explaining the relaxation response to a person. Which of the following statements would be most appropriate for the nurse to make?
Choice 1: “When the relaxation response is used, your sympathetic nervous system is activated and your pulse rate slows down.”
Choice 2: “The relaxation response helps you to become more aware of your surroundings.”
Choice 3: “Deep breathing is very effective in relaxing muscle groups and relieving stress.”
Choice 4: “Holding your breath for 10 to 15 seconds will reduce your blood pressure and pulse rate.”
Explanation: The relaxation response causes blood pressure and pulse rate to lower and muscles to relax. Activation of the sympathetic nervous system has the opposite result.

Question: The nurse conducted a community health education program about the benefits and limitations of alternative therapies. The nurse recognizes that learning has occurred when a participant makes which of the following statements?
Choice 1: “Acupuncture is a technique that can be easily learned and practiced.”
Choice 2: “Hypnosis can be safely used by a licensed hypnotist to treat all cases of anxiety.”
Choice 3: “Reiki is a type of massage that can be used to relieve stress.”
Choice 4: “Herbal products must be used with caution because some can interact with prescription medications.”
Explanation: Acupuncture is a technique that requires administration by a trained acupuncturist. Hypnosis should not be used for people with severe mental illness. Reiki is not a massage technique.

Question: A nurse responded to a natural disaster and used expressive writing as a means of coping with the stress related to this experience. Which of the following benefits of expressive writing should the nurse expect?
Choice 1: Immediate relief of stress through storytelling
Choice 2: Insight into the personal meaning of the experience
Choice 3: Absence of the symptoms of stress
Choice 4: Feeling a great sense of relief immediately after making a journal entry
Explanation: Expressive writing helps one reflect on the personal meaning of an experience. Feelings of sadness or anxiety may accompany journal writing as events are analyzed.

Question: A nurse is helping a person reduce stress-disinhibition related to poor dietary choices. Which of the following nursing interventions would be most appropriate?
Choice 1: Work with the person to develop a plan to slowly replace high-fat, high-calorie foods with more healthy choices.
Choice 2: Encourage the person to eliminate all high-calorie, high-fat foods from the diet as quickly as possible.
Choice 3: Give the person a standard list of low-fat, low-calorie foods.
Choice 4: Provide the person a copy of the Food Guide Pyramid.
Explanation: Working with people to develop a realistic, culturally sensitive, healthy eating plan is more likely to produce lasting results than simply dictating what he or she should eat.

Question: The nurse is assisting a person to develop a positive attitude toward exercise. Which of the following nursing interventions would be most successful when working with this person?
Choice 1: Educate the person that 60 minutes of moderate to strenuous exercise a day is required to lower the risk of heart disease.
Choice 2: Suggest that the person participate in a formal exercise program that has been demonstrated to produce the best results.
Choice 3: Educate the person that exercise patterns established in young adulthood are more effective than those established later in life.
Choice 4: Suggest that the person walk at a moderate pace for 30 minutes a day, 5 days a week for improvement in physical and psychological health.
Explanation: Formal exercise programs are no more effective than walking 30 to 60 minutes a day for 3 to 5 days a week. Exercise is beneficial at any stage of life.

Question: A nurse is helping a man restructure his eating, sleeping, exercise, and thinking patterns to reduce stress. Which of the following nursing interventions would be most effective for this person?
Choice 1: Encourage writing in a journal on a daily basis.
Choice 2: Suggest joining a support group.
Choice 3: Offer referral to individual or group therapy sessions.
Choice 4: Promote purchasing a gym membership.
Explanation: Before any meaningful change in behavior can take place, one must have an awareness of, and reflection about, personal behavior.

Question: A nurse is demonstrating how to use effective communication when dealing with conflict. Which of the following statements would be most appropriate for the nurse to make?
Choice 1: “I am so angry that you are late again that you are grounded for a week.”
Choice 2: “When you miss an appointment, I am hurt.”
Choice 3: “Because you cannot be on time, you cannot have the car for a week.”
Choice 4: “I feel anxious when you do not come home on time because I worry about your safety.”
Explanation: Effective communication relies on assertive communication, which requires an assertive statement (emotion), expressed feelings (behavior), and perceived rights (explanation).

Question: A nurse is educating a client about the four-step approach to active listening. Which of the following actions should the nurse suggest the client take first?
Choice 1: Formulate a nonaggressive response.
Choice 2: Mirror the person’s feelings.
Choice 3: Hear what is being said.
Choice 4: Listen to the response.
Explanation: Active listening requires the listener to hear what the person is saying, mirror his or her feelings, listening to the person’s response, and communicate in a nonaggressive manner.

Question: Which of the following statements concerning enjoying healthy activities is true?
Choice 1: People enjoy pleasant activities even when they are stressed.
Choice 2: People cherish happy activities and feel that such activities are important even during times of stress.
Choice 3: People generally feel that they deserve to be happy.
Choice 4: People who have hobbies are better able to handle stress than those without hobbies.
Explanation: Hobbies, and other pleasurable activities, help people balance a stressful life.

Question: A nurse is assisting a client in values clarification. Which of the following actions should the nurse assist the client to complete first?
Choice 1: Develop a religious affiliation to assist with the process.
Choice 2: Identify what is meaningful in one’s life.
Choice 3: Act in a way that is consistent with one’s beliefs.
Choice 4: Use beliefs held by others as a guideline for life.
Explanation: Values clarification begins with examining one’s beliefs and then acting in a way that supports those beliefs. Formal religious affiliation is not required for values clarification.

Question: The nurse is caring for a person who is obese, sedentary, and has recently been diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes mellitus. Which of the following goals for the person is correctly stated?
Choice 1: The person will exercise more often.
Choice 2: The person will consume 900 calories a day.
Choice 3: The person will walk one-quarter mile a day, 5 days a week.
Choice 4: The person will eliminate all refined sugar and processed foods from her diet.
Explanation: Goals must be realistic, specific, and measurable. Exercising “more often” is too broad a statement. Consuming “900 calories a day” or “eliminating all refined sugar, processed foods, and bread products from his or her diet” is not realistic.

Question: A nurse is caring for a person who has a diagnosis of “Sleep disturbance related to stress as evidenced by excessive daytime fatigue.” Which of the following nursing interventions would most likely to assist this person?
Choice 1: Encourage daytime naps.
Choice 2: Encourage exercise one hour before bedtime.
Choice 3: Encourage a cool shower before bedtime.
Choice 4: Encourage a consistent sleep-wake schedule.
Explanation: Daytime napping, exercising within 1 hour of bedtime, and taking a cool shower prior to bedtime will not promote nighttime sleep. Following a consistent sleep-wake cycle seven days a week will help establish a sleep pattern.

Question: A nurse is educating a person about the process of cognitive restructuring. Which of the following actions should be taken at the end of this process?
Choice 1: Take a deep breath.
Choice 2: Select a realistic alternative thought.
Choice 3: Reflect on the situation.
Choice 4: Stop generating negative thoughts.
Explanation: The most effective approach to restructuring thought patterns is to first stop generating negative thoughts, then take a deep breath to relax, then think about how the thought process is affecting well-being, and last, select a new realistic thought pattern to replace the negative thought pattern.

Question: A nurse is explaining the concept of “presence.”The nurse should include that presence means that the person:
Choice 1: is in the same room as another.
Choice 2: multitasks in order to examines all aspects of a situation.
Choice 3: sets goals in response to what another is saying.
Choice 4: practices active listening and focuses on what is being said.
Explanation: The concept of “presence” means that a person’s full attention is focused on the situation at hand. Multitasking produces the opposite effect because focus is lost.

Question: A nurse is educating a group of adults about stress management strategies. Which of the following examples would the nurse include in the presentation? (select all that apply)
Choice 1: Participation in a swimming class
Choice 2: Keeping a food diary as part of a weight reduction program
Choice 3: Joining a smoking cessation support group
Choice 4: Setting a goal of walking one mile a day
Explanation: Goal setting, self-monitoring, exercise, and problem solving are all effective stress reduction strategies.

Question: The nurse in the pediatric oncology unit is working with a family whose toddler has been diagnosed with leukemia. The nurse can best assist the family to deal with this extrinsic stressor by doing which of the following? (select all that apply)
Choice 1: Setting treatment goals for them until they are able to do so themselves
Choice 2: Encouraging them to talk about their concerns
Choice 3: Discussing relaxation techniques such as guided imagery with them
Choice 4: Asking them if they would like to meet with a member of a pediatric oncology support group
Explanation: The nurse can assist this family by active listening, encouraging the family to discuss concerns, teaching them relaxation techniques, and providing access to a support group. It is not appropriate for the nurse to set goals for the family.

Question: Edelman: Health Promotion Throughout the Life Span, 8th Edition1.Which of the following statements best defines the concept of holistic nursing care?
Choice 1: Holistic nursing care is a family-centered approach to care.
Choice 2: Holistic nursing care relies primarily on alternative medicine.
Choice 3: Holistic nursing care takes into consideration all aspects of a person’s life.
Choice 4: Holistic nursing care focuses on wellness rather than illness.
Explanation: Holistic nursing care takes into account all aspects of a person’s life experiences including environmental, physical, social, spiritual, and psychological constructs.

Question: In contrast to holistic health care, Western or allopathic medicine focuses on the:
Choice 1: mind-body connection.
Choice 2: impact of family relationships on health-seeking behaviors.
Choice 3: physical aspects of health deviations.
Choice 4: environmental impact on health.
Explanation: Holistic health care focuses on the whole person, mind, body, spirituality, and so forth. Western or allopathic medicine focuses mainly on physical aspects of disease.

Question: A nurse is discussing holistic health care with an individual. Which of the following explanations should the nurse include in this discussion?
Choice 1: Empirical research has consistently demonstrated the value of alternative/complementary therapy.
Choice 2: Self-reports of stress relief related to alternative/complementary therapy are numerous.
Choice 3: The majority of research related to alternative/complementary therapy has utilized the scientific method.
Choice 4: Research has, to date, been unable to verify the effectiveness of alternative/complementary therapy on health and well-being.
Explanation: Empirical research related to the effectiveness of alternative/complementary therapy has been mixed. Some research studies have verified positive physiological reaction to this type of therapy.

Question: The nurse is conducting a community health education program concerning alternative/complementary therapies. Which of the following should be included in the presentation?
Choice 1: Alternative/complementary therapy is primarily used when conventional medicine has failed to achieve desired results.
Choice 2: Alternative/complementary therapy is used in both hospital and outpatient settings.
Choice 3: Alternative/complementary therapy was popular in the late 1980s but is rarely used today.
Choice 4: Alternative/complementary therapy primarily focuses on herbal remedies for common health deviations.
Explanation: Alternative/complementary therapy is gaining popularity in both hospital and outpatient settings. It is used as an adjunct to traditional medicine and focuses on all aspects of being (e.g., environmental, spiritual), not just herbal products.

Question: Which of the following complementary/alternative therapies involves emphasizing healthy lifestyle, strengthening and cleansing the body, and noninvasive treatments?
Choice 1: Homeopathy
Choice 2: Naturopathy
Choice 3: Traditional Chinese medicine (TCM)
Choice 4: Ayurvedic medicine
Explanation: Naturopathy is guided by the healing power of nature. Practitioners do not use prescription drugs, injections, x-rays, or surgery, but instead use a variety of complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) modalities, emphasizing healthy lifestyle, strengthening and cleansing the body, and noninvasive treatments.

Question: A nurse discussing aromatherapy at a community health fair. Which of the following aspects of this technique should be stressed?
Choice 1: Aromatherapy can be used by individuals without special training.
Choice 2: Aromatherapy is a recently developed therapy based on the work of contemporary natural healers.
Choice 3: Aromatherapy uses herbal scents in candles or incense as the primary method of delivery.
Choice 4: Aromatherapy can cause an allergic reaction in some people.
Explanation: Aromatherapy uses aromatic plant materials and the essential oils of plants to treat physical imbalances, as well as to achieve psychological and spiritual well-being through inhalation, external application or ingestion. The use of aromatherapy without professional clinical training is strongly discouraged. Individuals must have this training to know the specific warnings and contraindications for each oil, as oils may cause allergic reactions or other undesirable side effects.

Question: A nurse is instructing a person on the use of breath meditation. Which of the following instructions would the nurse give the person?
Choice 1: “You may use this form of meditation when walking down the street.”
Choice 2: “The best time of day to engage in this form of meditation is while you are eating.”
Choice 3: “Watching the sunset and reflecting on its beauty is a great way to use breath meditation.”
Choice 4: “It is important to observe your breathing when using this technique.”
Explanation: Breath meditation is the simplest form of meditation. It can be done anywhere and can evoke the relaxation response. This type of meditation should not be done while completing other activities. One should stand, sit, or lie quietly when beginning to focus on breathing. Breathing should be observed using this technique, but not controlled.

Question: A nurse is teaching a person about the technique of breath meditation. Which of the following aspects of this technique should the nurse stress to the person?
Choice 1: Hold your breath for short amounts of time in order to regulate your breathing pattern.
Choice 2: Focus on calming thoughts that come to mind during the meditation.
Choice 3: Practice this technique when sitting or walking.
Choice 4: Concentrate on the sensations associated with breathing.
Explanation: This technique should be practiced when standing, sitting, or laying quietly. Thoughts that emerge during this technique should be let go, so the focus is on the sensation of breathing. Holding one’s breath is not part of the technique.

Question: The nurse is teaching imagery as a method to reduce anxiety in preoperative individuals. Which of the following aspects should the nurse stress when teaching this technique?
Choice 1: The benefits of guided imagery are primarily psychological.
Choice 2: This technique promotes a sense of well-being.
Choice 3: A “prayer circle” is needed for imagery to be most effective.
Choice 4: Imagery produces only beneficial, calming results.
Explanation: Imagery is a gentle but powerful technique that focuses and directs the imagination in order to promote a sense of well-being and help people relax. Imagery is an individual exercise and does not include a prayer circle.

Question: An individual asks the nurse to explain yoga. Which of the following statements would be made by the nurse?
Choice 1: Yoga requires the ability to assume and maintain certain poses.
Choice 2: There are many different types of yoga.
Choice 3: Yoga is the most strenuous of the movement therapies.
Choice 4: The major benefit of yoga is an increase in physical exercise and flexibility.
Explanation: Not all forms of yoga involve physical activity. There are many forms of yoga, some of which involve meditation and others that involve movement.

Question: A nurse working at a holistic health center is asked by a person with severe rheumatoid arthritis if yoga would be a realistic therapy choice. Which of the following would be the best response by the nurse?
Choice 1: “Let’s discuss other alternative therapies. Yoga involves positioning that you might not be able to do.”
Choice 2: “Hatha yoga would be a great therapy option because it involves mediation rather than positioning.”
Choice 3: “There are many types of yoga that would be realistic for you to try. Let’s talk about the types that would be suited to your needs.”
Choice 4: “I will ask the instructor teaching karma yoga if there is room in her class for you. I think that you would enjoy this type of yoga.”
Explanation: There are many types of yoga that do not involve positioning, such as raja yoga, mantra yoga, and so forth. People should be informed about all of the choices and allowed to select the one most suited to their needs. Hatha yoga involves positioning, which might not be realistic for this individual.

Question: A nurse is describing how energy flow can affect health and well-being. Which of the following examples would the nurse discuss when sharing how energy flow can become chaotic?
Choice 1: Believing that one has been abandoned by God
Choice 2: Reestablishing contact with a friend who has recently moved back into the area
Choice 3: Recovering from an acute illness
Choice 4: Walking one mile a day
Explanation: Spiritual distress can create a chaotic energy flow. Reestablishing friendships, having a positive outcome from an illness, and exercise can balance energy.

Question: The nurse is asked to explain acupuncture to a person. Which of the following statements concerning acupuncture would the nurse include in the explanation?
Choice 1: Acupuncture is accomplished by inserting very fine needles into various areas of subcutaneous tissue.
Choice 2: Acupuncture can be used to either diagnose or treat a health deviation.
Choice 3: The main focus of acupuncture is to relieve stress.
Choice 4: Moxibustion is the term used to describe a disturbed energy flow, which results in disease.
Explanation: Acupuncture is accomplished by inserting fine needles into the skin, not subcutaneous tissue. This treatment modality is used to either treat illness or diagnose illness. Moxibustion describes using burning herbs to increase point stimulation.

Question: A person asks the nurse to explain the difference between acupuncture and acupressure. Which statement would be the appropriate response by the nurse?
Choice 1: Acupressure uses massage and oil aromatherapy to stimulate meridian points.
Choice 2: Acupuncture has been shown to relieve nausea and vomiting, but acupressure is not effective in relieving these symptoms.
Choice 3: Acupressure stimulates meridian points by using pressing and stretching movements.
Choice 4: Acupressure is achieved by applying more pressure to the fine needles inserted as part of acupuncture.
Explanation: Massage oil is not used during acupressure therapy. Both acupressure and acupuncture have been shown to relieve nausea and vomiting. Acupressure involves pressing, knuckling, rubbing, squeezing, and stretching, not by applying pressure to needles inserted during acupuncture.

Question: The nurse has just discussed reflexology with an individual. Which of the following statements would the person make that demonstrates that learning has taken place?
Choice 1: Reflexology is a therapy that uses upper back massage to control tension and stress.
Choice 2: Reflexology uses massage of acupressure points to optimize positive energy flow.
Choice 3: Reflexology uses pressure applied to specific hand and foot areas to relieve tension.
Choice 4: Reflexology uses a squeezing or stretching motion to hands or feet to restore a positive energy flow.
Explanation: Reflexology is a hand pressure technique applied to the hands or feet. It does not involve massage, squeezing, or stretching like acupressure.

Question: A nurse has completed an educational session about touch therapy with a group of adults. Which of the following statements made by an individual would demonstrate understanding of this topic?
Choice 1: “Research has shown that touch therapy is effective because it relieves stress and tension.”
Choice 2: “Touch therapy is effective because deep massage relaxes muscles.”
Choice 3: “During touch therapy the therapist’s hands may not actually touch me.”
Choice 4: “It is the massage skill of the therapist that produces the positive benefits of touch therapy.”
Explanation: Why touch therapy is effective is not known. Touch therapy does not involve massage.

Question: A nurse is performing therapeutic touch with a person. Which of the following would be the first action that the nurse would take?
Choice 1: Centering
Choice 2: Movement of hands above the body
Choice 3: Treatment technique
Choice 4: Attunement
Explanation: The first step in therapeutic touch therapy is for the therapist to become centered, so full attention can be paid to the person receiving the therapy. The second step is to assess for disturbances by moving the hands above the body. The last step involves the actual treatment techniques.

Question: A person wishes to participate in a therapy involving energy utilization and dietary design. Which of the following therapies would the nurse recommend to the person?
Choice 1: Polarity therapy
Choice 2: Reiki
Choice 3: Qi gong
Choice 4: Pranic healing
Explanation: Reiki, Qi gong, and pranic healing are all forms of touch therapy. Polarity therapy utilizes touch therapy and dietary restructuring.

Question: The nurse is assisting an individual who is interested in music therapy. Which of the following statements made by the person indicates an understanding of this type of therapy?
Choice 1: “I will select the music I listen to carefully. Energetic or rap music is not a good choice.”
Choice 2: “I will need to find someone who has specialized in this type of therapy for best results.”
Choice 3: “Chants, electronic sounds, or ‘designer music’ is generally the best choice.”
Choice 4: “The music I choose may be different than what my spouse prefers.”
Explanation: Music selection is an individual choice. There is no one “best” type of music. Family members may also benefit from the positive effects of listening to music.

Question: A nurse would like to include holistic nursing care in her nursing practice. Which of the following actions must the nurse take first?
Choice 1: Learn the specific therapy method.
Choice 2: Engage in self-exploration.
Choice 3: Explore the various types of complementary therapies available.
Choice 4: Ask the person which type of therapy he or she prefers.
Explanation: The first step to providing holistic care is an exploration of self. Each of the other steps follows that step.

Question: Which of the following describes a nurse who is “being with” the client?
Choice 1: Answers a call bell
Choice 2: Completes a dressing change
Choice 3: Silently prays with a client when requested to do so
Choice 4: Teaches a client about his or her medication regime
Explanation: Performing one’s duty or completing a task allows a nurse to “be there” with the client, but entering the client’s world and praying with him or her when requested to do so exemplifies truly “being with” the client.

Question: A nurse is providing education about safety precautions for people to take when using complementary/alternative medicine (CAM). Which of the following information would be included in this presentation?
Choice 1: Most treatments are covered by insurance.
Choice 2: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration regulates the quality of dietary supplements.
Choice 3: It is important to research and understand the treatment before starting to use it.
Choice 4: There are minimal interactions between the treatments prescribed by allopathic and holistic medicine providers.
Explanation: It is important to take time to research and understand the treatment and ensure it is appropriate for the individual and the purpose. Treatments may not be covered by insurance. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration regulates dietary supplements, but does not always regulate their quality. There may be interactions between the treatment prescribed by allopathic and holistic practitioners so both providers should know about the care and treatment provided by the other.

Question: The nurse has formulated a nursing diagnosis for a person with carpal tunnel syndrome of “Energy Field Disturbance r/t Slowing or Blocking of Energy Flow Secondary to Repetitive Motion Injury.” Which of the following actions must the nurse take first when planning interventions for this person?
Choice 1: Move his or her hands over the person.
Choice 2: Obtain permission to use healing touch therapy.
Choice 3: Explain healing touch therapy.
Choice 4: Focus on the area of disturbed energy flow.
Explanation: Before giving informed consent, the person must understand the proposed therapy.

Question: A nurse is caring for a Hispanic individual. Which question should the nurse ask the person during the assessment process?
Choice 1: “How many herbal medicines do you take?”
Choice 2: “You cannot use any herbal products in the hospital. Did you bring any?”
Choice 3: “Herbal products interact with medicine, so you cannot continue to use the herbal products. Which ones do you use?”
Choice 4: “Tell me how you treat your asthma at home. What treatments work especially well for you?”
Explanation: Many in the Hispanic culture use herbal products and alternative therapy. Keeping an open mind during the assessment process and asking open-ended questions will encourage the person to share his or her stories.

Question: Which of the following people are participating in alternative/complementary therapies? (select all that apply)
Choice 1: A 15-year-old who listens to rap music to lessen anxiety related to a painful dressing change
Choice 2: A 45-year-old who burns lavender-scented candles while meditating
Choice 3: A 7-year-old who draws as a means of communicating feelings
Choice 4: A 78-year-old who practices yoga to increase balance
Explanation: Music, art therapy, aromatherapy, and movement therapy are all alternative/complementary therapies.

Question: During an alternative therapy conference, a nurse attends a session related to massage therapy. Which of the following statements made by the presenter should the nurse question? (select all that apply)
Choice 1: “Massage therapy is most useful for individuals who are between the ages of 13 and 60.”
Choice 2: “Massage therapy involves the use of lotion or powder.”
Choice 3: “Several massage techniques can be used, including kneading and pinching the skin.”
Choice 4: “Massage therapy is best used by a licensed massage therapist.”
Explanation: Nurses frequently use massage therapy by giving back rubs. All age groups from neonates to elders can benefit from massage therapy.

Question: A 66-year-old woman with osteoarthritis of the knees and hands tells the nurse she is interested in movement therapy. Which of the following would be the most appropriate for the nurse to suggest to this person? (select all that apply)
Choice 1: Tai Chi
Choice 2: Hatha yoga
Choice 3: Qi gong
Choice 4: Dance therapy
Explanation: Tai Chi combines slow, relaxed, gentle movement with controlled breathing. Qi-gong combines relaxed movements with a meditative aspect and controlled breathing. Hatha yoga involves poses, which might be difficult for this person to achieve. Dance therapy may also be difficult for this person to complete.

Question: A nurse consultant is helping redesign a pediatric unit which is undergoing renovation. Which actions by the nurse consultant are congruent with creating a positive energy force in the unit? (select all that apply)
Choice 1: Selecting energizing colors for the playroom and soothing colors for the exam rooms
Choice 2: Planning for a music source for all rooms
Choice 3: Reducing the amount of natural light on the unit to promote relaxation
Choice 4: Planning for an atrium garden in the center of the unit
Explanation: Positive energy forces include light, color, and music. Limiting natural light has a depressive effect on some people.

Question: Edelman: Health Promotion Throughout the Life Span, 8th Edition1.The nurse is explaining the concept of growth to a parent. Which of the following statements should be made by the nurse?
Choice 1: “Growth means adding height and weight to your body.”
Choice 2: “We continue to grow in various ways throughout life.”
Choice 3: “How much we grow is based on gender.”
Choice 4: “Growth stops when we are young adults.”
Explanation: Growth, in some form, continues throughout life, not just during puberty. Not all growth is based on gender. Growth indicates more than a change in height and weight.

Question: Which of the following statements is correct related to the concept of growth
Choice 1: Growth occurs mainly during early childhood.
Choice 2: Older adults do not experience growth-related changes..
Choice 3: Growth refers only to the increase in the size of specific organs and systems.
Choice 4: Growth occurs throughout the life cycle.
Explanation: People experience developmental transitions throughout life, not just during times of rapid physical growth. Growth changes that take place in young, middle-aged, and older adults should be noted. People who think of growth only as it applies to infants, children and adolescents are missing important changes from conception throughout adulthood.

Question: The nurse at a well-baby clinic is assessing a 12-month-old child. At birth, the child weighed 7 lb. 3 oz. During this visit, the child weighs 21 lb. 10 oz. Which of the following conclusions would the nurse make about the child’s weight?
Choice 1: The infant is gaining weight faster than anticipated.
Choice 2: The infant is malnourished.
Choice 3: The infant is at the expected weight for his or her age.
Choice 4: The infant is having a growth spurt.
Explanation: A 1-year-old infant is expected to have at least doubled his or her weight by 12 months of age.
