Explanation: Retirement community living is suited for a person who is oriented to person, place, and time and has a memory that is intact, but has occasional forgetfulness without a consistent pattern of memory loss. Independent living may be appropriate for the person if she had a consistent pattern of memory loss. Assisted living or nursing facility living may be appropriate if the woman has difficulty with orientation to person, place, or time or has difficulty with confusion that results in anxiety, social withdrawal, or depression.

Question: Which of the following interventions will have the greatest impact on reducing constipation in older adults? (select all that apply)
Choice 1: Offering pureed foods that are easy to digest
Choice 2: Encouraging fluids between meals
Choice 3: Administering laxatives on a daily basis
Choice 4: Assisting with ambulation
Explanation: Nurses can help reduce the incidence of constipation by encouraging older adults to exercise and increase their fluid and dietary intake. Dietary modifications, such as increasing fiber and fluid intake, can stimulate the colon and resolve constipation. Pureed foods do not contain adequate fiber. Increased fluid intake and exercise should be implemented before relying on medication to relieve constipation.

Question: A nurse has accepted a position as director of health services in a retirement community. Which of the following statements about retirees is important for the nurse to consider as she plans programs? (select all that apply)
Choice 1: Depressed and inactive.
Choice 2: Left their job to spend more time with family.
Choice 3: Left their job because of ill health.
Choice 4: Happy and well-adjusted to retirement.
Explanation: Research has demonstrated that the majority of retirees are in good health and happy with their decision to leave work so as to spend more time with their families.

Question: The nurse working in a retirement community for older adults is conducting a psychosocial assessment of all residents. Which of the following questions should the nurse ask during the assessment process? (select all that apply)
Choice 1: “Have you thought about harming yourself?”
Choice 2: “Are you still playing bridge every Thursday?”
Choice 3: “How does your congestive heart failure affect your life?”
Choice 4: “Has your financial situation changed since last year?”
Explanation: Suicide ideation, loss of interest in activities, and chronic illness are signs of, or may lead to, depression. Economic difficulty is not a predictor of suicide in older adults.

Question: Which of the following nursing interventions implies respect for a person’s spirituality? (select all that apply)
Choice 1: Changing the position of the bed in a Muslim client’s room so that it faces east
Choice 2: Contacting the chaplain to assess the client’s spiritual needs
Choice 3: Saying a silent prayer with a client at the client’s request
Choice 4: Praying out loud in the room of a dying client
Explanation: Because of the highly personal quality of spirituality, an unobtrusive and sensitive presence by the nurse is needed to allow the person in any setting to achieve spiritual health. The nurse can provide an environment that is supportive to the practice of the person’s spirituality. Praying out loud does not demonstrate respect for a person’s spirituality but imposes the nurse’s belief system on the person. Nurses should be able to assess the person’s spirituality initially and determine if it is necessary to further consult the chaplain.

Question: A nurse is conducting a community health education program about osteoporosis with a group of older adults. Which of the following individuals in attendance is at greatest risk for developing osteoporosis? (select all that apply)
Choice 1: 65-year-old Asian woman who smokes one pack of cigarettes per week
Choice 2: 80-year-old White man who has three glasses of wine per day
Choice 3: 74-year-old White woman on daily oral prednisone for emphysema
Choice 4: 68-year-old Black man who has a sedentary lifestyle
Explanation: Osteoporosis is a disease of bone loss common to women age 70 and older and men age 80 and older. The disease occurs six times more frequently in women than it does in men. Risk factors include a small, thin frame; White or Asian ancestry; family history; excessive thyroid medication or high doses of cortisone-like drugs for asthma, arthritis, or cancer; a diet low in dairy products and other sources of calcium; physical inactivity; smoking cigarettes; and drinking alcohol.

Question: An 80-year-old person is admitted to the hospital. During the health assessment process, which of the following conditions should the person be screened for by the nurse? (select all that apply)
Choice 1: Polypharmacy
Choice 2: Kidney failure
Choice 3: Illegal drug use
Choice 4: Alcoholism
Explanation: Alcoholism and illegal drug use are often overlooked by health care professionals because of a person’s age. Many older adults take multiple over-the-counter and prescription medications and are at risk for drug interactions.

Question: Edelman: Health Promotion Throughout the Life Span, 8th Edition1.A nurse is encouraging members of the community to advocate for the prevention of premature deaths in children under the age of 5 at the international level. Which of the following interventions would most likely be discussed by the nurse?
Choice 1: Using mosquito netting in sleeping areas
Choice 2: Participating in international vaccination programs
Choice 3: Implementing accident prevention programs
Choice 4: Providing nutritional supplements
Explanation: Protein-energy malnutrition can be severely harmful to the mental and physical development of individuals, especially young children under the age of 5. Worldwide, one out of two deaths among children younger than 5 years old stems from protein-energy malnutrition.

Question: A nurse is working at a clinic in a third world country and suspects a child has severe acute malnutrition (SAM). Which of the following assessment findings would be expected?
Choice 1: Distended abdomen
Choice 2: Bulging eyes
Choice 3: Large tears when crying
Choice 4: Lethargy
Explanation: Severe wasting is characterized by sunken eyes, visible ribs, and protruding shoulder blades. Children with severe wasting usually have a distended abdomen and general overall appearance in some way similar to an older adult. In general, these children are irritable, anxious, and cry easily; yet they will often have absence of tears while crying due to lachrymal gland atrophy.

Question: A nurse is determining if children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) should receive facility-based or community-based care. Which of the following children should receive care in the community?
Choice 1: 3-year-old male who has a history of dehydration
Choice 2: 9-month-old male whose family has adequate support and resources to obtain the recommended treatment
Choice 3: 4-year-old female who has sensitivity to milk products
Choice 4: 6-month-old female who has a good appetite and no underlying medical conditions
Explanation: When a child has a good appetite with no medical conditions (hypoglycemia, hypothermia, dehydration, electrolyte imbalance, and/or infections), Ready-to-Use Therapeutic Foods (RUTF) under community-based care are appropriate. RUTF are special milk-based foods which are soft, crushable, and tasty nutrient- and energy-rich foods that can be consumed by children six months or older.

Question: A nurse working on a post-partum unit of a large urban hospital has received a grant to begin a “Baby-Friendly Hospital Initiative” developed by WHO. Which of the following statements would the nurse most likely make when explaining the major premises of the initiative to the unit manager?
Choice 1: “This program is meant to encourage sibling visits in the early postpartum period, so the adjustment to a new baby is a smooth process.”
Choice 2: “A major goal of this program is to ensure that all infant/pediatric units have implemented basic safety initiatives.”
Choice 3: “Improving nutrition by promoting breast-feeding of newborns through four months of age is what this program is all about.”
Choice 4: “The purpose of this program is to make sure that all health care providers who care for newborns and children up to the age of 18 really understand basic principles of growth and development.”
Explanation: The purpose of the initiative is to improve newborn nutrition by promoting breast-feeding of newborns through age 4 months.

Question: Which of the following projects would most likely be administered by International Micronutrient Malnutrition Prevention and Control (IMMPaCT) Program?
Choice 1: Researching best methods to preserve the freshness of foods
Choice 2: Surveying various populations about consumption patterns
Choice 3: Comparing the effectiveness of vitamin pills versus fresh fruit and vegetables
Choice 4: Analyzing the relationship between BMI and cardiovascular disease
Explanation: IMMPaCt provides its skills and resources toward working to eradicate vitamin and mineral deficiencies around the globe. The IMMPaCT program’s activities include conducting surveys; providing micronutrients to infants, young children, and women of childbearing age; and monitoring and evaluating intervention systems.

Question: The school nurse has been asked to present a workshop on CA-MRSA for high school teachers. Which of the following information would the nurse most likely include?
Choice 1: CA-MRSA is a common viral infection that responds well to antiviral meds.
Choice 2: CA-MRSA is a serious bacterial infection that does not spread easily.
Choice 3: CA-MRSA is a fungal infection common in school settings.
Choice 4: CA-MRSA is a potentially fatal skin infection that is difficult to treat.
Explanation: CA-MRSA is a highly contagious bacterial infection that is difficult to treat and can result in pneumonia and death.

Question: The school nurse has been asked to present a workshop on how to prevent CA-MRSA spread in the school. Which of the following interventions should be emphasized?
Choice 1: Completing prophylactic antibiotic therapy for those in close contact with an infected person
Choice 2: Using correct hand-washing technique
Choice 3: Requiring those infected stay home from school until the infection has resolved
Choice 4: Disinfecting all classrooms on a daily basis
Explanation: Hand washing is an effective way to prevent spread of the infection. In order to contract the infection, students must come into contact with a draining wound, etc.

Question: A nurse is providing care to HIV positive clients living in sub-Saharan communities in Africa. When discussing prevention of the transmission of HIV, which of the following statements should be made by the nurse?
Choice 1: “Alternative practices to traditional sexual cleansing should be considered after the death of a spouse.”
Choice 2: “Traditional sexual cleansing should be performed with a cleanser who is known to not have HIV.”
Choice 3: “Virgin cleansing is a safer option than traditional sexual cleansing.”
Choice 4: “Traditional sexual cleansing can lead to further transmission of HIV.”
Explanation: Although traditional sexual cleansing can lead to further transmission of HIV is a true statement, it is not the most culturally sensitive response by the nurse. The nurse should respect the cultural practices of the clients living in the sub-Saharan community and discuss that alternative practices may be a better option to traditional sexual cleansing.

Question: A nurse is working with UNAIDS to fight against HIV/AIDS at the global level. Which of the following activities would the nurse most likely be involved in?
Choice 1: Determining prevalence rates of HIV/AIDS in African countries
Choice 2: Administering antiretroviral medications to pregnant women who are HIV positive
Choice 3: Providing treatment access for all HIV-positive individuals who need medication
Choice 4: Reporting confirmed cases of HIV to the World Health Organization
Explanation: UNAIDS has outlined three strategic directions:  revolutionizing HIV prevention; catalyzing the next generation for treatment, care, and support; and advancing human rights and gender equality in responses to HIV. Providing treatment access for all HIV-positive individuals who need medication meets the strategic direction of catalyzing the next generation for treatment, care, and support.

Question: A nurse is using the four-step public health approach to address violence in the community. Which of the following actions would the nurse take first?
Choice 1: Analyze a variety of data sources to determine the cause of the problem.
Choice 2: Examine risk factors that have contributed to the violence.
Choice 3: Develop an evidence-based program to address the problem.
Choice 4: Train community members to discuss the problem within their neighborhoods.
Explanation: The WHO has proposed a four-step public health approach which includes: defining the problem; identifying risks and protective factors; devising and testing means of dealing with violence; and applying successful means on a large scale. Defining the problem is the first step in this process. Examination of different data sources are needed to understand the magnitude of the problem.

Question: A nurse using the four-step public health approach to respond to violence. Which of the following actions would occur as the nurse identifies risk and protective factors?
Choice 1: Planning a community-based educational program to respond to violence
Choice 2: Reviewing police reports and population-based surveys
Choice 3: Interviewing local community members about their experiences with violence
Choice 4: Examining characteristics in the community where violence has not occurred
Explanation: A “risk factor” is defined as “a characteristic that increases the likelihood of a person becoming a victim or perpetrator of violence,” and a “protective factor” as “a characteristic that decreases the likelihood of a person becoming a victim or perpetrator of violence.” Knowing risk and protective factors can help responsible organizations and personnel to estimate violence magnitudes and devise appropriate prevention measures.

Question: The school nurse is planning a workshop for high school students about interpersonal violence (IPV). Which of the following information would the nurse discuss as risk factors for IPV?
Choice 1: Cultural norms
Choice 2: Family support
Choice 3: Drug and alcohol abuse
Choice 4: Depression
Explanation: Risk factors for IPV may include a victim’s low self-esteem, low self-control, and personality/conduct disorders. Other risk factors are reported to be lack of social support, dysfunctional family structure, family history of violence, and drug and alcohol abuse.

Question: The nurse is working at a crisis hotline center. Which of the following callers would be most at risk for suicide?
Choice 1: A 16-year-old girl who broke up with her boyfriend
Choice 2: A 26-year-old male who has been laid off from his job
Choice 3: A 50-year-old female who has a history of alcohol abuse
Choice 4: A 40-year-old male whose brother died suddenly
Explanation: Older adults have a greater risk of committing suicide than do younger people. Major factors contributing to suicide in Europe and North America include mental disorders especially depression and alcohol use disorders.

Question: Which of the following age groups is experiencing the greatest increase in suicide rates?
Explanation: Suicide rates among people aged 15 to 24 have been increasing to such an extent that they are the second leading cause of death in this age group in some developed and developing countries.

Question: Which of the following information about anthrax is correct?
Choice 1: Anthrax is a viral infection.
Choice 2: Anthrax can cause skin lesions or pneumonia.
Choice 3: Anthrax is spread by person-to-person contact.
Choice 4: Anthrax is treated by IV penicillin for 30 days.
Explanation: Anthrax is a bacillus that is not spread person-to-person. An anthrax infection is treated by using ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, doxycycline, or penicillin for 60 days.

Question: Which of the following statements about smallpox is accurate?
Choice 1: Smallpox results in a rash that looks similar to the chickenpox rash.
Choice 2: Side effects from a smallpox vaccine include acute renal failure.
Choice 3: The last case of smallpox occurred in 1997.
Choice 4: The rash associated with smallpox is most prominent on the face and extremities.
Explanation: A rash from smallpox is most prominent on the face and extremities with the same stage of legion development. Additionally, smallpox symptoms usually resemble influenza symptoms. The smallpox rash is distinctive from the varicella rash. Side effects from the vaccination mostly involve a low fever, soreness in the injection area, and enlarged glands under the armpit. The last case of smallpox was in 1977.

Question: A nurse is working in the emergency department (ED). Which of the following situations would cause the nurse to suspect bioterrorism?
Choice 1: When two people out of twenty who ate at a restaurant come to the ED with nausea and vomiting
Choice 2: When a worker in a lab comes to the ED complaining of a severe headache
Choice 3: When thirteen people, aged 24 to 33, come to the ED with ascending flaccid muscle paralysis
Choice 4: When five people come to the ED with an upper respiratory infection
Explanation: The other examples are common problems for which people seek health care. Flaccid paralysis is a symptom of botulism.

Question: Which of the following statements best explains priorities related to preventative health care?
Choice 1: Global initiatives have been developed to respond to health care needs around the world.
Choice 2: Health care initiatives are focused mainly on people in developed countries because of the access to medication.
Choice 3: Health care initiatives are focused mainly on people in developing countries because of their great need.
Choice 4: Public health agencies are leaders in health care development.
Explanation: Health care initiatives have a global focus and involve developing as well as developed countries. Nurses play a major role in this initiative.

Question: A nurse states that many community members are concerned about the increasing number of natural disasters that have been occurring in the United States. Which of the following would the community members be referring to?
Choice 1: Fires and suicides
Choice 2: Wildfires and hurricanes
Choice 3: Traffic accidents and floods
Choice 4: Tornadoes and food poisonings
Explanation: Natural disasters phenomena that occur through natural forces involving land, air, or water, and they often have large-scale negative impacts on humans who live in the affected areas. Examples of natural disasters include tsunamis, earthquakes, floods, landslides, mudslides, tornadoes, hurricanes, cyclones, typhoons, wildfires, volcano eruptions, extreme heat, winter weather, and others.

Question: A hurricane has just caused extensive damage within a local community. Which of the following are community members at risk to experience?
Choice 1: Unequal access to health care
Choice 2: Exposure to community-associated methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus
Choice 3: Increased incidence of suicide
Choice 4: Outbreaks of acute respiratory infection
Explanation: Victims of natural disasters tend to have limited access to essential infrastructures for survival related to food, water, shelter, and sanitation. Infection outbreaks commonly diagnosed after natural disasters include diarrhea, acute respiratory infections, viral hepatitis, and snail and trematode infections.

Question: A primary care clinic is being established in a rural county that recently experienced a hurricane severely damaging its infrastructure for medical care. Which of the following considerations would be the priority when planning for this clinic?
Choice 1: The ability to provide mental health services to community members
Choice 2: The ability to deliver primary care services to community members
Choice 3: The ability to refer community members to other necessary services
Choice 4: The ability to supply community members with daily necessities
Explanation: The priority in planning should be the ability to provide mental health services to the community members. In 2007, the Inter-Agency Standing Committee developed its Guidelines on Mental Health and Psychosocial Support in Emergency Setting. It emphasizes the importance of primary care clinics being able to provide mental health services to victims of the disaster.

Question: A nurse is advocating for improved disease prevention and health promotion within the local community. Which of the following interventions would the nurse most likely implement?
Choice 1: Educate community members about the violence rates that exist within the community.
Choice 2: Administer flu shots for elderly at a local senior citizens center.
Choice 3: Participate in a disaster planning committee within the community.
Choice 4: Talk with a state legislator about improved access to health care for the uninsured and underinsured.
Explanation: In order to be advocates for newly emerging priorities for disease prevention and health promotion, nurses in the twenty-first century need to participate in policy development for health promotion as the health care of individuals in acute settings shifts from hospitals to home and community settings, influence public expectations about health promotion, and promote equitable access to preventive health care. Talking with a state legislator about improving access to health care for the uninsured and underinsured is the only example that demonstrates the nurse in the role of an advocate working in one of these priority areas.

Question: Which of the following are classifications within the World Health Organization’s (WHO) definition of malnutrition? (select all that apply)
Choice 1: Obesity
Choice 2: Micronutrients deficiencies
Choice 3: Protein-energy malnutrition
Choice 4: Water insufficiency
Explanation: Inadequate or excessive intake of protein and or vitamins and obesity are components of the WHO’s definition of malnutrition.

Question: Which of the following individuals would be susceptible to CA-MRSA? (select all that apply)
Choice 1: 16-year-old student who plays football
Choice 2: 48-year-old person who has taken antibiotics for sinus infections
Choice 3: 36-year-old man serving 12 months in jail for robbery
Choice 4: 22-year-old woman who shares a towel after a swimming meet
Explanation: CA-MRSA is spread by close skin-to-skin contact such as during contact sports, by sharing towels and clothing, and by those living in crowded conditions. People who take or who have been on antibiotic therapy are also susceptible to CA-MRSA.

Question: A nurse employed by the World Health Organization is working with HIV positive clients in Africa and is teaching them about ways to reduce transmission of this disease. Which of the following barriers should be considered when planning this education? (select all that apply)
Choice 1: Culture-specific practices
Choice 2: Unavailability of antibiotic therapy
Choice 3: Lack of understanding about the transmission process
Choice 4: Overcrowded living areas
Explanation: Culture-specific sexual practices such as “sexual cleansing” and a lack of understanding about how HIV is spread contribute to its transmission. HIV is a viral infection, not a bacterial infection. Simply living with someone who has HIV will not result in transmission unless the person comes into contact with blood or bodily fluid from the infected person.

Question: A school nurse is planning an educational presentation for high school students about violence. Which of the following statements would be included in the presentation? (select all that apply)
Choice 1: “Violent behavior happens when someone bullies another person.”
Choice 2: “Withholding food from a child as a punishment is violent behavior.”
Choice 3: “Collective violence occurs during an argument between two people.”
Choice 4: “Painting a racial slur on a building is violent behavior.”
Explanation: Violent behavior as defined by WHO is the intentional use of physical force or power, threatened or actual against oneself, another person, or against a group or community, that either results in or has a high likelihood of resulting in injury, death, psychological harm, maldevelopment, or deprivation. Collective violence is defined as the instrumental use of violence by a particular group of people for specific political, economic, or social objectives.

Question: Which of the following individuals assessed by the nurse is experiencing interpersonal violence? (select all that apply)
Choice 1: A 16-year-old female who hides in her apartment due to civil unrest in the country
Choice 2: A 32-year-old male whose co-worker sends him insulting e-mails at work
Choice 3: A 19-year old male who has attempted suicide
Choice 4: A 78-year-old female living in a nursing home who is force-fed by aides
Explanation: Interpersonal violence is violence committed by an individual or a small group of people in a wide range of acts and behaviors (emotional, physical, sexual, and psychological). The violence can happen to people of any age and at any place. Self-directed violence occurs with self-abuse and suicide. Collective violence is defined as the instrumental use of violence by a particular group of people for specific political, economic, or social objectives.

Question: A nurse is participating in disaster preparedness planning for the local community. Which of the following would be an appropriate responsibility for the nurse? (select all that apply)
Choice 1: Completing a risk assessment in the community
Choice 2: Implementing strategies to decrease posttraumatic stress disorder
Choice 3: Coordinating meetings among multiple agencies and disciplines
Choice 4: Evaluating the economic impact of the disaster
Explanation: The International Council for Nurses spells out its position on the role of the nurse concerning disaster preparedness to include risk assessment as well as management strategies bridging multiple disciplines and system levels. To coordinate health sector preparedness, regulatory meetings and frameworks across cultures will help nurses plan for and streamline health care responses to such mass events internationally.

Question: Edelman: Health Promotion Throughout the Life Span, 8th Edition1.Which addition to a community best demonstrates the concept of the Healthy People 2020 report?
Choice 1: New cardiothoracic intensive care unit at a major hospital
Choice 2: New rehabilitation center
Choice 3: New recreational health center
Choice 4: New children’s hospital
Explanation: The Healthy People 2020 report promotes health care, not illness care. A hospital, ICU, and rehabilitation center emphasize episodic care after an illness. The recreation health center serves to preserve health in the community and helps meet the goals of the Healthy People 2020 report.

Question: Which nurse is at risk of making a medical error?
Choice 1: Working overtime
Choice 2: Works in a hospital that advocates multidisciplinary care
Choice 3: Caring for four clients during the shift
Choice 4: Attends regular continuing education programs
Explanation: Health care systems are the basic cause of medical errors. Organizational and workforce management, work design, and organizational culture are problem areas that contribute to medical errors. Poor management leads to increased nurse turnover, the need for increased client-to-nurse ratios, increased need for overtime, and decreased number of nurses, all of which can lead to medical errors. A nurse working overtime is at risk of making a medical error.

Question: What is the most effective policy a staff nurse can implement to help decrease medical errors on the unit?
Choice 1: Forgo opportunities for continuing education so the unit is never understaffed.
Choice 2: Foster a collaborative working environment on the unit.
Choice 3: Check all medications a minimum of three times before administering them.
Choice 4: Develop a policy that mandates the firing of any nurse who commits an error.
Explanation: Health care systems are the basic cause of medical errors. Organizational and workforce management, work design, and organizational culture are problem areas that contribute to medical errors. Creating a collaborative working environment helps improve organizational culture, thereby reducing the chance of medical errors.

Question: The person known as the father of British and American public health is:
Choice 1: Lillian Wald.
Choice 2: Edwin Chadwick.
Choice 3: Lemuel Shattuck.
Choice 4: Paul Ehrlich.
Explanation: Edwin Chadwick is known as the father of British and American public health.

Question: A community health nurse most effectively preserves the health of a person with tuberculosis (TB) and the community by:
Choice 1: administering and reading the purified protein derivative (PPD) of all close contacts
Choice 2: providing direct observed therapy (DOT) for the individual with TB
Choice 3: isolating the person because it is likely drug resistant
Choice 4: telling the person to wear a mask when leaving the home
Explanation: Community health nursing practice promotes, preserves, and maintains the health of populations and the effect of their health status on that of the community as a whole through care provided to individuals, families, and groups. Thus, the most effective strategy of treating the individual and preventing the spread of TB is to provide DOT.

Question: A community planning committee is working on the development of a community nursing center. Which of the following essential components should be included in this center?
Choice 1: Physician as medical director
Choice 2: Interdisciplinary staff
Choice 3: Nurse as chief manager
Choice 4: Partnership with an academic institution
Explanation: The essential components of a community nursing center include a nurse as chief manager, a nursing staff that is accountable and responsible for care and professional practice, and nurses as the primary providers of care.

Question: Considering the provider and client perspective, which of the following is the most autonomous form of insurance?
Choice 1: Fee-for-service plan
Choice 2: Health maintenance organization (HMO)
Choice 3: Preferred provider organization (PPO)
Choice 4: Independent practice association (IPA)
Explanation: In the fee-for-service plan, a provider provides a service and bills the individual’s insurance company. The individual is also allowed to choose his or her provider.

Question: Which could result in a change in a nurse practitioner’s practice?
Choice 1: Holding a master’s degree or higher
Choice 2: Moving to another state when she gets married
Choice 3: Caring for Medicare clients
Choice 4: Changing to another office within the same practice
Explanation: Nurse practitioners generally hold master’s degrees or higher. The nurse practice act within their states may be more comprehensive than the institutions for which they work. Legislation exists for reimbursement of nurse practitioners by Medicare. However, practice acts and prescriptive authority vary from state to state and thus influence practice patterns.

Question: Which health care provider represents a primary care provider?
Choice 1: Psychiatric advanced practice nurse
Choice 2: Clinical nurse specialist
Choice 3: Pediatric nurse practitioner
Choice 4: Acute care nurse practitioner
Explanation: A primary care provider serves as a gatekeeper, coordinating care of individuals by determining the need for referrals and procedures. A primary care provider can be a physician, physician’s assistant, or advanced practice nurse in a primary care setting. The primary care provider provides basic and routine care usually in an office or a clinic. A pediatric nurse practitioner is an example of a primary care provider.

Question: Which form of managed care restricts providers to caring for individuals who are members of their organization?
Choice 1: Fee-for-service plan
Choice 2: Health maintenance organization (HMO)
Choice 3: Preferred provider organization (PPO)
Choice 4: Independent practice association (IPA)
Explanation: The traditional HMO was a group or staff model in which a group of physicians and some specialty services provided care to its members. Providers generally spent all their time serving members of the HMO. Fee-for-service, IPAs, and PPOs are not restricted to serving clients for any one organization.

Question: A Medicare client reports to the home care nurse that he is receiving care through an accountable care organization (ACO). Which of the following considerations should be made when delivering care to this individual?
Choice 1: The individual must see a primary care provider before being referred to a specialist.
Choice 2: The focus of care is prevention and management of individuals with chronic disease.
Choice 3: The individual has paid a membership fee to be part of this organization.
Choice 4: The focus of care is to conserve money in a health savings account.
Explanation: The focus of care of accountable care organizations (ACOs) is to focus on prevention and management of individuals with chronic disease out of the hospital. In an ACO, physicians accept the responsibility for the quality of care provided and overall costs of delivering care to a defined population of patients. Accountable care organizations are composed of physicians, specialists, and hospitals, so a specialist will be able to be seen within the ACO. Individuals who are part of concierge care pay a membership fee in return for enhanced health care services or amenities. Health savings accounts are used in conjunction with high deductible health insurance plans and are not related to the use of ACOs.

Question: An individual states that his family has insurance, but that paying for routine medical costs is very expensive because most routine services are paid for out of pocket. Which type of insurance plan does this individual most likely have?
Choice 1: High deductible health insurance plan (HDHP)
Choice 2: Point-of-service plan (POS)
Choice 3: Health maintenance organization (HMO)
Choice 4: Preferred provider organization (PPO)
Explanation: High deductible health insurance plans (HDHPs) are structured in a way similar to traditional managed care plans and fee-for-service plans but have a very high annual out-of-pocket deductible. Thus, a family with this type of insurance will pay out-of-pocket until they reach the deductible, which may make receiving health services expensive for them. Point-of-service plans allow members, for an additional fee and higher copayment, to use providers outside of the HMO network. Health maintenance organizations (HMOs) deliver comprehensive health maintenance and treatment services for a group of enrolled individuals who prepay a fixed fee. Preferred provider organizations (PPOs) have a preselected list of providers who have agreed to provide health services for those enrolled in the plan.

Question: Which of the following is a health plan consisting of hospitals and physician providers providing health care services to plan members (usually at discounted rates) in return for expedited claims payment?
Choice 1: Health maintenance organization (HMO)
Choice 2: Health savings account (HSA)
Choice 3: Preferred provider organization (PPO)
Choice 4: Independent practice association (IPA)
Explanation: A health plan consisting of hospitals and physician providers providing health care services to plan members (usually at discounted rates) in return for expedited claims payment is known as a preferred provider organization (PPO).

Question: Two working adults do not have access to health insurance for their family from their employers and do not meet the financial criteria for Medicaid. For which of the following federal programs may the children in this family be eligible?
Choice 1: Medicare
Choice 2: Civilian Health Medical Program for Uniformed Services (CHAMPUS)
Choice 3: State Children’s Health Insurance Program (SCHIP)
Choice 4: Veteran’s Administration Program
Explanation: The State Children’s Health Insurance Program is a public state insurance program established to provide insurance to uninsured children whose family is typically described as the working poor and do not meet Medicaid requirements. In this case, both parents work but do not have access to insurance through their employers. Additionally, they do not meet the financial Medicaid requirement.

Question: A nurse complies with the Patient Self-Determination Act when asking:
Choice 1: a person upon admission to the hospital if he or she has an advanced directive
Choice 2: the family in the recovery room if the client has an advanced directive
Choice 3: a person before discharge from the hospital if he or she has an advance directive
Choice 4: the family about an advanced directive after the person has been intubated
Explanation: The Patient Self-Determination Act is designed to increase individual involvement in decisions about life-sustaining treatments. The nurse must ensure that advanced directives are available to physicians at the time the medical decision is being made. Therefore, the nurse complies with the act when she asks a person upon admission to the hospital if he or she has an advanced directive.

Question: A nurse discussing the care of a person on the surgical unit following gastric bypass surgery with a friend is in violation of the:
Choice 1: Patient Self-Determination Act
Choice 2: Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996
Choice 3: Americans with Disabilities Act
Choice 4: Civil Rights Act
Explanation: The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 (HIPAA) is a federal privacy standard that requires safeguards to protect the security and confidentiality of health information. Disclosures without individual authorization are allowed only to public health authorities authorized by law to collect and receive information for the purpose of preventing or controlling disease, injury, or disability.

Question: Which is a violation of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996?
Choice 1: Nurse reporting a case of TB to the health department
Choice 2: Nurse reporting a case of child abuse to the Department of Human Services
Choice 3: Nurse discussing the person’s case with his or her physician
Choice 4: Nurse discussing the person’s case with his or her school nurse
Explanation: The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 (HIPAA) is a federal privacy standard that requires safeguards to protect the security and confidentiality of health information. Disclosures without individual authorization are allowed only to public health authorities authorized by law to collect and receive information for the purpose of preventing or controlling disease, injury, or disability. Before speaking to the school nurse, the nurse must obtain authorization from the client’s parents.

Question: Which nurse is functioning as a care manager?
Choice 1: Nurse working with a family to coordinate care after their child experiences a second hospitalization for an asthma exacerbation
Choice 2: Nurse providing asthma education in the office setting to a child with moderate, persistent asthma
Choice 3: Nurse administering the appropriate antiinflammatory medication to a child admitted to the hospital with an asthma exacerbation
Choice 4: Nurse making a home visit for a respiratory assessment to a child following an admission for an asthma exacerbation
Explanation: Care managers help determine what medical care is necessary, monitor care, and arrange for individuals to receive the most cost-effective care in the most appropriate settings. They must collaborate with providers and with the client/family. Care managers are especially helpful following a client after discharge and clients with complex needs. A nurse working with a family to coordinate service after a hospitalization is a good example of services provided by a care manager.

Question: A pregnant woman with two toddlers living at less than 135% of the federal poverty level would be eligible for:
Choice 1: Medicare Part A
Choice 2: Medicare Part B
Choice 3: Medicaid
Choice 4: State Children’s Health Insurance Program (SCHIP)
Explanation: State Medicaid programs must cover all pregnant women and children up to 6 years of age with a family income of less than 133% of the federal poverty level. States Children’s Health Insurance Program provides insurance coverage to children whose family income is below 200% of the federal poverty level or whose income is 50% higher than the state’s Medicaid eligibility threshold. In this case, the woman is pregnant, her children are under the age of 6, and they meet the financial criteria for Medicaid but not SCHIP.

Question: Which of the following is a major factor limiting health care services in the United States?
Choice 1: Lack of nurses
Choice 2: Lack of health care facilities
Choice 3: Lack of funding
Choice 4: Lack of client interest in health promotion
Explanation: The lack of nurses may prevent health care providers from offering health promotional education activities. The cost of health care and prescription drugs is a major limitation to health care services. The United States has the highest proportion of population with no health insurance, thereby limiting health care services available to Americans.

Question: Which person is at highest risk for being uninsured?
Choice 1: 68-year-old retired mailman
Choice 2: 48-year-old on renal dialysis
Choice 3: 2-year-old whose parents work but do not have benefits through their employers
Choice 4: 27-year-old who attends college and works part time in a small pizza parlor
Explanation: Young adults (27 years of age or older) are not eligible to be covered under their parents’ insurance. Medicare is available for those over the age of 65 and for people who require dialysis. Medicaid and SCHIP are available for children whose families meet the financial requirements. This child would likely meet criteria for either Medicaid or SCHIP because the parents are considered working poor. Because health care insurance is so expensive, it would be difficult for a 27-year-old to afford his or her own plan. Young adults often go without insurance because of the high costs.

Question: Adoption of a Canadian-style health care system in the United States has the potential to:
Choice 1: decrease waiting times for tests and procedures.
Choice 2: create further health disparities.
Choice 3: increase the number of HMOs.
Choice 4: increase the amount of funding available for health care.
Explanation: Canadians with private health insurance and higher incomes have access to greater health care services and more expedient health care. This translates to a two-tier system of health care, which can contribute to health disparities in health care access and quality.

Question: A system used to evaluate the necessity, appropriateness, and efficiency of the use of the health care system, the purpose of which is to lower costs by discouraging unnecessary treatments, is known as:
Choice 1: managed care
Choice 2: gate keeping
Choice 3: utilization review
Choice 4: capitation
Explanation: A system used to evaluate the necessity, appropriateness, and efficiency of the use of the health care system, the purpose of which is to lower costs by discouraging unnecessary treatments, is known as utilization review.

Question: The country with the lowest infant mortality rate in 2011 was:
Choice 1: Canada
Choice 2: Mexico
Choice 3: Sweden
Choice 4: the United States
Explanation: Sweden had the lowest infant mortality in 2011 with a mortality rate of 2.74 per 1000 live births.

Question: The country with the highest life expectancy for women in 2011 was:
Choice 1: France
Choice 2: Germany
Choice 3: Sweden
Choice 4: the United States
Explanation: France was the country with the highest life expectancy for women (85 years of age) in 2011.

Question: A community health nurse is presenting information about the current health of the nation to a local political action group in 2011. Which of the following information would be included in this presentation? (select all that apply)
Choice 1: Funding of public health programs has improved the health of the nation.
Choice 2: Provision of health care has improved the health of the nation.
Choice 3: Advances in technology have improved the health of the nation.
Choice 4: Consumer education has improved the health of the nation.
Explanation: According to the 2010 Report of Health, the health of the nation has improved in many areas as a result of substantial funding of public health programs, research, provision of health care, and initiatives to support consumer education.

Question: Which of the following statements about the financing of health care in the United States is accurate? (select all that apply)
Choice 1: Employee-sponsored health insurance premiums experienced minimal increases from 2001 to 2011.
Choice 2: State tax dollars must fund at least 50% of a state’s Medicaid cost.
Choice 3: The largest percentage of health care dollars is spent on hospital care.
Choice 4: Most workers who have an employer-sponsored health insurance plan are enrolled in preferred provider organizations (PPOs).
Explanation: In 2010, almost one third (31%) of health care dollars was spent on hospital care. The majority of employee-covered workers were enrolled in PPOs (55%). Employee-sponsored health insurance premiums rose dramatically from 2001 to 2011 by 113%. Federal dollars must fund a minimum of 50% of a state’s Medicaid cost; the state is responsible for contributing whatever percentage is not funded by the federal government.

Question: Which of the following would be considered part of a vulnerable population? (select all that apply)
Choice 1: Deaf man
Choice 2: Cocaine-addicted teenage girl
Choice 3: Handicapped child
Choice 4: College graduate
Explanation: Those who are physically disabled or handicapped, substance abusers, and those with communication difficulties are considered part of the vulnerable population in the United States.

Question: Edelman: Health Promotion Throughout the Life Span, 8th Edition1.Which of the following statements about values is true?
Choice 1: It is impossible for someone to understand his or her values.
Choice 2: Values evolve over time; they are not static.
Choice 3: Values assimilated in childhood are those held for a lifetime.
Choice 4: Values clarification tells a person how to act.
Explanation: Values take time to develop, and they may change with education, experience, exposure, or a combination of these.

Question: A nurse is providing education about improving self-awareness to a small group of women who have been victims of domestic violence. Which of the following should the nurse recommend the clients do first to improve their self-awareness?
Choice 1: Use self-disclosure to share aspects of self.
Choice 2: Listen to and learn from others.
Choice 3: Listen to oneself and pay attention to emotions, thoughts, and reactions.
Choice 4: Use others to bounce back your own thoughts and recollections.
Explanation: To achieve a high self-awareness, three steps must be taken. The first step is listening to oneself and paying attention to emotions, thoughts, memories, reactions, and impulses. The second step is listening to and learning from others. The third step is using self-disclosure to share aspects of self.

Question: The nurse shares with her client the news that she, the nurse, is going to be married soon and tells the client about her wedding plans. Which of the following best describes the nurse’s actions?
Choice 1: The nurse is sharing inappropriate personal information with her client.
Choice 2: The nurse is exhibiting a communication technique called self-disclosure.
Choice 3: The nurse is attempting to show empathy with her client.
Choice 4: The nurse is violating client confidentiality rights of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA).
Explanation: Sharing aspects of the self enriches interpersonal life and is a use of the technique labeled self-disclosure.

Question: A nurse has started admitting a new person on home care and is beginning to establish a relationship. Which of the following would be the most important thing for the nurse to do?
Choice 1: Complete the paperwork in a timely fashion
Choice 2: Establish open communication
Choice 3: Conduct a complete physical health assessment
Choice 4: Provide feedback to the person’s questions
Explanation: Communication is the foundation for any professional relationship. It is the cornerstone of a positive nurse-person relationship. It refers to a set of strategies and actions to enhance reciprocity, mutual understanding, and decision making.

Question: Which of the following best describes person-centered communication?
Choice 1: The nurse says to the person seeking care, “Why do you continue to drink when you know it is not good for you?”
Choice 2: The nurse responds to person seeking care’s request for pain medicine by saying, “It is not time for your pain medicine. You had it [PIC_20170114132026_0014.jpg]  hours ago.”
Choice 3: The client says to the nurse, “I think my husband is cheating on me.” The nurse responds by saying, “You think your husband is cheating on you?”
Choice 4: The client says to the nurse, “I can’t believe I have cancer.” The nurse responds by saying, “One of my closest friends had cancer and had to have chemotherapy.”
Explanation: The nurse recognizes that the person seeking care has some concerns that she would like to discuss and paraphrases her statement to give the person an opportunity to elaborate on thoughts that are important to him or her.

Question: A nurse is counseling someone who has recently been diagnosed with diabetes. The nurse says, “Tell me more about how this diagnosis has affected your daily activities.” Which of the following best describes the type of communication the nurse is using?
Choice 1: Verbal communication
Choice 2: Nonverbal communication
Choice 3: Metacommunication
Choice 4: Functional communication
Explanation: Verbal communication is the transmission of messages using words, spoken or written. Nonverbal communication encompasses all messages that are not spoken or written. Metacommunication refers to a message about the message, the relationship aspect of communication.

Question: Which of the following statements about nonverbal communication is true?
Choice 1: Nonverbal behavior is not usually contextual.
Choice 2: Nonverbal behavior is culturally and situationally bound.
Choice 3: Nonverbal communication is the most important type of communication.
Choice 4: Nonverbal communication is easy to interpret.
Explanation: Cultural exposure and situational impact are essential components of interpreting nonverbal communication and must be taken into consideration in attempts to interpret nonverbal communication.

Question: Which of the following scenarios best describes a nurse using metacommunication?
Choice 1: Using both touch and silence when counseling an individual
Choice 2: Practicing reflection when interaction with an individual
Choice 3: Discussing with an individual how to solve a problem
Choice 4: Understanding that an individual needs a break before proceeding
Explanation: Metacommunication refers to a message about the message. It is the relationship aspect of communication. In a sense, it involves reading between the lines or going past the surface content of the message to glean nuances of meaning.

Question: Which of the following statements can be identified as a method for clarifying a message?
Choice 1: “I get very upset when you talk to me in that tone.”
Choice 2: “You make me very angry when you drink alcohol.”
Choice 3: “I can make you happy. I know I can.”
Choice 4: “What I want from you is to be left alone!”
Explanation: Use of “I” statements is one technique that can be used for clarifying and qualifying messages.

Question: A nurse and a man are involved in a conversation. When the person folds his arms across his chest, the nurse almost simultaneously folds her arms across her chest. This behavior is recognized as:
Choice 1: empathy.
Choice 2: reciprocity.
Choice 3: flexibility.
Choice 4: spacing.
Explanation: The patterning of similar activities within the same interval by two people can facilitate communication. This patterning is known as reciprocity.

Question: A nurse and her client are engaged in meaningful conversation when suddenly there is silence between the two. To facilitate effective client-centered communication, the nurse should:
Choice 1: ask the person what he is thinking, so they can understand each other.
Choice 2: restate what the person said before silence ensued, to get clarification.
Choice 3: change the subject to one that is more pleasant for the person to discuss.
Choice 4: wait quietly to give the person time to reflect where he wants to lead the conversation.
Explanation: Silence allows the person to reflect on what is being discussed or experienced and lets him or her know that the nurse is willing to wait until he or she is ready to say more.

Question: A person has just been admitted to the hospital. In talking with the person, the nurse is able to elicit from her that the reason for her hospitalization is that her husband beat her up. Which characteristic of the therapeutic relationship is being demonstrated?
Choice 1: Empathy
Choice 2: Trust
Choice 3: Rapport
Choice 4: Purposeful communication
Explanation: The nurse focuses communication for a particular aim: to obtain information to be used in care of the person.

Question: An individual reveals to the nurse that he is having an affair with his wife’s best friend. Which of the following statements will enhance effective therapeutic communication between him and the nurse?
Choice 1: “You know that what you are doing is wrong.”
Choice 2: “Why would you want do something like that?”
Choice 3: “How could you do that to your wife and children?”
Choice 4: “This affair seems to be troubling you.”
Explanation: The nurse is seeking to determine the client’s own feelings about his affair. By seeking feedback, the nurse helps explain the meaning further. The nurse suspends judgment and responds in such a way as to encourage him to keep talking rather than make judgments about his behavior, which would shut down communication.

Question: A nurse is working with a person to increase his daily exercise and activity. Which of the following statements by the nurse best demonstrates the use of reflection?
Choice 1: “I have also struggled with finding time to exercise on a regular basis.”
Choice 2: “Regular exercise plays an important role in preventing many health problems.”
Choice 3: “You said that you have difficulty making time in your day for exercise.”
Choice 4: “It may be helpful if we developed a goal related to daily exercise. “
Explanation: Reflection is the restatement of what the individual has said in the same or different words. This technique can involve paraphrasing or summarizing the person’s main point to indicate interest and to focus the discussion. It is the selective paraphrasing or literal repetition of the person’s words to underscore the importance of what has been said, summarize a main concern or theme, or elicit elaborated information.

Question: A woman tells the nurse that she is very nervous about their meeting today. Which of the following relationship stages are the nurse and woman most likely experiencing?
Choice 1: Orientation phase
Choice 2: Working phase
Choice 3: Therapeutic phase
Choice 4: Termination phase
Explanation: The orientation phase begins when the nurse and individual meet. This meeting typically involves some feeling of anxiety because neither party knows what to expect.

Question: Which of the following is the first step in the valuing process?
Choice 1: Acting out the choice
Choice 2: Selecting from alternatives
Choice 3: Being happy with personal beliefs and actions
Choice 4: Choosing freely
Explanation: The seven-step valuing process involves (1) choosing freely, (2) choosing from alternatives, (3) choosing after careful consideration of potential outcomes of each alternative, (4) cherishing and being happy with personal beliefs and actions, (5) affirming the choice in public, when appropriate, (6) acting out the choice, and (7) repeatedly acting in some type of pattern.

Question: The nurse makes sure that the distance between himself and the client is at least 6 feet before he begins to ask questions related to the client’s health history. Which of the following statements is true?
Choice 1: This is the ideal space for intimate communication.
Choice 2: This distance is too far for the nurse to build a therapeutic relationship while obtaining the information.
Choice 3: This is the recommended distance between client and nurse for effective therapeutic communication.
Choice 4: The nurse should position himself an additional foot away to facilitate the conversation.
Explanation: Personal space of 18 inches to 4 feet is appropriate for close relationships in which touching may be involved and good visualization is desired.

Question: A nurse is working on values clarification with a person who has chosen to smoke during her pregnancy. Which of the following statements would be the most appropriate for the nurse to assist in this process? (select all that apply)
Choice 1: “Why do you smoke cigarettes?
Choice 2: “What do you value most in life?”
Choice 3: “Who has influenced your decision to smoke?”
Choice 4: “Is your decision to smoke consistent with your values?”
Explanation: Techniques to clarify values include assisting the person to identify her own values (“What is important to you?”), identify values conflicts or conflicts between values and actions (“Are your actions consistent with your values?”), and using reflection to restate the value and make it explicit.

Question: A nurse is in the process of establishing a therapeutic relationship with a person. Which of the following techniques should be used by the nurse? (select all that apply)
Choice 1: Learn about the person’s interests.
Choice 2: Sit close to the person.
Choice 3: Show interest in the person’s concerns.
Choice 4: Define the parameters of the relationship with the person.
Explanation: Purposeful communication should be an aim of the therapeutic relationship. Social chitchat, communication without a goal, should not make up the bulk of the therapeutic interaction. The amount of space between communicators varies from culture to culture, so sitting close to the person may not be culturally appropriate. Building rapport by showing the person that his or her concerns interest the nurse is important. Also, trust can be built with the person by clearly defining the relationship parameters and expectations.

Question: Which of the following is an essential question that nurses should encourage individuals to ask at every health visit? (select all that apply)
Choice 1: “What is my main problem?”
Choice 2: “What health information do I not understand?”
Choice 3: “What do I need to do?”
Choice 4: “What is the plan for the next visit?”
Explanation: Health literacy is the capacity to read, comprehend, and follow through on health information; it is a critical component of health promotion. To combat low health literacy, nurses can encourage individuals to ask three essential questions at every health visit: “What is my main problem?” “What do I need to do?” “Why is it important for me to do this?”

Question: Edelman: Health Promotion Throughout the Life Span, 8th Edition1.Which of the following statements is true with regard to health promotion?
Choice 1: Health promotion efforts are not concerned with addressing environmental obstacles to health.
Choice 2: Advocates of health promotion are not involved in political campaigns against harmful products.
Choice 3: The business of eliminating health disparities is a unique function of Healthy People 2010 goals.
Choice 4: Health promotion involves collaboration of many professional groups.
Explanation: Health promotion is not the province of a single discipline but involves individuals, health care providers, and institutions working together to create a positive environment for health and to achieve health goals.

Question: Which of the following types of ethical theories tells us how people act toward each other and their environments and what they believe are good or moral actions?
Choice 1: Descriptive value theories
Choice 2: Normative theories
Choice 3: Consequentialism theory
Choice 4: Duty-based theories
Explanation: Descriptive theories do not tell us what actions we ought to take. They are not directive; they tell us how people act toward each other and their environments and what they seem to believe are good or moral actions.

Question: A nurse includes the statement, “Treat others the way you would like to be treated.” when teaching a group of adolescents about bullying. Which type of ethical theory is being used in this example?
Choice 1: Descriptive value theory
Choice 2: Normative theory
Choice 3: Consequentialism theory
Choice 4: Duty-based theory
Explanation: Normative theories are concerned with ensuring good actions. They are reasoned explanations of the moral purpose of human interactions, or they are divinely “revealed” truths about good action (religious ethics).

Question: A nurse believes that it is his responsibility to ensure the safety of the public by administering flu shots to everyone in the community. Which ethical theory is being used by the nurse?
Choice 1: Descriptive value theory
Choice 2: Normative theory
Choice 3: Consequentialism theory
Choice 4: Duty-based theory
Explanation: Consequentialism theory proposes that actions are good insofar as they are aimed at yielding the greatest amount of happiness or pleasure or cause the least amount of harm or pain to individuals and overall in society. Administration of flu vaccines proposes the best result for individuals and decreased risk for others in the community.

Question: Which of the following statements best describes the application of moral or ethical theory to the practices involved in health promotion?
Choice 1: One can be assured of morally correct action in a given situation if one adheres to a theory of moral principles.
Choice 2: There are no identifiable criteria that can be used effectively to determine correct actions in a given situation.
Choice 3: The good of the larger population always takes precedence over the good of one individual.
Choice 4: Making ethical decisions regarding human health involves the consideration of multiple factors.
Explanation: Making moral or ethical decisions about human health is not an easy task and requires assessing various criteria or theories.

Question: An emergency department provides care for all individuals regardless of circumstances and ability to pay. This is an example of:
Choice 1: ethic of justice.
Choice 2: ethic of care.
Choice 3: applied ethics.
Choice 4: metaethics.
Explanation: The ethic of justice is impartial and nondiscriminatory. An ethic of care, however, requires an understanding of situational particularities, ensuring that we try to understand a given individual’s needs in the context of his or her life.

Question: A nurse uses ethical reasoning to solve an ethical dilemma. Why would the nurse use this process?
Choice 1: Assists in predicting all of the possible consequences of future actions
Choice 2: Facilitates gathering of the most important information to solve the problem
Choice 3: Considers the importance of caring when solving the problem
Choice 4: Highlights salient aspects of future actions
Explanation: The purpose of ethical inquiry is to gain clarity on actual or potential moral issues arising in the context of health-promotion endeavors and to understand what is expected of the health-promotion agent viewed as a moral agent. Ethical reasoning can facilitate appropriate and in-depth data gathering, permit the uncovering of hidden agendas and interests, and focus on the most salient aspects of a particular problem.

Question: A nurse whose religious beliefs prohibit abortion has been asked to participate in a termination of the pregnancy of a 16-year-old victim of date rape. According to the revised American Nurses Association’s (ANA’s) Code of Ethics for Nurses, which of the following actions should the nurse take next?
Choice 1: Suspend her religious beliefs and provide comfort and support for the client.
Choice 2: Quit her job and find another source of employment.
Choice 3: Notify her supervisor about her beliefs and request a change in assignment.
Choice 4: Refuse to participate in the abortion.
Explanation: In the immediacy of the situation, the ANA Code of Ethics provides for the right of nurses to refuse to participate in procedures that violate their own values, but the nurse’s ethical behavior must ensure that arrangements for the care of the client are provided.

Question: A liver for which two people are tissue-typed has become available after the death of a donor in a car accident. Client A is a 45-year-old substance abuser whose liver is damaged as a result of his use of alcohol. Client B is a 16-year-old adolescent in need of a liver transplant because of a birth abnormality. Which of the following would be useful for a nurse in giving input as to which of the two should receive the liver?
Choice 1: Advocate for Client B because he is the younger of the two and will live longer.
Choice 2: Use feminist moral theory to advocate for Client A in spite of his alcohol use.
Choice 3: Use a guided set of moral principles in decision-making before advocating for either.
Choice 4: Advocate for Client A because he has 15 to 20 years of productive life left.
Explanation: Systematically using a set of moral principles in making ethical decisions assists the nurse in resolving ethical dilemmas such as that described.

Question: Which concept is aimed at interrupting potential ethical problems before they develop?
Choice 1: Feminist ethics
Choice 2: Preventive ethics
Choice 3: Metaethics
Choice 4: Normative ethics
Explanation: Preventive ethics is a requirement of health promotion in which practitioners envision potential problems and institute actions that stop their development.

Question: When providing preoperative teaching for a client who will be undergoing total knee arthroplasty, the nurse asks the client questions to assess his understanding of the surgery. Which type of ethics is the nurse implementing?
Choice 1: Duty-based ethics
Choice 2: Normative ethics
Choice 3: Metaethics
Choice 4: Preventive ethics
Explanation: Preventive ethics aims to forestall ethical problems before they develop. Preventive ethics is an important requirement of health-promotion endeavors that includes individual action by the nurse, as well as social and political activism with other nurses or professional nursing organizations. Assessing the client’s understanding of what is going to happen during a surgical procedure before the client signs the consent for the procedure makes sure the client understands the information and should help prevent ethical problems.

Question: A 24-year-old man with severe cognitive impairment, and no relatives participating in his care, needs to make a decision about removal of a brain tumor that will render him totally dependent for completion of all activities of daily living. The nurse participates in ethical decision making on his behalf, knowing that the client is unable to benefit from which of the following ethical concepts?
Choice 1: Autonomy
Choice 2: Justice
Choice 3: Beneficence
Choice 4: Advocacy
Explanation: Because the client is cognitively delayed and is unable to understand explanations of treatment that would be given to him, the client is unable to be autonomous in making a decision regarding neurosurgery.

Question: A client is scheduled to have open-heart surgery. His physical condition is such that he is at high risk to experience complications during the procedure, but he has not been advised of this possibility. Which of the following ethical concepts has been ignored in rendering care for this client?
Choice 1: Beneficence
Choice 2: Autonomy
Choice 3: Justice
Choice 4: Informed consent
Explanation: The client is able to “substantially understand” his care. Ethical care ensures that a person has all of the appropriate information necessary to make an autonomous decision about his or her care. This client has not been informed of his chances of dying during the surgery.

Question: An 18-year-old woman in whom a sexually transmitted disease (STD) was recently diagnosed asks the nurse not to tell her mother that she has an STD. Her mother asks the nurse what is causing her daughter’s vaginal discharge. Which of the following actions should the nurse take?
Choice 1: Follow the principle of veracity and tell the mother the diagnosis.
Choice 2: Respect the principle of confidentiality and support the client’s request not to tell her mother the diagnosis.
Choice 3: Tell the client’s mother that she has a urinary tract infection, to protect the client’s privacy and honor the mother’s request.
Choice 4: Ignore the mother’s request for information.
Explanation: The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) guarantees client confidentiality. The client is the only person who can inform her mother of the diagnosis and the only person who can give the nurse permission to inform her mother of the diagnosis. The nurse could appropriately respond to the mother by saying, “I cannot share that information with you because of client confidentiality legislation. You might ask your daughter to share that information with you.”

Question: A nurse is providing care to a 15-year old female who has recently been diagnosed with a sexually transmitted infection (STI). Which of the following actions should the nurse take next?
Choice 1: Seek advice from an ethics expert.
Choice 2: Facilitate interaction between the adolescent and her parents/guardians.
Choice 3: Report the STI to the appropriate authorities.
Choice 4: Contact the adolescent’s parents/guardians.
Explanation: Federal and state laws generally serve to protect the privacy and autonomy of adolescents. Responsibilities of the nurse include helping an adolescent to grasp his or her authentic options and rights, facilitating interaction between the adolescent and parents or guardians, maintaining trust, and preserving confidentiality.

Question: An elderly client has recently been diagnosed with cancer. The client’s family has asked the nurse to withhold this information from the client because they feel that this information would cause the client to give up on life and become very depressed. The nurse believes the client should be told this information. Which ethical principle is being upheld by the nurse?
Choice 1: Justice
Choice 2: Beneficence
Choice 3: Veracity
Choice 4: Nonmaleficence
Explanation: Veracity is also known as devotion to the truth. Veracity in giving people information about their health care needs facilitates autonomous choice and enhances personal decision-making. Withholding information, or providing information that is misleading or incomprehensible, in an attempt to influence someone to agree to a treatment or intervention, conflicts with veracity.

Question: Which of the following concepts of ethics is described as the “duty to maximize the benefits of actions while minimizing harm”?
Choice 1: Advocacy
Choice 2: Justice
Choice 3: Beneficence
Choice 4: Autonomy
Explanation: Beneficence governs actions taken to further the overall health or well-being of an individual or society. “Beneficence” means doing good.

Question: A nurse reflects on previous experiences with minority populations and considers how these interactions have influenced her present care to these populations. Which part of values clarification and reflection has the nurse used?
Choice 1: Formulate a possible course of action.
Choice 2: Examine the influence of beliefs.
Choice 3: Reflect on practice.
Choice 4: Determine the prevalent values.
Explanation: It is important for the nurse to think about the influence that beliefs and values have on his or her practice. An understanding of how personal beliefs and values are either congruent, or are liable to interfere, with the task at hand is crucial to ethical problem solving.

Question: A nurse is working with a community to increase its awareness about the dangers of lead poisoning. Which of the following provides the best explanation as to why the nurse is performing this action? (select all that apply)
Choice 1: It is the right thing to do.
Choice 2: It is a moral responsibility.
Choice 3: It is an ethical responsibility.
Choice 4: It is the role of the nurse.
Explanation: When nurses provide service to society through health promotion interventions, their care for clients can be seen as a moral endeavor. Moral issues are confronted in the process of attempting to enhance the well-being of a society overall, as well as promoting and protecting health for individual members of a society. The ANA Code of Ethics for Nurses Interpretive Statements promises that “nursing encompasses the prevention of illness, the alleviation of suffering, and the protection, promotion, and restoration of health in the care of individuals, families, groups and communities.” The terms ethical and moral are used interchangeably throughout the chapter.

Question: A nurse is using feminist ethics when planning a program for women to promote screening and early detection of breast cancer. Which of the following considerations would be made by the nurse? (select all that apply)
Choice 1: Importance of relationships
Choice 2: Understanding of the oppression of women
Choice 3: Importance of responsibility when caring for others
Choice 4: Understanding of the imbalance of power
Explanation: Characteristics of feminist ethics include: understanding that human beings are inseparable from their relationships with others; a focus on care and responsibility aspects of relationships, rather than application of abstract principles; a concern with the development of character and attitudes that result in caring actions reflective of a person who is related to rather than detached from context; and a concern for the rights and equality of all individuals that is not limited to the oppression of women.

Question: Edelman: Health Promotion Throughout the Life Span, 8th Edition1.Healthy People 2020 objectives provide a framework for:
Choice 1: assessment.
Choice 2: diagnosis.
Choice 3: prevention.
Choice 4: treatment.
Explanation: The health promotion initiative named Healthy People 2010 provides a framework for prevention.

Question: Which of the following best describes a primary prevention method for colon cancer?
Choice 1: Hemoccult testing
Choice 2: High fiber diet
Choice 3: Colonoscopy
Choice 4: Laparoscopy
Explanation: Primary prevention includes generalized health promotion and specific protection from disease. Hemoccult and colonoscopy are forms of screening, not prevention. Eating a healthy diet high in fiber is a preventive measure.

Question: Who authored the framework which provides the foundation for nursing assessment and diagnosis using the functional health patterns?
Choice 1: Erikson
Choice 2: Gordon
Choice 3: Newman
Choice 4: Nightingale
Explanation: Gordon’s framework provides the foundation for most NANDA nursing diagnoses using the functional health pattern. Nurses use the framework to combine assessment skills with subjective and objective data to construct patterns.

Question: Over the last week, a person has had finger stick glucose levels of 127, 132, 140, 138, 143, 145, and 140. This information allows the nurse to characterize the person’s function pattern by utilizing which area of focus?
Choice 1: Age-developmental
Choice 2: Functional
Choice 3: Individual-environmental
Choice 4: Pattern
Explanation: Pattern focus implies that the nurse explores patterns or sequences of behavior over time. Pattern recognition occurs during information collection. Functional health patterns then provide structure to analyze factors.

Question: A nurse is using a functional focus to assess a person. Which of the following the nurse be evaluating?
Choice 1: Visual acuity
Choice 2: Pupil reactivity
Choice 3: Ability to drive
Choice 4: The red reflex
Explanation: Functional focus refers to the individual’s performance level. Nurses assess how particular visual patterns affect lifestyle. The ability to drive would affect a person’s lifestyle and might require a change in how the person functions.

Question: A nurse working with a Hispanic family is explaining the plan for managing a child’s asthma to the child’s mother, father, and grandmother. To whom should the nurse direct the education?
Choice 1: Mother
Choice 2: Father
Choice 3: Grandmother
Choice 4: Parents and grandmother
Explanation: Culturally competent care is delivered with understanding of and sensitivity to cultural factors influencing health behaviors. Nurses provide culturally competent care when they identify and use cultural norms and values. In the Hispanic population, the male figure is usually the decision maker, and the family elders are highly respected. However, assumptions about cultural norms should not be made. As a result, the nurse should direct education to all three adults because they may all have an impact on the child’s health care needs.

Question: A 27-year-old woman has not received a Pap test in [PIC_20170114132026_0015.jpg] years. This assessment finding identifies an alteration in which functional pattern?
Choice 1: Health-perception–health-management pattern
Choice 2: Elimination pattern
Choice 3: Activity-rest pattern
Choice 4: Self-perception–self-concept pattern
Explanation: Assessment objectives for the health-perception–health-management pattern consist of obtaining data about perceptions, management, and preventive health practices. Exploring these values identifies potential health hazards. A 27-year-old woman should receive a Pap test every 2 years. Failing to do so could place her at risk for health problems; thus, this finding identifies an alteration in the health-perception–health-management pattern.

Question: A client is experiencing an alteration in the health-perception–health-management pattern and an alteration in the values-beliefs pattern. Which of the following best describes the behavior of this person?
Choice 1: Never sees a physician
Choice 2: Only sees a physician if not feeling well
Choice 3: Sees a physician for screenings only
Choice 4: Sees a physician for follow-up care of a chronic disease
Explanation: Health beliefs and perceptions directly affect participation in care. Dimensions of assessment in the values-beliefs pattern include the individual’s values, beliefs, or goals that guide choices or decisions that are related to health. People who do not believe in health promotion activities will likely see a physician only when sick. Thus, someone with an alteration in the health-perception–health-management and values-beliefs patterns will likely only see a physician if not feeling well.
