Although publicity is often very helpful, photographs should not be a primary consideration. Moreover, although the needs of community agencies may be a consideration, it is not of primary concern in the planning of a health fair.

Question: What variables are considered in the decision as to which screening tests are to be performed at a health fair? (Select all that apply.)
Choice 1: A national day dedicated to a specific screening
Choice 2: Preferences of the local politicians who support such events
Choice 3: Preferences of the local church, which donated space to be used for the event
Choice 4: The learning needs of the senior nursing students who are going to be helping
Choice 5: The sociodemographics of the population that will probably attend
Choice 6: What donations the nurse or the clinic has received
Explanation: On a population level, choice of screening test is based on general sociodemographic factors rather than individual risk factors. Age, gender, and ethnicity factors affect the risk status of a population. Hence, population data are an important consideration in the planning of a health fair. The other population-based screenings can be offered in conjunction with national screening days.

Question: Nursing students were setting up a meeting to finalize plans for a health fair. Of the following people, who must be included? (Select all that apply.)
Choice 1: All the health care personnel who will be doing the screenings
Choice 2: Community leaders who are actively involved in neighborhood activities
Choice 3: Local politicians who will enjoy having their pictures in the media
Choice 4: Philanthropists who might contribute funds for additional screening tests if their names are publicized
Choice 5: Staff from the health department that is sponsoring the fair
Choice 6: Volunteers who will help collect the consent forms and other tasks
Explanation: Although the students might invite anyone, the persons who are most important are those who may help secure needed resources or who will help implement the program. These include health care personnel, volunteers, and community leaders.

Question: Which screening tests would be most useful at a health fair at a local YMCA that serves young adults? (Select all that apply.)
Choice 1: Measurements of blood pressure, blood glucose level, and cholesterol level
Choice 2: Measurements of height and weight
Choice 3: Mammography and prostate examination
Choice 4: Purified protein-derivative skin test (PPD) and review of immunizations
Choice 5: Stool for occult blood and sigmoidoscopy
Choice 6: Vision and hearing
Explanation: On the basis of the age group that would be screened, the blood pressure, cholesterol, and diabetes screening would be most useful. Height and weight measurements are useful for assessing obesity, which is a risk factor for heart disease and stroke, two of the three leading causes of death in Americans. Tests such as mammography, prostate examinations, and stool for occult blood and sigmoidoscopy are more typically used in older populations. PPD, review of immunizations, and vision and hearing screenings are not necessary for a population of young adults.

Question: A nurse was trying to determine what resources might be available to support a screening program for middle-aged adults in the local community. The nurse should be sure to assess which variables? (Select all that apply.)
Choice 1: Cost and funding sources
Choice 2: Equipment and personnel to run the screening tests
Choice 3: Free newspaper publicity
Choice 4: Local diagnostic and treatment resources
Choice 5: Temporary personnel who could be hired to assist
Choice 6: Volunteers to help with the screening
Explanation: Practical resources needed to support screening programs include funding, personnel, equipment, volunteers, follow-up diagnostic and treatment services, and support by key community leaders. Temporary employees would not typically be hired. With the low literacy rates, newspapers should not be the only public notification used. Rather, media should include flyers, mass mailings, and notices on community websites and local advertisements on radio and television, as well as in newspapers.

Question: A volunteer explained to a nurse that a certain client did not wish to fill out the information/consent form. What should the nurse explain to the client as to why the form was required? (Select all that apply.)
Choice 1: “The agency requires such forms to document personnel time.”
Choice 2: “The information serves as data for duplicating the screening in the future.”
Choice 3: “You may wish to keep these data so that they are available for needed follow-up.”
Choice 4: “The form is needed for student education; the data are collated to determine community-wide needs.”
Choice 5: “Consent is needed before any tests, particularly invasive ones, are administered.”
Choice 6: “The data are used for program evaluation so that more such screenings may be available.”
Explanation: Easy-to-use forms are typically used to document the data for counseling, instruction, and referral information. They provide test results for the participant and future providers, as well as for program evaluation. Consent is legally required before invasive screening measures such as blood measurements. It is hoped that students will use general sociodemographic variables such as age, gender, and ethnicity rather than a biased sample from one screening for determining community-wide needs. Agencies would assign personnel, so they would not need patients to fill out forms to confirm personnel activity.

Question: The nursing students created a media spot to publicize a free screening for undergraduates to be held at the college. What must the students remember to do? (Select all that apply.)
Choice 1: Discuss how listeners would benefit by attending.
Choice 2: Emphasize the program is being given for everyone’s benefit.
Choice 3: Keep the message short, at about 30 seconds or 75 words.
Choice 4: Require that the ads run late in the evening when most students listen to the radio and watch television.
Choice 5: Stress the health risks that students face that may be diagnosed at this screening.
Choice 6: Use lots of visual aids to help listeners visualize the experience.
Explanation: Such media spots must be short (30 seconds or 75 words) and clarify how listeners will benefit. Fear (stressing the health risks) is not an effective long-term strategy. Visual aids would not be very effective with radio, which is an auditory medium. The screening is not for everyone, but for the college students (not staff or faculty). Although the students can request a late evening advertisement, the channels air public service announcements at whatever time they choose.

Question: A nurse is referring a client who needs follow-up care. Which of the following actions should the nurse take? (Select all that apply.)
Choice 1: Asking whether the client prefers to have the nurse make all the arrangements
Choice 2: Assessing whether the client meets the eligibility requirements for the receiving agency
Choice 3: Discussing with the client the payment mechanism for follow-up care
Choice 4: Determining whether the client is interested in following up at that particular agency
Choice 5: Arranging for the client to have transportation and child care available
Choice 6: Contacting several agencies in the area to see whether they are willing to accept a referral
Explanation: The nurse must be sure the client meets eligibility requirements and is interested in the referral. The nurse must be aware of the payment mechanism that will be used for follow-up care so the client can be given names of community resources that are able to provide care on the basis of the source of payment. Contacting agencies about follow-up before the other actions with a client referral are completed is premature. Most agencies cannot provide free transportation and child care for clients to attend a different agency. It would encourage dependency for the nurse to make all the arrangements and then announce to clients what they should do. The client must be actively involved in follow-up care.

Question: With what aspect of the population being served have both nursing and public health always been most concerned?
Choice 1: Financial resources
Choice 2: Political beliefs
Choice 3: Religious faith
Choice 4: Social and physical environments
Explanation: Community/public health nursing has always been most concerned with the interrelationship among people and their physical and social environments.

Question: A community/public health nurse is working for a local health department. Which of the following would be an appropriate goal for the nurse?
Choice 1: Assessing clients in their own home environment
Choice 2: Caring for whole families, not just individuals
Choice 3: Improving health over the long term for families
Choice 4: Striving for social betterment
Explanation: The text stresses that community/public health nursing attempts to meet not only educational and other nursing needs but also social betterment, which includes social and political activism. Although all the other answers might seem appropriate, many community/public health nurses do not provide direct care.

Question: What occurred as a result of industrialization?
Choice 1: People from lower socioeconomic classes were able improve their socioeconomic positions.
Choice 2: Problems such as overcrowding and disease developed.
Choice 3: Products were individualized to meet customers’ unique needs.
Choice 4: Taxes for roads and other community services increased.
Explanation: Because workers flocked to cities for employment, overcrowding resulted, which enabled disease to spread rapidly.

Question: A district nurse in England during the 1860s was providing care for the community. With which of the following groups would the nurse most likely have interacted?
Choice 1: Church clergy
Choice 2: Business owners
Choice 3: Lobbyists
Choice 4: Government officials
Explanation: In England, nurses were assigned a district associated with a church parish, whereas in the United States, district nurses often worked in conjunction with physicians who were employed in the local dispensary.

Question: A nurse was working with William Rathbone and other social reformers to improve care in the homes of poor residents. What barrier was this nurse likely to have encountered?
Choice 1: Poor persons did not want nurses to enter their homes.
Choice 2: Providing home care to the poor was not accepted by the community.
Choice 3: Wealthy community members were reluctant to donate money for these services.
Choice 4: There were not enough nurses to provide adequate services.
Explanation: Society has long accepted that some part of the population is always poor. Furthermore, nursing was a new profession with inadequate numbers. Consequently, Rathbone had to work to have more nurses trained.

Question: A district nurse working with William Rathbone was visiting homes of persons suffering from contagious disease. Which of the following nursing interventions probably would have been implemented?
Choice 1: Providing information to family members without providing direct care
Choice 2: Assessing the client who was suffering from the disease
Choice 3: Donating money, food, bedding, and supplies to the families of the ill person
Choice 4: Referring the client and family to community resources
Explanation: To avoid transmission from one household to another, nurses did not provide care directly but taught family members how to do so. Thus, it was unlikely that the client would be assessed by the nurse. It was not the responsibility of the nurse to donate supplies to the family, and during this period, available community resources to which a client and family could be referred were limited.

Question: A public health nurse is addressing problems in the community. What would be the nurse’s primary concern?
Choice 1: Collecting and analyzing data
Choice 2: Assuring sufficient standard of living for clients
Choice 3: Providing direct care to clients living in the community
Choice 4: Assisting clients and families in adapting to their circumstances
Explanation: Public health is committed to social betterment and recognizes the influence of poverty or socioeconomic class on health.

Question: Who emphasized that public health must be concerned with the standard of living of citizens?
Choice 1: C. E. A. Winslow
Choice 2: Lemuel Shattuck
Choice 3: Florence Nightingale
Choice 4: John Snow
Explanation: C. E. A. Winslow, the leading theoretician of the American public health movement, stated a standard of living adequate for the maintenance of health must be assured.

Question: Who was the first person to recognize the importance of the environment by noting that cholera rates were much higher among persons who drank water from a particular well?
Choice 1: C. E. A. Winslow
Choice 2: Edwin Chadwick
Choice 3: Lemuel Shattuck
Choice 4: John Snow
Explanation: John Snow demonstrated that the cases of cholera in an 1854 outbreak were linked to water from a specific well.

Question: Which person established population-based objectives and used statistics to show that specific interventions dramatically decreased the death rate by 51%?
Choice 1: C. E. A. Winslow
Choice 2: Lemuel Shattuck
Choice 3: Florence Nightingale
Choice 4: John Snow
Explanation: Florence Nightingale used biostatistics to demonstrate the decline in annual death rates from 70 per 1000 to 19 per 1000 after her reforms.

Question: How did Nightingale demonstrate the effectiveness of providing nursing care to soldiers?
Choice 1: Persuading military officers that clean air was necessary for the ill soldiers
Choice 2: Using biostatistics to demonstrate decline in death rates
Choice 3: Improving the living quarters for the injured soldiers
Choice 4: Bringing ranked officers of the military to see the improvements
Explanation: The science of biostatistics was used to demonstrate the decline in death rates as a result of nursing reforms.

Question: For what is Clara Barton primarily known?
Choice 1: Helping found the American branch of the Red Cross
Choice 2: Exemplifying excellent military strategy skills
Choice 3: Working at the U.S. Patent Office
Choice 4: Facilitating reforms in prisons and mental institutions
Explanation: Clara Barton, although employed at the U.S. Patent Office, was instrumental in creating the American branch of the Red Cross.

Question: Why would a nurse who was practicing in the 1900s have been considered to be part of the “golden age” of public health?
Choice 1: Antibiotics were discovered to fight infections.
Choice 2: Federal, state, and local funding to public health departments increased.
Choice 3: Pasteurization of milk and public water and sewage systems began.
Choice 4: Major plagues with high death rates had been stopped.
Explanation: General sanitary reforms that occurred between 1880 and 1910 helped prevent communicable diseases.

Question: A nurse has recently been hired by a school to fulfill the role of the school nurse. What was the reason for the initial development of this specialty nursing practice?
Choice 1: In-school treatment reduced absenteeism.
Choice 2: Nurses were cheaper to employ than additional teachers.
Choice 3: In-school treatment was cost effective.
Choice 4: Nurses knew when to send young children home.
Explanation: Daily treatment of illnesses such as ringworm and impetigo by the school nurses reduced illnesses and also dramatically reduced absenteeism.

Question: A public health nurse newly employed by a local health department learns that the focus of her practice will be to prevent illness in the community. Why does the focus of practice not include the treatment and care of ill patients?
Choice 1: Ill people prefer to get care from physicians or in hospitals.
Choice 2: People do not trust public health department personnel.
Choice 3: Physicians have voiced opposition for fear of loss of income.
Choice 4: Visiting nurses associations are becoming part of health departments.
Explanation: Physicians and nongovernmental visiting nurses associations feared loss of income if health departments treated patients, and so health officers limited nurses to preventing disease.

Question: A nurse working in 1965 wondered how passage of the Medicare and Medicaid legislation would change health care in the United States. Which of the following accurately describes an outcome of this legislation?
Choice 1: It decreased the separation between government funding and private physicians.
Choice 2: It provided federal intervention for previous state responsibilities.
Choice 3: It helped the public realize that some persons had not been getting care.
Choice 4: It allowed the federal government to finance health care services.
Explanation: The private sector had focused on diagnosis and treatment of the ill, whereas the state and local health departments had focused on health promotion and disease prevention. Under Medicare and Medicaid, government funds paid for the health care of ill elderly and poor persons.

Question: A nurse works in an outpatient clinic. The care that the nurse provides is considered to be community-based because this term
Choice 1: Emphasizes the environment of care.
Choice 2: Describes care provided by nongovernmental employees.
Choice 3: Implies care that is provided to the very poor.
Choice 4: Is used by physicians and other health care professionals.
Explanation: Although community health nursing is a synonym for public health nursing, public health nursing had become linked with nurses employed by governments. The term community health nursing emerged to include nursing sponsored by both private nonprofit organizations and governmental agencies.

Question: A nurse supports Nursing’s Agenda for Health Care Reform. For which of the following actions would the nurse advocate?
Choice 1: Availability of third-party reimbursement to advanced-practice nurses under Medicare and Medicaid
Choice 2: Employment by local health departments of nurses to teach aggregates at high risk how to avoid health problems
Choice 3: Physicians’s ability to employ additional nurses in their practice to improve patients’ compliance with medical regimens
Choice 4: Permission to state governments to pay public health nurses to develop health promotion projects for communities
Explanation: Medicare and Medicaid reimbursement was expanded to all nurse practitioners and clinical nurse specialists.

Question: A public health nurse is discussing disaster planning in relation to bioterrorism preparedness with members of the county board of health. Which of the following topics is likely to be addressed?
Choice 1: Selection of drugs that should be stockpiled for future use
Choice 2: Limited resources for managing bioterrorism and day-to-day expenses
Choice 3: Inconsistencies in systems for distributing supplies to areas of need
Choice 4: Need for ongoing education for public health professionals
Explanation: Because of the limited supply of personnel and funding, a tension exists between the use of resources for bioterrorism preparedness and their use for other public health issues. Selection of drugs that should be stockpiled and inconsistencies related to distribution of supplies would not occur at the county level. The need for ongoing education does not relate to the discussion of disaster planning.

Question: During World War I, three acute care (hospital-based) nurses were hired to work in an industrial setting. What would have been a reason for their change of practice? (Select all that apply.)
Choice 1: Philanthropy from industrial business owners was encouraged.
Choice 2: Collective bargaining contracts required a nurse to be on site.
Choice 3: Efficiency and productivity improved if workers were at the workplace.
Choice 4: Employers feared the movement toward collective bargaining.
Choice 5: Legislation requiring employers to have first aid services was passed.
Choice 6: The National Safety Council required that a nurse teach first aid to staff.
Explanation: Industrial nursing spread because factory efficiency was improved if workers were at the workplace and healthy, which was particularly important during World War I. Philanthropy, industrial justice, and fear of union movements were other motives for creating industrial nursing positions.

Question: A nurse in the early twentieth century visited the homes of mothers with newborns. Which of the following would have been appropriate nursing interventions? (Select all that apply.)
Choice 1: Ensuring that the mothers complied with physician prescriptions
Choice 2: Referring the families to the Women, Infants, and Children program (WIC)
Choice 3: Administering the immunizations required by state law
Choice 4: Promoting breast-feeding
Choice 5: Supervising formula preparation and feeding
Choice 6: Teaching mothers how to care for and feed their infants
Explanation: The nurses provided home visits to promote breast-feeding, to supervise formula preparation and feeding if necessary, to support mothers in following medical advice, and to teach mothers how to properly care for their infants. Mothers were encouraged to follow medical advice, but nurses could not ensure compliance. There were no state laws requiring immunizations, and the WIC program did not exist at that time.

Question: A community/public health nurse refers to Healthy People 2020 when providing community-based education. What is the significance of this document? (Select all that apply.)
Choice 1: It clarifies the importance of hospitals in community-based care.
Choice 2: It expands on what kinds of care the federal government is willing to fund.
Choice 3: It explains the federal goals for improved health of the nation.
Choice 4: It provides a guide for nurses when they speak with the public.
Choice 5: It specifies how federal health care funds will be spent.
Choice 6: It emphasizes appropriate nursing interventions when direct client care is provided.
Explanation: Healthy People 2020 is a clear statement of national health goals and objectives and provides a guide for community/public health nurses speaking with people about healthy communities.

Question: What are the basic goals of Healthy People 2020? (Select all that apply.)
Choice 1: Recognizing health disparities among all populations
Choice 2: Promoting healthy behaviors among all persons
Choice 3: Attaining high-quality, longer lives for all persons
Choice 4: Developing a plan for quality care for all clients
Choice 5: Achieving health equity for all groups
Choice 6: Creating environments that promote good health for all persons
Explanation: The goals of Healthy People 2020 are to attain high-quality, longer lives free of preventable disease, disability, injury, and premature death; to achieve health equity, eliminate health disparities and improve health for all groups; to promote quality of life, healthy development, and healthy behaviors across all life stages; and to create social and physical environments that promote good health for all. Healthy People 2020 not only recognizes health disparities but also recommends ways to address them. It does not help with developing a plan for quality care.

Question: A nurse was employed by the Frontier Nursing Service in the 1940s. What is significant about this agency? (Select all that apply.)
Choice 1: It paid nurses considerably more than persons in urban staff positions.
Choice 2: It had the first nurse–midwives and taught midwifery to others.
Choice 3: Its nurses improved sanitation efforts in rural communities.
Choice 4: Its nurses collected data to demonstrate nursing effectiveness.
Choice 5: It employed nurses who traveled by horseback through the mountains.
Choice 6: Its nurses continue to provide care even today.
Explanation: Mary Breckinridge was a pioneer in community assessment, population-based planning, and partnership building. She created a system for rural nursing in which nurses on horseback were employed; furthermore, she used research to demonstrate effectiveness. Her vision of the Frontier Nursing Service continues today.

Question: For whom are patient education programs very helpful?
Choice 1: Adults and families who can learn to avoid health problems
Choice 2: Adults and families, who will all be clients in the future
Choice 3: People who wish to learn how best to use the health care system
Choice 4: People with an identified health problem
Explanation: Patient education describes teaching-learning activities for people with an identified alteration in health. Health education focuses on helping healthy groups maintain or improve their health.

Question: Toward which individuals and their families are health education programs primarily aimed?
Choice 1: Those who are acutely ill and need information to help them recover and avoid further problems
Choice 2: Those who are healthy and can support each other in maintaining healthy lifestyles
Choice 3: Those who must cope with an ongoing chronic disease
Choice 4: Those who have defined health problems and who can support each other in maintaining healthy lifestyles
Explanation: Health education focuses on helping healthy groups maintain or improve their health. Patient education describes teaching-learning activities for people with an identified alteration in health.

Question: Which of the following criteria must be met in order for an educational program to receive third-party reimbursement?
Choice 1: It must be provided to a geriatric population.
Choice 2: It must be given by an advanced nurse practitioner.
Choice 3: It must occur in a rural, underserved area.
Choice 4: It must be prescribed by a physician for an ill client.
Explanation: Insurance companies pay for illness, not wellness, and so they will pay for patient teaching regarding an existing illness only when it is prescribed by a physician.

Question: How can nurses best help expand availability of health education programs?
Choice 1: Being entrepreneurs and asking patients to pay what they think the educational program was worth
Choice 2: Suggesting to their friends and neighbors that they lobby local health organizations to provide such health education programs
Choice 3: Teaching health education programs as unpaid volunteers in the community
Choice 4: Working politically to influence public policy regarding funding health education programs
Explanation: Although nurses can volunteer, join other people in requesting health education programs, or teach such programs as nurse entrepreneurs, the best way to expand the availability of such programs is to influence public policy regarding development and funding of health education programs. Although it is not clearly stated in Chapter 20 (all the answers are recommended in the text), the book as a whole emphasizes the importance of political action for more extensive influence.

Question: What strategies will a nurse include when planning an educational program for adults that ensures student learning?
Choice 1: Individual one-on-one tutorials to ensure maximum understanding
Choice 2: Large group lectures with handouts of main points along with culturally appropriate pictures
Choice 3: Small peer group discussions on how to apply the new knowledge with prompt feedback
Choice 4: Use of multimedia technologies such as videotapes and PowerPoint presentations
Explanation: Small group discussions help adults become actively involved, often with repetition of the information as they discuss how to apply the knowledge. Individual one-on-one tutorials are extremely expensive. Large group lectures, even with handouts and pictures, still are only effective for low-level cognitive learning, not application. Table 20-1 emphasizes that adults want application of the facts and real-life context.

Question: In what way is the Predisposing, Reinforcing, Enabling, Causes in Educational Diagnosis, and Evaluation (PRECEDE) model helpful when health education programs are implemented?
Choice 1: It addresses the learning needs of ill individuals.
Choice 2: It begins with examining an aggregate’s general concerns and quality of life.
Choice 3: It emphasizes the learning needs of families who have an ill member.
Choice 4: It focuses primarily on environmental resources.
Explanation: The PRECEDE model begins with the presence or absence of health problems that are linked to quality-of-life issues, with the question “What are the general concerns of the population?” Such assessment helps ensure that the intervention is based on diagnosis of the community’s need.

Question: Which of the following factors most influences a client’s ability to learn from a health education program?
Choice 1: Client’s belief that the information will be useful or enjoyable
Choice 2: Handouts given to the client
Choice 3: Nurse’s ability to teach
Choice 4: Setting in which the educational program is given
Explanation: Learning depends primarily on emotional readiness, which is reinforced primarily by internal motivation. The learner must be willing to put forth the effort needed to learn. Internal motivation is self-directive and long lasting and is based on the belief that the client’s action will be useful or enjoyable.

Question: A nurse is teaching a client how to perform her own insulin injections. Which of the following should the nurse assess first to determine the client’s experiential readiness to learn?
Choice 1: Culture and ethnic background
Choice 2: Educational ability
Choice 3: Family structure
Choice 4: Home environment
Explanation: The client’s ability to learn can most easily be assessed by determining the client’s educational level. Direct questioning related to years of formal education is useful but does not always provide complete and accurate information. Reading ability and learning disabilities should also be considered.

Question: Behavioral objectives should be
Choice 1: Comprehensive and complete.
Choice 2: Observable, measurable, and clearly communicated.
Choice 3: Specific and detailed.
Choice 4: Written on the teaching plan.
Explanation: Although all of the responses are consistent with careful planning, the plan will not be workable unless the objectives are measurable and the nurse is able to observe changes in learning, attitudes, or behavior. Because the objectives convey intent to other people, such as external evaluators, they must also be communicable. If clearly stated, the objectives can also be used for evaluation purposes.

Question: The nurse distributed written materials with culturally appropriate pictures to the small groups in the audience and began to lecture on the important content before the planned discussion period. However, no one was listening. What should the nurse have done differently?
Choice 1: Created a more interesting and entertaining lecture
Choice 2: Withheld the written materials until after the lecture
Choice 3: Let the audience discuss the material as a whole, not in small groups
Choice 4: Skipped the lecture and went directly to the discussion period
Explanation: Wait to make group assignments and to give handouts for group activity until after you have given the final instructions; otherwise, people will be reading instead of listening to you.

Question: Which of the following statements best demonstrates an appropriately written behavioral objective?
Choice 1: “The learner will be able to verbally explain the need for political action.”
Choice 2: “The panel of experts will have discussed knowledge, assumptions, and cultural values.”
Choice 3: “The participant will understand the material presented.”
Choice 4: “The teacher will distribute and collect evaluation forms.”
Explanation: Behavioral objectives focus on the learner and what the learner demonstrates in terms of knowledge, attitudes, or beliefs. Understanding is not observable, whereas an accurate verbal explanation is observable.

Question: A community/public health nurse is planning an educational program about healthy choices to prevent heart disease. Which of the following variables will be the primary influence as the nurse selects content for the program?
Choice 1: Employing agency’s preferences
Choice 2: Needs of the high-risk target group
Choice 3: Third-party payers’ probable coverage of the educational program
Choice 4: What the nurse feels most comfortable and skilled in teaching
Explanation: The nurse certainly must function within the constraints of the health care system, including policies of the employing agency and third-party payers; in a specific planned program, however, the actual content depends on the learning needs of the target group, as determined by a needs assessment.

Question: A nurse began by asking the audience, “What do you want me to discuss?” All responses were written on the chalkboard and then, as specific points were discussed, the nurse erased the item. However, the nurse often added material that was not requested. Why would the nurse add more content?
Choice 1: Because the nurse believed the additional information was entertaining and lightened the mood
Choice 2: Because the nurse knew, on the basis of personal experience, other relevant information that the audience needed
Choice 3: Because the nurse knew so much about the subject and wanted to give all the details.
Choice 4: Because the nurse was sure that the audience meant to ask about it
Explanation: The presentation should include not only what the audience wants to learn but also what the nurse, on the basis of previous experience, knows would be useful to them.

Question: When teaching an educational program to an adult audience, which of the following actions should a nurse take to best meet their educational needs?
Choice 1: Providing a specific, detailed explanation of each component of the program
Choice 2: Using various methods of instruction, including lecture, discussion, and visual aids
Choice 3: Providing an opportunity for participants to express their feelings about the program
Choice 4: Using a PowerPoint presentation so that the audience can visualize the material
Explanation: To best meet the needs of the audience, it is important to use different teaching methods so that each member of the audience can learn by his or her preferred method, whether that is hearing, reading, discussing, or another activity. Thus, the use of only a PowerPoint presentation may not meet the needs of all the members of the audience. In addition, it is helpful to include all three domains of learning, which is usually necessary to incorporate a new health behavior into the learner’s life. The best choices include opportunities for learning the material by preferred learning style, expressing feelings, and applying material, which represent the cognitive, affective, and psychomotor aspects.

Question: A nurse educator wanted to be certain that the program participants not only learned the content but also had time to practice these new behaviors. Which of the following must the nurse be sure to include in the program?
Choice 1: Providing positive praise for participation
Choice 2: Allowing time for role-playing
Choice 3: Engaging the audience in stress-reduction exercises
Choice 4: Modeling the appropriate behaviors
Explanation: All of the answers are positive teaching behaviors, but to most effectively help the participants change both their attitudes and their behaviors, role-playing provides exploration of attitudes and use of problem-solving skills.

Question: Which comment to the nurse best demonstrates a successful health education program?
Choice 1: “I’m going to take a 30-minute walk each day.”
Choice 2: “I certainly enjoyed the program, and thank you for the freebies.”
Choice 3: “You gave me so much new information; thank you so much.”
Choice 4: “Wow! I learned many things that I can use in my daily activities.”
Explanation: The overall goal is to teach a health-promoting activity that can be incorporated into the learner’s lifestyle. Assessment of learner outcomes has traditionally been based on achievement of the behavioral objectives. If the objectives are properly written, each objective is measurable. Planning to take a daily walk demonstrates intention to incorporate the program content into personal lifestyle.

Question: Which of the following would be the best question for a nurse to ask to determine whether an educational intervention had any effect?
Choice 1: “Are you interested in any other topics for me to teach?”
Choice 2: “Did you find this program useful to you?”
Choice 3: “Do you understand the material I presented?”
Choice 4: “How are you going to apply these ideas at home?”
Explanation: Only “How are you going to apply these ideas at home?” will elicit responses that demonstrate whether the learner understood what was said and is willing to use the information in his or her life. It is also an excellent discussion question. Assessment of learner outcomes has traditionally been based on achievement of the behavioral objectives.

Question: Which audience comment best demonstrates self-efficacy?
Choice 1: “I believe I can learn to do this.”
Choice 2: “I think the nurse is a real expert in this stuff.”
Choice 3: “Those computer graphics really make it clear how people can do this.”
Choice 4: “Wow. The nurse really expects us to do this.”
Explanation: Self-efficacy is the belief that the learner is capable of engaging in the desired action. Stating “I believe I can learn to do this” demonstrates the belief by the learner that implementation is possible.

Question: The nurse had a peer evaluation completed in order to improve her teaching expertise. Which of the following best describes this evaluation?
Choice 1: A summary of the evaluation that the audience completed at the end of the program
Choice 2: Another nurse observing and providing feedback on the presentation
Choice 3: Completion of an evaluation of their learning and satisfaction by participants
Choice 4: Videotaping of the presentation for further review by the nurse and others
Explanation: All of the options are possible evaluation mechanisms, but peer evaluation is having a peer—in this case, another professional nurse—observe and give feedback.

Question: In preparing to give a presentation on breast self-examination, a nurse went to the American Cancer Society and obtained a variety of handouts to use during the presentation. Which possibly erroneous assumption is the nurse making?
Choice 1: Handouts are the best technique for emphasizing important points.
Choice 2: Handouts will be easily read by people in the audience.
Choice 3: People will appreciate the brochures and freebies such as shower hook reminders.
Choice 4: People will use the reminders and put them in their bathrooms.
Explanation: The use of handouts and other written materials is based on the assumption that the audience can read, but research has shown that approximately 50% of Americans lack basic literacy and math skills.

Question: One of the adults at a health education program introduced a rather unorthodox suggestion, claiming, “I saw it on the Internet.” Which of the following criteria is most important for laypeople to use in deciding whether to accept information on the Internet?
Choice 1: The author of the information has written several books on the topic, all of which are for sale.
Choice 2: The content of the site is supported by an international pharmaceutical company.
Choice 3: The site is frequently referred to in magazine and TV advertisements.
Choice 4: The site is maintained and frequently updated by a federal health agency.
Explanation: In an Internet site, the authorship should be based on credentials and clinical reputation, preferably peer reviewed. The information should be written by staff at a reputable organization, preferably based on research, frequently updated, and not biased by being financially supported by companies or people attempting to sell products.

Question: Which of the following activities would be important for the nurse to complete when planning an educational program?
Choice 1: Avoid rehearsing the content or it will sound too practiced.
Choice 2: Come early to set up the audiovisual materials.
Choice 3: Remind all possible participants that early registration is required.
Choice 4: Try to get as many free handouts and freebies as possible.
Explanation: The nurse should visit the site to ensure the cleanliness, temperature, and lighting of the area; arrive early to set up the audiovisual materials; and bring extra supplies such as projector bulb and extension cord. Last-minute attendees should be welcomed. In addition, the nurse should practice the material until it is known forwards and backwards.

Question: A nurse was asked to select an appropriate site for a nursing education program for adults in the community. Which of the following characteristics is most important in choosing the site?
Choice 1: Location in a building that does not charge rent for use of the space
Choice 2: Lots of room for participants to stand, walk around the room, and socialize with other participants
Choice 3: Accessibility to public transportation, location in a physically safe area, and accessibility for disabled participants
Choice 4: Location next to a police station, fire station, or other community resource
Explanation: Although all the criteria would be useful, the most crucial would be an area where prospective participants can get to the meeting while feeling safe doing so. Consequently, the site ideally should be in an area with public transportation, appropriate for people with disabilities, and in a safe (or at least safer) neighborhood.

Question: Which of the following actions should be considered when a nurse provides an educational program to adults? (Select all that apply.)
Choice 1: Encouraging the learner to share resources with the group during the program
Choice 2: Focusing on the content that needs to be presented
Choice 3: Providing a detailed overview of the program before starting the formal education
Choice 4: Teaching what the learner wants to know before continuing the instruction
Choice 5: Establishing an ongoing support group for the participants
Choice 6: Relating the content to life experiences
Explanation: When a nurse is teaching adults, a few of the strategies that should be included are encouraging the learner to share resources with the group during the program, teaching what the learner wants to know before continuing the instruction (otherwise the learner will not be able to focus on instruction if a question is not answered), and relating the content to life experiences. Because the learner’s needs should be addressed throughout the program, the focus should not be solely on delivering necessary content. An overview of the program is a good idea before the education is started; however, this does not need to be detailed. An ongoing support group may be appropriate for some participants depending on the nature of the presentation, but it is not necessary for some topics and groups.

Question: What is the single most crucial variable associated with health status?
Choice 1: Cultural background
Choice 2: Ethnic group
Choice 3: Race
Choice 4: Socioeconomic class
Explanation: The most important factor associated with health status is economic status. Poverty drastically increases a person’s/group’s vulnerability to poor health status.

Question: In 2010, how many people fell below the poverty in the United States?
Choice 1: About 4.5% or 13 million people
Choice 2: About 8.5% or 25 million people
Choice 3: About 15.1% or 46 million people
Choice 4: Fewer people than in the year 2008
Explanation: According to the U.S. Census Bureau (2010), 15.1% of all people in the United States fall below the poverty level, or about 46 million, an increase of 6.6 million since 2008.

Question: What is the relationship between race and ethnicity and health status?
Choice 1: Ethnic and racial minorities are equally as vulnerable to poor health status as the rest of the population.
Choice 2: Ethnic and racial minorities are less vulnerable to poor health status than the rest of the population.
Choice 3: Ethnic and racial minorities are more vulnerable to poor health status than the rest of the population.
Choice 4: There is no significant relationship between ethnic and racial background and health status.
Explanation: Ethnic and racial minorities are more vulnerable to poor health status than the rest of the population because minorities are at greater risk for poverty. Other factors include discrimination and some health behaviors and beliefs.

Question: Approximately what percentage of the American population does not have health insurance according to the U.S. Census Bureau?
Explanation: The U.S. Census Bureau reports about 49.9 million Americans, or 16.3% of the population, do not have health insurance.

Question: Which of the following is the primary reason that only a small percentage of those eligible participate in COBRA insurance?
Choice 1: COBRA is too costly for most eligible people.
Choice 2: They do not think it is important to have health care insurance.
Choice 3: Medicaid is a more effective choice to obtain health care.
Choice 4: They are healthy and are willing to not carry insurance.
Explanation: Over 90% of people choose not to participate in the COBRA plan because of the cost of the premiums.

Question: An uninsured child lives in a family which has an income level below the poverty level. Under which of the following programs can this child receive health care?
Choice 1: Children’s “Health For All” initiative
Choice 2: “No Child Left Behind” Act
Choice 3: State Children’s Health Insurance Program
Choice 4: Temporary Assistance to Needy Families Program
Explanation: The uninsured rate for children has been cut in half because of the 1997 passage of the State Children’s Health Insurance Program. Despite the success of CHIP, eligible children are still missed and are not receiving care.

Question: A homeless veteran, who finds his posttraumatic stress disorder so overwhelming that he cannot deal with society, lives by the river underneath a bridge, in a large packing crate, and seems to have adapted to his situation. Which of the following best describes this type of homelessness?
Choice 1: Chronic
Choice 2: Episodic
Choice 3: Not really homelessness
Choice 4: Temporary
Explanation: Because this is an ongoing, apparently permanent situation to which the veteran has adapted, this has become the norm for him, hence chronic.

Question: The middle-aged white woman seemed unable to relate to the staff in any meaningful way or to behave in an appropriate manner in the emergency department, where the police officer had brought her as a result of inappropriate behavior at a public gathering. Which of the following would best describe this woman?
Choice 1: A public nuisance
Choice 2: An unfortunate drain on society
Choice 3: Extremely mentally and physically ill
Choice 4: Psychologically and socially decompensated
Explanation: A homeless woman with such symptoms is said to be suffering from psychological and social decomposition. That is, she is unable to interact with others by communicating well or behaving in socially acceptable ways and is emotionally and mentally separated from society.

Question: Although single men are the largest single group of homeless people, which of the following is the fastest growing group of homeless people?
Choice 1: Adolescents
Choice 2: Adult single women
Choice 3: Elderly
Choice 4: Families with children
Explanation: Single homeless men still make up the largest and most visible subgroup of the homeless. However, families with children are the fastest growing group.

Question: What is the primary reason women with small children are homeless?
Choice 1: Domestic abuse
Choice 2: Lack of education
Choice 3: Lack of employment
Choice 4: Lack of job skills
Explanation: Although lack of education and job skills makes it difficult to find employment and funds with which to pay for housing, the primary reason a woman with small children would be homeless is a result of domestic abuse.

Question: The nurse was assessing a child who had spent the last 3 years living with her mother in homeless family shelters. Which of the following would the nurse expect of the child in relation to intellectual development?
Choice 1: Development is somewhat below grade level
Choice 2: Development is above grade level
Choice 3: Development is at the appropriate grade level
Choice 4: Development is quite low for her age and grade level
Explanation: Many homeless children have attended school programs on a sporadic basis. They often have deficiencies in acquiring learning readiness and social interaction skills and experience long intervals between school attendances. This lost school time results in academic underachievement and gaps in learning and experience.

Question: Which of the following would a homeless adolescent see as an important survival skill?
Choice 1: Being able to beg, manipulate, and lie to obtain resources
Choice 2: Using free clinics to obtain access to health care providers
Choice 3: Trying to keep a list of all social programs in the community
Choice 4: Trying to look and act like a middle class member of society
Explanation: Homeless youths adapt quickly to life on the street, where they are subject to criminal victimization such as learning to solicit money and drugs through prostitution.

Question: A community/public health nurse is caring for clients living at a local homeless shelter. Which of the following would be most likely expected of many of the clients?
Choice 1: Many suffer from alcohol or drug abuse or are mentally ill.
Choice 2: Many are extremely violent and dangerous to be around.
Choice 3: Many receive free care at the local public health clinics.
Choice 4: Many suffer from acute illnesses resulting from exposure to weather extremes.
Explanation: Research demonstrates that the majority of the homeless are men, many are veterans, almost one third abuse alcohol or other drugs, and one fourth will be mentally ill.

Question: Why do many migrant/seasonal workers not complain about their poor living conditions?
Choice 1: Being undocumented, they risk discovery and deportation
Choice 2: Conditions here are so much better than in their original home
Choice 3: There is nothing a nurse can do about housing conditions
Choice 4: It is not a part of their ethnic group’s culture to complain
Explanation: Although the other reasons may also be true, the main reason this population does not complain is because many migrant/seasonal workers are undocumented and fear discovery and deportation.

Question: The two wage earners in a family with four children have recently become unemployed. Suddenly, they are unsure as to how they are going to pay their mortgage, monthly bills, and purchase groceries. To which of the following governmental assistance programs would the nurse most likely refer this family?
Choice 1: Aid to Families with Dependent Children (AFDC)
Choice 2: Medicaid
Choice 3: Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF)
Choice 4: Women, Infants, and Children Program (WIC)
Explanation: AFDC was abolished under the Welfare Reform Act, and TANF replaced it. The two biggest programs are TANF and Social Security Income (SSI), but both programs only cover about one third of the 37 million people below the poverty line. TANF provides temporary financial assistance to needy families with dependent children. Medicaid provides health care services to certain people in need. WIC provides supplemental food and formula for infants, young children, and pregnant and new mothers.

Question: Which of the following populations was most affected by the federal budget cuts made in 1996?
Choice 1: The upper and middle class
Choice 2: The wealthy
Choice 3: The lower-middle class
Choice 4: The poverty-stricken
Explanation: Poverty programs were cut in 1996 under the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act, also known as the Welfare Reform Act.

Question: What has happened to the funds set aside for nutrition and food programs, such as WIC?
Choice 1: They have decreased a small amount in an effort to be fair to everyone
Choice 2: They have increased the recognition of the number of low-income mothers seeking assistance
Choice 3: They have been maintained at current levels, even though more women are documenting eligibility for help
Choice 4: They have been sharply reduced with benefits limited to one year
Explanation: WIC was sharply curtailed so mothers living with others could have only 1 year of benefits, women in prison or detention centers were denied benefits for their children, and adults without children could have only 3 months of assistance every 3 years.

Question: When the nurse accepted a position at the local community health center, the nurse was told to not ask the immigration status of any client. Why would an agency have such a policy?
Choice 1: Agency personnel do not want to get involved in political or legal concerns in any possible way.
Choice 2: All state and federally funded programs are barred from using funds to care for illegal immigrants, so care can only be given if status is unknown.
Choice 3: The agency did not want to inadvertently refuse care to a U.S. citizen by constantly requiring documentation, which wastes agency time, effort, and money.
Choice 4: The agency recognizes that immigration status has no bearing on a client’s health or need for care, so there is no reason to ask.
Explanation: All states are required to bar illegal immigrants from state and locally funded programs. This ruling has created a dilemma for health care workers, who feel they have been asked to operate as agents of Immigration Services. Many facilities simply do not ask immigration status when providing care.

Question: How has requiring proof of citizenship for all Medicaid recipients caused a problem for these clients?
Choice 1: Additional paperwork always increases workload and costs for agencies.
Choice 2: Citizens are not accustomed to having to prove they are citizens and may not have appropriate documentation immediately available.
Choice 3: Many low-income people do not have driver’s licenses or birth certificates immediately available with which to prove citizenship.
Choice 4: Most agencies recognize that immigration status has no bearing on a client’s need for Medicaid assistance.
Explanation: Congress requires states to demand proof of citizenship, which is an additional administrative burden that causes delay in Medicaid coverage for families. Poor people are particularly at risk because many do not have passports, driver’s licenses, or birth certificates.

Question: A single adult male is employed full-time and is earning the minimum wage. Under which of the following conditions could he afford housing?
Choice 1: If he combines his earnings with another adult who is employed part-time
Choice 2: If he chooses to live in a one-room efficiency apartment
Choice 3: If he lives in an apartment located in a low-income housing area
Choice 4: If he uses over 50% of his net income to pay for housing
Explanation: An estimated 7.1 million low-income households spend more than 50% of their income on housing with no assistance from public assistance housing programs. Such households are one paycheck away from being homeless. Two adults, both employed full-time, may be able to rent a small apartment, but it is still difficult to save enough for the required deposit on a rental.

Question: Facing the changes in society, what have most state and local governments chosen to do?
Choice 1: Cut programs for low-income families to balance the budget
Choice 2: Cut programs that primarily serve the middle class
Choice 3: Increase taxes to meet revenue requirements
Choice 4: Ignore any federal mandates that are unfunded
Explanation: States have had to contend with shrinking revenues and increased program responsibilities and federal mandates. States have used program cuts, especially in programs serving low-income families, as the primary method for balancing their budgets.

Question: What is an extremely important strategy that a community/public health nurse can take to assist vulnerable families?
Choice 1: Encourage the families to find and use free food distribution centers
Choice 2: Encourage the families to find and attend so-called free clinics for health care
Choice 3: Share information about local assistance programs and eligibility requirements
Choice 4: Write letters to the editor in the local newspapers
Explanation: Although letters to the editor might be helpful, it would be more effective for the nurse to write about community problems than for individual families to beg for help. Certainly sharing the location of community resources is central to the nurses’ role, including eligibility requirements and benefits available for food, clothing, housing, emotional support, etc.

Question: The nurse wanted to engage in primary prevention in relation to the vulnerable populations for whom the nurse provided care. For what might the nurse choose to volunteer?
Choice 1: Counselor at the homeless shelter
Choice 2: Instructor for the community college home aide course
Choice 3: Nurse in a homeless clinic
Choice 4: Speaker to community groups as an advocate for vulnerable groups
Explanation: Primary prevention tries to prevent health problems. Therefore, the nurse must advocate for vulnerable groups and speak to community groups on such issues as the need for low-cost housing and funding for poverty-level families.

Question: By definition, what must a group be in order to be considered a “vulnerable” population? Select all that apply.
Choice 1: Aware that they are “at risk”
Choice 2: Diagnosed with an observable medical problem
Choice 3: Have difficulty obtaining appropriate health care
Choice 4: Acutely ill with several comorbidities
Choice 5: Likely to develop health-related problems
Choice 6: Probably confronting a shorter life span than others their age
Explanation: By definition, a vulnerable population has mitigating factors that place them at greater risk for ongoing poor health status than other at-risk people or groups. A vulnerable population is more likely to develop health-related problems, have more difficulty accessing health care to address those health problems, and is more likely to experience a poor outcome or shorter life span from those health conditions. Awareness of problems is not a factor, since many diseases, such as hypertension, do not have observable symptoms and may not be diagnosed because the person may not have sought assistance.

Question: What conclusions can be drawn when comparing the prison population in the United States to the general adult population in the United States? Select all that apply.
Choice 1: More prisoners are from low-income, single-parent homes.
Choice 2: More prisoners have been diagnosed with a mental problem and substance abuse.
Choice 3: More prisoners are exposed to drug trafficking, weapons, and gang violence.
Choice 4: More prisoners have a lower level of education.
Choice 5: More prisoners receive better and more extensive health care.
Choice 6: More prisoners have a decreased risk of injury while incarcerated.
Explanation: Statistical analysis of research demonstrates that vulnerable populations are overrepresented in juvenile justice and adult prison systems. Prisoners are more likely to come from single-parent homes and poverty, have lower levels of education, and have been exposed to drug trafficking, weapons, and gang violence. There is a disproportionate representation of racial minorities. Prisoners report more physical health problems, just more than 50% have a mental problem, and the risk of injury increases with time served.

Question: What were some of the effects of welfare reform? Select all that apply.
Choice 1: Additional governmental agencies have been established to fill in the gaps in services.
Choice 2: Earned Income Tax Credit helps increase income among low-income families.
Choice 3: Fewer people can use the system to their own personal advantage.
Choice 4: Lacking transportation and child care, many parents cannot seek or retain employment.
Choice 5: More children are able to receive health insurance assistance.
Choice 6: Very few people can receive assistance while earning a GED or attending remedial classes.
Explanation: Long-term effects of welfare reform on families include a drop in the number and percentage of needy families receiving help; lower average payment (the Earned Income Tax Credit) helps increase income; many children lost their health insurance; time limitations resulted in families losing benefits; educational pursuits are no longer considered a work activity; and the number of extremely poor is increasing. All of these have put vulnerable groups even more at risk for health problems.

Question: Even though the nurse may be employed to do a specific task or engage in specific programs, in what activities can the nurse engage to continue to help vulnerable groups in the community? Select all that apply.
Choice 1: Consider every contact with clients an opportunity to ask about the health of their family members
Choice 2: Engage in extensive multiphasic testing to diagnose other possible medical problems
Choice 3: Screen for potential problems while engaging in the tasks for which the nurse is reimbursed
Choice 4: Voice ongoing concern about the needs of the agency for ongoing funding to all the clients seen at the agency
Explanation: Although the nurse must complete the responsibilities of the nurse’s employing agency, the nurse can multitask through screening and interviewing each person or family concerning their health and the health of their family members while engaging in the required tasks. Voicing concern about funding to individual clients is not an effective way to change the health care system. Multiphasic testing would be wonderful but is not affordable in either time or other resources.

Question: Although it was not part of the nurse’s employment responsibilities, the nurse often volunteered to speak before community groups as well as legislators. Why would the nurse choose to do this? Select all that apply.
Choice 1: Advocacy is an ethical and professional responsibility of all nurses.
Choice 2: Engaging in such actions will increase the nurse’s personal and professional visibility.
Choice 3: Speaking before such groups may well result in a promotion and an increased pay scale for the nurse when the nurse’s expertise is publicly recognized.
Choice 4: Such public speaking is part of the nurse’s role in most public health agencies.
Choice 5: The nurse may recognize that many people are truly not aware of the problems experienced by vulnerable groups.
Explanation: Public speaking is not a requirement of the nurse’s role in most agencies. Nonetheless, the nurse may recognize that many people are truly not aware of the problems experienced by vulnerable groups. Speaking out helps increase public awareness. Furthermore, the ethical code for nurses states: “The nurse provides services with respect for human dignity and the uniqueness of the client, unrestricted by considerations of social or economic status, personal attributes, or the nature of health problems.” In other words, the nurse seeks to obtain care for clients and, if necessary, to seek funding for that care through political action.

Question: What should the nurse be sure to include in the research design when involved in community/public health research? Select all that apply.
Choice 1: Accurate data collection systems
Choice 2: Carefully worded research hypotheses and definition of terms
Choice 3: Cost/benefit measures as part of the research design
Choice 4: Detailed tables of the study’s sample and population demographics
Choice 5: Established outcome measures
Choice 6: Lengthy detailed title and abstract to the study
Explanation: In the current climate of economic retrenchment, cost concerns must be addressed as part of any intervention strategy. All studies should have cost/benefit measures as part of the research design. Nurses must document the effects of poor, improved, or good service through accurate data collection systems with established outcome measures. Different research approaches may or may not have research hypotheses, definition of terms, and summaries of the study’s sample.

Question: Which natural disaster is the most common worldwide?
Choice 1: Earthquakes
Choice 2: Floods
Choice 3: Hurricane (water)/tornado (over land)
Choice 4: Volcanic eruption
Explanation: Flooding is the most common natural disaster worldwide and also the third leading cause of weather-related deaths in the United States.

Question: Why might citizens be concerned about disasters, especially terrorism, even before they occur?
Choice 1: Charities will be trying to collect money for the victims by using personal stories.
Choice 2: Financial costs of a disaster or terrorist attack increase citizens’ taxes.
Choice 3: Laws have been passed requiring preparation for disaster education for laypeople.
Choice 4: There have been an increased number of terrorist activities throughout the world.
Explanation: Worldwide, there have been an increased number of terrorist activities that have been widely publicized using various forms of media.

Question: What group or organization defined the term disaster as “a threatening or occurring event,” either natural or man-made, “that causes human suffering and creates human needs that victims cannot alleviate without assistance”?
Choice 1: American Red Cross
Choice 2: Department of Health and Human Services
Choice 3: National Office of Disaster Control
Choice 4: Department of Homeland Security
Explanation: The American Red Cross—the voluntary agency historically most involved in disaster relief—so defined the term in 1975.

Question: When is the term mass casualty incident used in a disaster or crisis?
Choice 1: Fewer than 100 victims, which strains resources
Choice 2: Man-made disaster events
Choice 3: More than 100 victims, which overwhelms resources
Choice 4: Natural disaster events
Explanation: In a multiple casualty incident, 2 to 99 people are injured. In a mass casualty incident, a large number people, usually 100 or more, are injured, which significantly overwhelms available emergency medical services, facilities, and resources.

Question: Which of the following actions is the most important to perform first in caring for victims of a mass casualty incident?
Choice 1: Call in all part-time and on-call staff to help care for newly admitted clients.
Choice 2: Contact surrounding communities for assistance.
Choice 3: Call the hospital supply store and order extra dressings, intravenous fluids, and other materials.
Choice 4: Discharge as many hospital patients as possible to make room for disaster victim admissions.
Explanation: A mass casualty incident involves 100 or more people, which overwhelms a single institution, help must be summoned immediately, before the patients even arrive.

Question: A terrorist releases a poison gas in a crowded subway. This is an example of which of the following?
Choice 1: Appropriate political action
Choice 2: Man-made disaster
Choice 3: Media event
Choice 4: Natural disaster
Explanation: By definition, release of poison gas is a man-made disaster. Man-made disasters include war, chemical and biologic terrorism, transportation accidents, food or water contamination, and building collapse.

Question: In an earthquake, the roads and underground pipes were all destroyed. Fires and explosions began to occur from the broken leaking gas lines. Which of the following would be used to describe the fire?
Choice 1: A man-made disaster
Choice 2: The cause of the earthquake
Choice 3: The primary agent
Choice 4: The secondary agent
Explanation: The earthquake was the primary agent that caused the damage; the fires were secondary agents that resulted from damage by the primary agent. In this incident, primary agents include falling buildings, heat, wind, rising water, chemical and biologic agents, and smoke; secondary agents include bacteria and viruses that produce contamination or infection after the primary agent has caused injury or destruction. Primary and secondary agents vary according to the type of disaster.

Question: Of the following disasters, which would probably cause the most suffering?
Choice 1: A fire during finals’ week in a private residential college
Choice 2: A fire in an Alzheimer disease unit of an extended-care facility
Choice 3: A fire in an outpatient dermatology clinic at a major urban hospital
Choice 4: A thunderstorm that downs electrical lines to the local rural hospital
Explanation: Certain characteristics of humans influence the severity of the disaster’s effect on individuals and communities. For example, the age of a person, preexisting health problems, degree of mobility, and emotional stability all play a part in how someone responds in a disaster situation. Because patients with Alzheimer disease are less cognitively capable and physically less fit, many of them would probably be unable to escape and therefore would be injured or killed.

Question: The Mississippi River floods a small riverside town. A few citizens decide to stay even after the flood hits the town. Assuming flooding overwhelms city services, which of the following is the most dangerous problem?
Choice 1: Inability to drink safe water from the flooded city water pipes
Choice 2: Inability to eat because of food spoilage from lack of electrical service to refrigerators
Choice 3: Inability to relax, which would result in anxiety and tension
Choice 4: Inability to sleep because furniture will be wet
Explanation: Canned food would be edible. Although anxiety, tension, and sleeplessness may well occur, safe drinking water is the most important immediate physiologic need. Priority would have to be first to obtain safe drinking water for stranded people.

Question: Of the following families, which is most likely to need the most support to recover from the loss of electricity?
Choice 1: The family who moved into their motor home with its generator
Choice 2: The family who was away on vacation at the time
Choice 3: The family who was without electricity for 2 weeks
Choice 4: The family who was without electricity for 3 days
Explanation: The scope and severity of the disaster have a major effect on a person’s ability to cope. In general, people without electricity for longer periods of time have a more difficult time. Consequently, 2 weeks is more difficult than a few days to be without a major utility.

Question: Several people were involved in a local community shooting, and one victim died shortly thereafter. Which person will need the most help immediately after the shooting?
Choice 1: The police officer who will have to notify the victim’s family and follow up with the crime investigation
Choice 2: The woman who has been living with victim and has never experienced death of a close friend or family member
Choice 3: The woman who broke up with victim about a month ago and has not forgiven him for moving out of her apartment
Choice 4: The victim’s best friend, who is accustomed to gang shootings and random violence
Explanation: Personal variables influence an individual’s reaction. Psychological proximity and previous experience influence response. Risk for developing severe consequences is greater if that person is emotionally close to the individual affected or has never before experienced a disaster.

Question: A nurse, serving as a volunteer, was helping community residents who had been taken to an emergency shelter for food, clothes, and life necessities. Of the following families, which is in most need of receiving assistance from the nurse?
Choice 1: A woman who is visiting her father and sees the flood as helpful to finally convince her father to move in with her and her husband
Choice 2: The couple who believe the flood is God’s will and are attempting to determine its meaning for their life
Choice 3: The man who cannot believe that everything important to him is now lost
Choice 4: The man who believes the flood is a test of his faith but knows he will be alright
Explanation: Professionally, the nurse should concentrate on the victim to whom the disaster is the most overwhelming psychologically.

Question: Which of the following citizens trapped in a flood is in most need of supportive intervention by the nurse?
Choice 1: A handyman who was planning to remodel soon anyway
Choice 2: The man who had never been in a flood before and did not realize how much damage could be done
Choice 3: The store owner whose storefront was under water yet again
Choice 4: The woman whose house and small business were badly damaged but who had flood insurance
Explanation: The man who had no previous experience with a flood is psychologically unprepared for the disaster, whereas the other three citizens seem more prepared or do not seem to perceive the disaster as overwhelming.

Question: A family is supporting each other in the emergency shelter after a flood. The nurse overhears the conversation. Which family member most needs the other family members to listen and understand?
Choice 1: An 11-year-old girl, who lost her teddy bear collection and is crying
Choice 2: A 45-year-old adult, who keeps telling everyone that at least he still has his job and that they can cope with this
Choice 3: A 43-year-old woman, who keeps saying, “Without our family pictures, we’ve lost our history”
Choice 4: A 16-year-old boy, who has lost his favorite hunting rifle and seems angry
Explanation: The nurse should concentrate on the victim whose perception of the disaster is the most overwhelming. Losing one’s personal history would be the most overwhelming loss both psychologically and objectively.

Question: Which fact would suggest to a family that they may want to check building codes and availability of insurance and reconsider the location of their next home?
Choice 1: The area where they are looking had a huge neighborhood fire after a lightning strike last year, and people are just starting to rebuild.
Choice 2: The building lot is beautiful but in an area that has had forest fires and all the houses have burned three times in the past 20 years.
Choice 3: The empty building lot was in a neighborhood of very nice homes, but the home that used to be there was burned when the smoker fell asleep in his bed.
Choice 4: The home is very historic with features that cannot be replicated at any price today, but the damage from the fireplace fire is still very visible in the main living area.
Explanation: Most disasters are infrequent (such as being struck by lightning) and controllable (a person does not have to smoke, particularly in bed), but if such an event is predictable and frequent, action should be taken to avoid a disaster. In this case, it is probably foolish to build in an area where forest fires recur at frequent intervals.

Question: Which of the following is an appropriate definition of mitigation?
Choice 1: The actions used to avoid or prevent disaster damage
Choice 2: The cleaning-up process after a disaster
Choice 3: The process used to react to a disaster in order to minimize the death rate
Choice 4: The psychological intervention used to help people cope with a disaster
Explanation: Mitigation is a term used in disaster planning that describes actions or processes, or both, that can be used to prevent or reduce the damage caused by a specific disaster event.

Question: Of the following communities, which had a poor reaction to a disaster?
Choice 1: Chicago, which, after a large fire, now requires all buildings to be made of fireproof brick
Choice 2: Hilo, Hawaii, which, after the downtown was again destroyed by a tsunami, created an oceanfront park and moved small businesses farther up the mountain
Choice 3: Los Angeles, which is in the process of strengthening highway resistance to earthquake damage
Choice 4: Settersville, which, after a tornado flattened downtown, decided to appeal for state funds to rebuild, and which, if no funds are forthcoming, will simply cease to exist as a town
Explanation: Healthy cities that are susceptible to particular disasters on a frequent basis try to establish prewarning, or control, measures that can reduce the impact of disasters. Thus, a healthy community is one that plans to minimize damage and strengthens structural resources. An unhealthy community might just give up.

Question: Floods have hit a small town on the Mississippi many times. The last time, a levee broke, and there was extensive property damage, as well as several deaths. What should be the first preparation that the nurse should make before another flood hits?
Choice 1: Create child care centers.
Choice 2: Establish morgue facilities.
Choice 3: Plan for a parking area for rescue workers.
Choice 4: Practice the nurse’s personal family response plan.
Explanation: Nurses should establish their own family disaster response plans to protect their family and homes and still be able to respond to their community’s need.

Question: In a city where tornadoes have been known to strike, an emergency siren sounds, suggesting to its citizens that an emergency is imminent. What should a community/public health nurse do first?
Choice 1: Call every family member and tell them to come home immediately.
Choice 2: Call the local civil defense office for specific instructions for the nurse’s agency.
Choice 3: Follow the disaster plan of the local emergency management agency.
Choice 4: Start driving to the hospital and prepare to care for the injured.
Explanation: On the basis of their employment position, nurses should know their role and specific responsibilities for disaster response. Therefore, the nurse should be prepared to follow the emergency preparedness plan.

Question: As the flood receded from the town, the Disaster Action Team (DAT) met for debriefing. Why is this debriefing important for the whole community, as well as for the disaster team members?
Choice 1: The DAT is too tired to keep working and needs to sit and rest a while.
Choice 2: The DAT has insights that can help modify disaster plans to be used in the future.
Choice 3: The DAT has to give details of their names and addresses, so formal appreciation for their efforts can be sent.
Choice 4: The DAT needs some time to just socialize.
Explanation: The experience of implementing the disaster plan is extremely useful in knowing which changes need to be made.

Question: After a disaster, one citizen was most impressed with how much his neighbors went out of their way to help rescue him and take him to the emergency shelter. What is the most likely reason why his neighbors helped him?
Choice 1: They feared that he would sue them if they did not help him.
Choice 2: They hoped that, because he was very wealthy, he might give a reward for their help.
Choice 3: Such help is part of the pattern of behavior during the heroic phase of reaction to a disaster.
Choice 4: Such behavior is what any American would expect of a neighbor today.
Explanation: Helping other people survive is often the first phase of a community’s reaction to a disaster.

Question: Everyone in the emergency shelter told their neighbors what they were doing and how they got away. Which of the following is the most likely reason why these people are sharing their escape stories?
Choice 1: They are euphoric because they are safe in the shelter.
