Explanation: One of the unique features of hospice is that direct service volunteers are part of the interdisciplinary team. Volunteers provide a variety of services, including respite care, meal preparation, and friendly visiting. Accurate documentation, Medicare reimbursement, and direct nursing services are all part of hospice, but they are also part of traditional home care services.

Question: Why will home health care continue to expand? (Select all that apply.)
Choice 1: Complex care can be more efficiently provided in the home setting.
Choice 2: Cost-containment measures are being implemented at all levels of government.
Choice 3: Insurance companies are requiring increased use of generic medications.
Choice 4: The public is demanding quality health care services in the home.
Choice 5: The public is exerting pressure to receive care in the most comfortable setting.
Choice 6: Technologic advances are occurring.
Explanation: There are numerous reasons that home health care will continue to expand, including advances in technologies, which allow equipment to move from hospitals to homes; policies for cost containment by care in less expensive settings; and the ongoing public demand for quality care.

Question: A home care nurse is caring for an adult client who has an infectious disease. What measures should the nurse tell the client’s family members to take to protect themselves from the disease? (Select all that apply.)
Choice 1: Use protective barriers to prevent exposure to blood and other body fluids.
Choice 2: Body substances should be put in the toilet along with 1 cup of bleach each time the toilet is flushed.
Choice 3: Keep young children out of direct contact with the client.
Choice 4: Soiled dressings should be thrown in a trash can labeled “Hazardous Waste.”
Choice 5: Use disposable dishes when serving the client his food.
Choice 6: Wash hands frequently.
Explanation: Specific measures to control infection do not include disposable dishes if regular dishes can be washed in hot, soapy water; isolation of the ill family member compromises quality of care and may create social-psychological issues; client wastes can just be flushed without further action. It is important for everyone to wash their hands frequently and to use protective barriers when one may have potential contact with hazardous body fluids.

Question: Which of the following descriptions is the most accurate example of a rural community?
Choice 1: The residents of the community are subject to environmental hazards.
Choice 2: It takes longer than 30 minutes to get from the community to health care services.
Choice 3: The community has less than 20,000 residents.
Choice 4: The residents of the community say, “This is smaller than where I grew up.”
Explanation: All of the descriptions could be used in an attempt to define “rural,” but each aspect has problems. A definition of “rural” has not yet been decided. However, in relation to health care, the time needed to get to a health care facility has a major influence on care outcomes.

Question: What is the poverty rate in rural areas?
Explanation: National estimates report that in rural areas, more than 40% of all families live below the poverty level.

Question: Why are children at risk on their own family’s farm?
Choice 1: Children often help with the work without much regard for training or safety.
Choice 2: It is expected that children fulfill the roles that are assigned to them.
Choice 3: Machinery can injure someone faster than a parent can turn the machine off.
Choice 4: Parents are too busy completing their own tasks to supervise the children.
Explanation: Farming is one of the four most dangerous industries. Agricultural work is inherently dangerous but also must be performed under adverse conditions such as mud or extreme heat or cold. On family farms, spouses, children, and other relatives often help without much regard to competency, training, or safety. Of all industries, agriculture has by far the highest number of injuries and deaths among children.

Question: An adolescent in a rural community has recently committed suicide. What is the significance of this event in the community?
Choice 1: Rural residents are less religious than urban residents and less capable of coping with the loss.
Choice 2: Because of the size of the community, it is likely that no one will discuss what has happened.
Choice 3: There could be a cluster of such deaths in small towns where everyone knows everyone so well.
Choice 4: Without the adolescent to work, the family may have increased economic difficulties.
Explanation: Because of the cluster or “copycat” phenomenon related to self-inflicted death, in several towns the suicide rate has reached epidemic proportions, with three or more suicide incidents occurring in a very short time (after one suicide, there is an increased incidence of additional suicides in a community). In small towns or rural areas, where most people are fairly well acquainted, a sudden death can be devastating to students and to the community as a whole.

Question: What was one purpose of Rural Health Clinic (RHC) Public Law 95-210?
Choice 1: To define rural areas as underserved and therefore eligible for many tax reductions
Choice 2: To encourage utilization of advanced practice nurses by providing reimbursement for their services under Medicare and Medicaid
Choice 3: To fund structures (building, equipment, supplies) for rural health care providers
Choice 4: To pay for physicians to serve in rural underserved areas
Explanation: RHC Public Law 95-210 was originally passed by Congress in 1977. The law defined core primary care, created reimbursement mechanisms, and encouraged utilization of midwives and nurse practitioners, among others, by providing reimbursement even without a full-time physician available. Reimbursement is based on cost so that additional revenues to eligible rural practices can be generated.

Question: A program to recruit advanced-practice nurses to practice in a rural community is being developed. The program developers have applied to receive federal training monies to help fund the costs of the program. Which of the following questions must be addressed when they apply for these funds?
Choice 1: “Does the health of the clients improve as a result of interventions?”
Choice 2: “Have professional schools increased enrollment?”
Choice 3: “Are advanced-practice nurses taught to embrace rural cultural values?”
Choice 4: “Should improvements be made to the buildings and equipment at the agency?”
Explanation: Federal training dollars have been linked to program outcomes. The question of whether the clients’ health improves as a result of interventions is the only question that addresses outcomes. For example, the goal is not simply to educate professionals but to prepare providers who are capable and willing to increase access to care for underserved and minority populations.

Question: A family nurse practitioner is employed in a rural health clinic. What generalization would the practitioner most likely be able to make about the local clients?
Choice 1: “They carefully budget their money in order to afford health insurance.”
Choice 2: “They define health as self-actualization of potential.”
Choice 3: “They are fatalistic and oriented to the land, nature, and the seasons.”
Choice 4: “They are open to sharing their problems and accepting my advice.”
Explanation: Rural families are often fatalistic because both their work and their recreation are dependent on the land throughout the seasons. They usually know everyone in the community, keep their problems within the family, define health as the ability to fulfill their work requirements, and are too poor for health insurance. These are, of course, generalizations, to which there are many exceptions.

Question: A new family nurse practitioner at the rural health clinic soon saw much strength in the community. What might be some resources used and accepted by ill people in a rural area?
Choice 1: Charity efforts that are publicized and coordinated by members of the nearby city
Choice 2: Family and friends who volunteer to help with food, cleaning, child care, and other tasks
Choice 3: Use of the extended-care facility in the community until the ill person feels better
Choice 4: Care that is coordinated by social services and the public health agency
Explanation: Rural residents, many of whom are related to each other, typically accept help from family, friends, and other community members with the understanding that someday such help will be reciprocated. However, formal support from agencies cannot be accepted because of the cost and inability to “pay back” for such support.

Question: A nurse is working in a rural health clinic. Which of the following situations may cause difficulties in maintaining confidentiality at the clinic?
Choice 1: Neighbors care about each other and will ask the nurse questions.
Choice 2: Neighbors recognize each others’ cars in the clinic parking lot.
Choice 3: The nurse will want to share information in a quest to seek assistance for the client.
Choice 4: The nurse will have to use names in referring clients to other agencies for assistance.
Explanation: Most people in a small town are recognized by the car that they drive, so seeing the car in the clinic parking lot can jeopardize confidentiality. Assumptions may be made about anyone seen in the building, even if it is not to attend the clinic. Leaks in confidentiality result from such chance encounters.

Question: A new female family nurse practitioner employed at the rural health clinic became very frustrated. What might be cause for complaint?
Choice 1: “I can’t survive on this salary with the high cost of living here!”
Choice 2: “I make this incredible salary, but there is nowhere here to spend it.”
Choice 3: “The men seem to make all the health decisions.”
Choice 4: “The clients keep asking me when I’m going to get married.”
Explanation: Salaries are lower, as is the cost of living in rural areas. Although she is a professional, as a woman she would be expected to fulfill female roles, such as wife and mother, and may be seen primarily in relation to her family relationships.

Question: A nurse is employed in a rural area. What might be a dismaying reality about this setting of nursing practice?
Choice 1: Cultural values require clients to refuse pain relief medications.
Choice 2: Farmers have to visit care providers when not busy in the fields.
Choice 3: Rural residents have a tendency to use folk healers instead of scientific care providers.
Choice 4: There is no “off duty” because everyone feels free to request information or service any time.
Explanation: There is no distinction between being the nurse on duty at the clinic and being a resident of the community. The newcomer’s role will be that of nurse, and everyone will feel free to ask questions at any time and at any place.

Question: The registered nurse came to see many strengths and resources in the rural area. Among these were that rural residents are
Choice 1: Diverse, both in ethnic groups and in age groups.
Choice 2: Politically open to new ideas and approaches.
Choice 3: Very resourceful and self-reliant.
Choice 4: Willing to spend money to improve safety.
Explanation: Rural residents are very resourceful and self-reliant. In addition, they are conservative, often having fewer financial resources available.

Question: What is the most common definition of health among those living in rural areas?
Choice 1: Balance or homeostasis
Choice 2: Capable of fulfilling work requirements
Choice 3: Feeling of well-being, not merely the absence of disease
Choice 4: Purposive adaptive response to stimuli
Explanation: Some people living in rural areas define health as “the ability to work and to do what needs to be done,” or “illness is not being able to do one’s usual work.” Therefore, rural residents often do not seek health care until they are too ill to work.

Question: Which of the following is part of the first level of social support for people living in rural communities?
Choice 1: Big city charities that rely on agricultural donations to help feed urban poor persons
Choice 2: Church or civic group assistance, to which a person is expected to contribute when able
Choice 3: Professional agencies or people who are paid financially for their contribution
Choice 4: Volunteer assistance by family and friends, which one is expected to reciprocate as needed
Explanation: Rural residents prefer services from friends, extended family, and neighbors with the understanding that they will reciprocate when possible and when other people need assistance.

Question: What is a problem when urban dwellers move into rural areas, seeking a more satisfying lifestyle? (Select all that apply.)
Choice 1: Aging water, sewage, housing, and schools in the rural area
Choice 2: Expectations for the amenities in art, recreation, and sports
Choice 3: Complaints arising from farming by neighbors, such as odors and insects
Choice 4: Disruption of local informal helping networks
Choice 5: Farmers’ reluctance to sell their land, especially for development
Choice 6: Sudden increase in money being difficult for the community to absorb
Explanation: Both out-migration and in-migration can create problems that, in many instances, a small town cannot solve because of the lack of resources. Population shifts disrupt long-established informal “helping networks,” creating a need for unusual kinds of human services. Existing local infrastructures and public services are unable to keep pace with the growth. For instance, aging utilities (water, sewage, and communication systems), housing units, and schools are inadequate to handle the increased demands associated with the influx of local residents.

Question: Why are rural residents considered a group at high risk for health problems? (Select all that apply.)
Choice 1: They are very self-sufficient and self-reliant.
Choice 2: Few health care providers are locally available.
Choice 3: The residents are exposed to high-powered machinery, extensive sun, and chemicals.
Choice 4: They have difficulty accessing affordable insurance if they are self-employed.
Choice 5: They must travel long distances to obtain specialized services.
Choice 6: They work in dangerous occupations (farming and ranching).
Explanation: Rural residents, including elderly persons and children in the family, often work in dangerous occupations without immediately accessible health care. The poverty rate is high, since many are unemployed or retired. Agriculture is considered one of the four most dangerous occupations in America because its workers are exposed to lightning, farm machinery, firearms, drowning, and accidents involving vehicles such as snowmobiles and all-terrain vehicles. In comparison with urban residents, rural residents suffer higher rates of chronic illnesses, mental illness, and stress-related diseases. Problems include machinery accidents, skin cancer from sun exposure, and breathing problems from exposure to chemicals and pesticides. Rural communities find it difficult to recruit or to retain qualified health care providers, and so the residents must travel long distances to obtain care. Being self-employed, few have health insurance or workers’ compensation insurance.

Question: A rural family is trying to obtain health care. Which of the following barriers would they be most likely to encounter? (Select all that apply.)
Choice 1: Fewer health care providers in the community
Choice 2: Greater travel distances for health care, especially for pregnant women and young children
Choice 3: Less willingness to accept help from local health care providers
Choice 4: Little attention being paid to the problems of the rural population by federal legislators
Choice 5: Many competing insurance companies with different rules and policies
Choice 6: Providers of health care inadequately prepared to cope with differences between rural and urban lifestyle and values
Explanation: Problems for rural residents that serve as barriers to obtaining health care, in comparison with urban residents, include greater travel distances for health care, especially for pregnant women and young children; availability of fewer health care providers in the community; less cultural and educational encouragement for health promotion behaviors; lower probability of having health insurance; and, often, lower income.

Question: A local community hospital that is highly valued by its community has just announced that it will be closing within the next year. What would be the most anticipated reason for its closure? (Select all that apply.)
Choice 1: The departure of a health care provider resulted in an inadequate number of providers to staff the hospital.
Choice 2: Clinics and home care are being used more so that there is no need for a hospital in the community.
Choice 3: Large care networks have purchased the hospital but have found it unprofitable.
Choice 4: Most residents prefer to access the specialized services available in the large city nearby.
Choice 5: It is too expensive for the hospital to meet the new magnet hospital standards.
Choice 6: Nurses have demanded a salary increase, which they feel is necessary because of their multiple responsibilities.
Explanation: An out-of-community transfer by even one physician may cause a small hospital to close its doors because of insufficient staff. Large, expanding health care systems are “buying out” small hospitals and physician practices; then, to cut costs and improve profits, outreach services to rural communities are reduced or eliminated, forcing residents to travel to large city hospitals or do without health care.

Question: Many nurses enjoy the independence and creativity of being among the few professional caregivers in a rural community. What might be a problem in this situation? (Select all that apply.)
Choice 1: Feelings of being alone and isolated
Choice 2: Feelings of being overwhelmed with responsibility
Choice 3: Absence of physicians to delegate the nurse’s responsibilities
Choice 4: Absence of professional colleagues to offer support and consultation
Choice 5: Difficulty in accessing resources when questions arise
Choice 6: Standards of practice that are different in rural settings
Explanation: With computers and telemedicine, the nurse can obtain information, but responsibilities can be overwhelming because there are few other resources in the community to assist. There are no other nurses around with whom to discuss clinical situations or from whom to obtain support or consultation.

Question: A community/public health nurse working in the late 1960s saw an increase in the number of psychiatric patients who were being cared for in the community. What was the reason for this increase?
Choice 1: Phenothiazine drugs such as chlorpromazine had been discovered.
Choice 2: Lobbyists had demanded closure of state psychiatric hospitals.
Choice 3: State funding encouraged the establishment of community mental health centers.
Choice 4: Community-based therapy was found to be effective at controlling psychiatric symptoms.
Explanation: Phenothiazine drugs such as chlorpromazine (Thorazine) were miraculous at that time because they reduced the most challenging of psychiatric symptoms. Although symptoms were improved, clients were not ready to reenter the community, nor was the community prepared to receive them. Many patients lacked family support, and some still exhibited behaviors that interfered with social interactions. The federal government appropriated funds for community mental health centers in 1963, and this money was to be matched by state funds.

Question: Why did many psychiatric patients have impaired social interaction, decision-making skills, and life skills when they were discharged from the large state mental hospitals?
Choice 1: They had families who had not socialized them appropriately.
Choice 2: They heard nurses tell them too often that they were incompetent and incapable.
Choice 3: They lacked the ability to learn how to behave in front of others.
Choice 4: They were accustomed to having needs met and decisions made by the institution.
Explanation: The patients had a condition called institutionalization, characterized by long-term adaptation to the demands of the setting, as evidenced by impaired social interaction and decision making and lack of life skills with which to function in society.

Question: In the 1960s, what was recommended by the Mental Health Survey Act’s Joint Commission on Mental Illness and Health?
Choice 1: That an increased number of professionals who were prepared to treat the mentally ill be educated and employed
Choice 2: That mental health patients be deinstitutionalized and treatment be given to them in the community
Choice 3: That families reintegrate the ill family member into the home
Choice 4: That large state institutions be demolished and smaller, more homelike “cottages” be built
Explanation: The Joint Commission on Mental Illness and Health’s recommendation was to deinstitutionalize the mentally ill, with treatment to be moved from large state hospitals to the community.

Question: What was one of the suggestions given to President Carter in the 1970s when the mental health needs of the nation were reassessed?
Choice 1: Decrease support for mental health research.
Choice 2: Establish national health insurance that includes coverage for mental health services.
Choice 3: Require private insurance carriers to include mental health coverage.
Choice 4: Return responsibility for mental health from the states to the federal level.
Explanation: The report to the President focused on strengthening the community mental health care system. Among other suggestions were to establish national health insurance that included coverage for mental health services and to encourage private insurance carriers to include mental health coverage. There was no requirement for private carriers to do so, only a recommendation.

Question: A community/public health nurse providing care for the mentally ill in the 1980s had difficulty finding funds to provide care for her clients. What was the end result of this lack of funding?
Choice 1: Many of the mentally ill died from lack of care and basic life necessities.
Choice 2: Most of the mentally ill returned to the large state institutions.
Choice 3: New, more progressive, modern state institutions were designed, built, and included community-based services.
Choice 4: Severely disabled clients remained in state institutions, and the less disabled clients used the services of community mental health centers.
Explanation: A two-tiered system resulted; the most severely disabled clients were within state institutions and the less disabled clients used the community mental health centers.

Question: What major event related to the mental health care system occurred in the late 1980s?
Choice 1: The Reagan administration’s Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act terminated funding specifically for community mental health services.
Choice 2: States refused to continue to be told how to spend their money by the federal level and refused to provide matching funds to community mental health centers.
Choice 3: The budget crisis resulted in less funding for mental health services on the federal level and more funding on the local level.
Choice 4: The President’s Commission on Mental Health confirmed that community mental health centers were ineffective in meeting the needs of the patients.
Explanation: The Reagan Administration’s Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act moved authority for mental health programs from the National Institute of Mental Health to the individual states. Federal funding ceased as such, and each state received a block grant to cover services of the state’s choices.

Question: A community/public health nurse caring for mental health patients in the late 1990s noticed changes in the services that were available for this population. What led to these changes?
Choice 1: Communities began banding together to demand increased funding from the federal budget.
Choice 2: Psychiatrists were given some power to speak for their patients about services necessary to facilitate their recovery.
Choice 3: Psychiatric patients and their families organized and became involved in policy development.
Choice 4: States convinced the federal government that they could not cope with the demands of this population.
Explanation: The recipients of services became involved in planning efforts when organizations of former hospital residents were formed. The primary goal behind organizing was to be heard and to influence public policy related to mental health programs.

Question: A patient asks the community/public health nurse why there has been an increase in the number of self-help programs in the community. What was one factor that led to the popularity of these programs?
Choice 1: Community mental health centers wanted to avoid paying professionals to work as counselors.
Choice 2: Families were unhappy with professional care and helped their family members to “do it yourself.”
Choice 3: There was a lack of professionals available to fulfill these needed responsibilities.
Choice 4: Patients chose to do this to give their lives meaning by making a difference to someone else through giving as well as receiving.
Explanation: Patient-run services provide former patients with a belief that they can make a difference to someone else, that they can give as well as receive, and that their lives have meaning. There was no problem with professional staff working in the community.

Question: According to E. Fuller Torrey, where would a person most likely encounter a mentally ill person?
Choice 1: State mental hospital
Choice 2: State prison or jail
Choice 3: Grocery store
Choice 4: Living with a family member
Explanation: According to Dr. Torrey, data from 2004 to 2005 indicated that in the United States, there are more than three times more seriously mentally ill people in jails and prisons than in hospitals. At least 16% of inmates in jails and prisons have a serious mental illness; this percentage increased from 6.4% in 1983. Forty percent of individuals with serious mental illnesses have been in jail or prison at some time during their lives.

Question: A community/public health nurse has contacted her legislator to discuss a bill that would enact the provisions of Timothy’s Law in the state where she lives. Which of the following statements would the nurse most likely make during this conversation?
Choice 1: “Timothy’s Law suggests that foster care is often the only workable approach to children in trouble.”
Choice 2: “Timothy’s Law encourages an increase in the amount of support and counseling available in schools.”
Choice 3: “Timothy’s Law demonstrates how helpful it is for families to have insurance coverage.”
Choice 4: “Timothy’s Law shows off the success of local collaboration to address the inequities in mental health coverage.”
Explanation: Timothy, a 12-year-old boy, committed suicide after spending time in the foster care system in which he was placed so that he would be eligible for Medicaid services and unrestricted access to mental health services. Public outrage was so vast that the law named after him was created to ensure that such a loss did not recur. The law in New York requires that group health insurance provide at least 30 inpatient days and 20 outpatient visits per year for mental health treatment so that parents will not become so desperate as to give up their child to foster care in order to be eligible for Medicaid coverage for mental health care.

Question: Which of the following is an example of a catchment area?
Choice 1: A community mental health center that provides comprehensive services
Choice 2: A community where the homeless meet each evening and are taken to a shelter for safety
Choice 3: A jail or prison where the severely mentally ill are kept isolated from prisoners who do not suffer from such illnesses
Choice 4: A city or several rural communities small enough to allow collaboration among themselves
Explanation: Community is defined in mental health terms as a catchment area, which is a city or several rural communities whose total population ranges from 75,000 to 200,000. This is a manageable segment for the delivery of mental health services because it is small enough to allow collaboration among the components of the system.

Question: What is the leading cause of disability in the United States among individuals aged 15 to 44?
Choice 1: Arthritis
Choice 2: Cardiac conditions
Choice 3: Cerebrovascular disorders
Choice 4: Mental illness
Explanation: Mental illness is the leading cause of disability in the United States and Canada among individuals aged 15 to 44.

Question: A nurse was creating health education units to be taught in the community high school. Which unit would be most helpful to adolescents, their teachers, and the community as a whole?
Choice 1: First aid and preparedness in case of natural disasters
Choice 2: Healthy lifestyles with an emphasis on the need for physical activity
Choice 3: Signs of depression and suicide and ways of helping someone at risk for suicide
Choice 4: Sex education about subjects ranging from abstinence to avoiding pregnancy and sexually transmitted diseases (STDs) among teenagers who are sexually active
Explanation: One of the best ways to help the community is by using primary prevention strategies; these strategies allow the nurse to intervene before a problem occurs. Although any such educational programs could be useful, the choice may depend in part on the local community’s needs and belief systems. The sexual education course may be an excellent approach, but in certain areas of the country, it would cause an uproar in the community. Physical education is also a high priority, but the leading causes of death in adolescents are accidents, homicide, and suicide. Therefore, preventing suicide would be the highest priority in the list.

Question: A community/public health nurse would like to implement a secondary prevention strategy within the community to meet the needs of the families caring for members with mental illness. Which of the following interventions would the nurse be most likely to complete?
Choice 1: Providing counseling services for the family members
Choice 2: Offering mental health consultation services to businesses in which family members are employed
Choice 3: Developing discharge planning instructions for the family members
Choice 4: Advocating within the political arena for the rights of the family members
Explanation: Providing counseling services for family members exemplifies secondary prevention, as this intervention demonstrates intervening with a group at risk for problems before a problem develops. Offering mental health consultation services and advocating within the political arena are examples of primary prevention. Developing discharge planning instructions is an example of tertiary prevention.

Question: A community/public health nurse links a mental health client with the necessary services in the community. This is an example of which category of individual client-focused interventions?
Choice 1: Consulting
Choice 2: Teaching
Choice 3: Providing therapy
Choice 4: Case management
Explanation: There are four categories of individual client-focused interventions: teaching, case management, consulting, and providing therapy. Case management addresses the multifaceted and complex needs of the client and includes assessing the client’s needs, compiling a plan for services, and linking the client with needed services. Consulting allows the nurse to offer mental health services to agencies within the community. While providing therapy, the nurse is concerned with symptom management, relationship building, and ego strengthening. Teaching describes providing education to the client, family, and community.

Question: A community/public health nurse was caring for mentally ill clients in the community during the 1960s. Which of the following changes in the community was the nurse likely to notice? (Select all that apply.)
Choice 1: Communities resented becoming dumping grounds for such severely ill people.
Choice 2: Community health centers were rapidly built, staffed, and prepared to provide appropriate care.
Choice 3: Families were relieved that they did not have to travel so far to visit their ill family member.
Choice 4: Housing units were quickly built for the patients capable of independent living.
Choice 5: Psychiatric patients were feared, mocked, and stigmatized and found life outside frightening.
Choice 6: Without adequate financial support, patients were admitted for crisis care but were quickly discharged.
Explanation: When institutions first began to discharge large numbers of clients, communities were unprepared. Financial support was lacking, housing and treatment facilities were scarce, and community attitudes were inhospitable. Patients were feared, mocked, misunderstood, and stigmatized. Former patients were unwelcome and rebuffed and found that life outside the hospital was frightening and unappealing. They were often caught up in a vicious cycle of short inpatient stays, rapid discharge, and eventual repeat admissions.

Question: A community/public health nurse is providing care for the mentally ill. Of the following needs that the nurse can help the client meet, which are most important? (Select all that apply.)
Choice 1: Access to medications
Choice 2: Basic life necessities
Choice 3: Integration of provided services
Choice 4: Funding for care
Choice 5: Options for day treatment
Choice 6: Support for family members
Explanation: The needs of severely mentally ill clients include basic life necessities, a sense that life is meaningful, access to medications, support for family members, and integration of nursing, medical, and social services. Many chronically mentally ill clients are without basic items. Access to medications is essential in order for the mental illness to be treated successfully. The burden of caregiving can be quite high, and so family support is crucial. Integration of services provided is necessary so that these clients can navigate the maze of services necessary to stay in the community. Not all these clients need a day treatment program, and some clients may not need additional services that require concern related to funding.

Question: What approach have nurses historically used when providing care and paying attention to costs?
Choice 1: Giving the best possible nursing care regardless of ability to pay
Choice 2: Giving whatever care the nurse has the expertise to give
Choice 3: Giving whatever care the patient could afford
Choice 4: Giving whatever care the patient desired and for which he or she was willing to pay
Explanation: Historically, cost was not considered relevant to the practice of nursing. The topic of cost was ignored by both clinicians and educators.

Question: Which of the following is true about access to care?
Choice 1: Care providers have always donated necessary services to make sure everyone received care.
Choice 2: Health care is rationed by the ability to pay.
Choice 3: Poverty-stricken patients received care from medical and nursing school students in teaching hospitals.
Choice 4: Universal access has always been a component of health care in America.
Explanation: Health care is rationed by the ability to pay. A person’s financial status affects the quality and quantity of care that he or she receives.

Question: A nurse educator teaches community/public health nursing students about how health care is financed in the United States. Why is it important that nursing students receive this information?
Choice 1: Nurses are expected to help patients find funding sources to pay for their care.
Choice 2: Nurses have to restrict their care to services that are financially reimbursed.
Choice 3: Health care organizations must charge patients for all supplies consumed while care is given.
Choice 4: Health care organizations must notify patients of the exact cost of the nursing services rendered.
Explanation: Nurses do have to charge for supplies used but can do so without understanding health care financing. In a position dealing with community/public health, advocating for a client may include making referrals to agencies that may be able to meet their needs on the basis of patient finances. All nurses have to focus on is giving care consistent with agency deadlines, which in turn must focus on reimbursement regulations in order to continue to be able to exist and provide care.

Question: A nurse has chosen to provide home care services to a needy client even though there is no source of reimbursement for this care. What problem may result?
Choice 1: The nurse will be expected to provide this care to other clients.
Choice 2: The nurse may not be covered in case of a malpractice claim.
Choice 3: The agency’s clients will start demanding that the staff provide free care.
Choice 4: The agency’s clients will be at risk for being billed for the services provided.
Explanation: The real danger that exists is that the nurse will not be covered in case of a malpractice claim because the service was not first sanctioned by the agency. The nurse should not be expected to provide free care to other clients because of the legal risks involved. Because it is stated there is no source of reimbursement for this client, the client is not at risk for being billed for the services provided. It is doubtful that other clients would start demanding free care as a result of this incident.

Question: A community/public health nurse is providing home care services to an elderly couple. They report that they believe they are spending more and more money on health care services and have limited funds available to meet their everyday living expenses. Which of the following offers the best explanation for their situation?
Choice 1: The proportion of the gross domestic product devoted to health care is increasing.
Choice 2: The health care costs are increasing for the elderly population.
Choice 3: The cost of living is increasing because of recent rapid inflation.
Choice 4: The cost of health care is increasing because more people are insured.
Explanation: As a result of the increasing proportion of the gross domestic product (GDP) devoted to health care, individuals and families spend more on health care and have less to spend on food, clothing, housing, schooling, leisure, and other needs or interests. The number of elderly persons in the population has increased, but the health care costs are increasing for everyone, not just this population. Both the cost of living and the cost of health care are increasing because of inflation. Higher numbers of uninsured and underinsured clients have also increased the cost of health care.

Question: Which of the following was true concerning the amounts paid by private funds and governmental funds in 2009?
Choice 1: Government spent 49%, and private funding accounted for 51%.
Choice 2: Government spent 75%, whereas private funding accounted for 25%.
Choice 3: Government spent 40%, whereas private funding accounted for 60%.
Choice 4: It is unknown what proportion of funds was governmental and what proportion was private.
Explanation: In 2009, governments at all levels provided 49%, and private funding provided 51%.

Question: A community/public health nurse is examining how health care dollars are distributed in the United States. Which of the following information would the nurse find in the literature?
Choice 1: The majority of health care dollars are spent on health promotion activities.
Choice 2: The percentage of health care dollars spent on public health activities is increasing.
Choice 3: The percentage of health care dollars spent on health care advances is increasing.
Choice 4: The majority of health care dollars are spent on personal health care services.
Explanation: Personal health care services account for 84% of the entire health budget. Hospital care is the most costly category. Public health, research, and construction together account for 9% of the entire budget.

Question: Which component of government is primarily responsible for health research spending?
Choice 1: The federal government, through the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Choice 2: The federal government, through the National Institutes of Health
Choice 3: State governments, through grants to state universities and research centers
Choice 4: State governments, through local public health departments in cooperation with local researchers
Explanation: The federal government bears the major responsibility for research, and most funds are distributed by the National Institutes of Health.

Question: A community/public health nurse is working with vulnerable populations in the community. Which population would be most likely to not have health insurance?
Choice 1: Elderly persons who do not qualify for Social Security
Choice 2: Homeless persons who lack a permanent address
Choice 3: Working poor persons whose jobs lack health insurance as a benefit
Choice 4: Young families who have not yet saved enough to qualify
Explanation: The working poor have low-paying jobs that lack benefits and therefore cannot afford to pay for services.

Question: Self-payment of health care costs are
Choice 1: Almost never done because that is the purpose of health insurance.
Choice 2: Frequently done because many employers do not offer a health insurance benefit.
Choice 3: Frequently done by paying for one’s own insurance to ensure coverage.
Choice 4: Usually done by paying co-payments and deductibles required by insurance.
Explanation: Today, self-payment is usually accomplished through co-payment and deductibles required by insurance companies, as well as additional out-of-pocket costs for services not provided by insurance plans.

Question: A community/public health nurse is visiting a nuclear family. Both of the parents are employed full-time, have a moderate income, and have health insurance. Which of the following is the most likely source of their health insurance?
Choice 1: Employer-paid insurance
Choice 2: Federal government–subsidized health insurance
Choice 3: Medicare/Medicaid program
Choice 4: Private-paid insurance
Explanation: Currently, the most common form of health insurance is employer-provided insurance, although its availability is decreasing.

Question: A company’s chief executive officer (CEO) discusses potential ways to control employee health care costs with the organization’s occupational health nurse. Which of the following recommendations would the nurse be most likely to suggest?
Choice 1: Suggest employees exercise and stop smoking to retain their employment.
Choice 2: Encourage the use of generic prescriptions and outpatient services.
Choice 3: Consider layoffs to decrease the number of employees who receive insurance.
Choice 4: Reward employees who have limited health care expenses.
Explanation: Cost-containment strategies are becoming routine in employer-provided group health insurance plans as employers’ costs continue to escalate. Employer cost-containment strategies include reimbursement for generic-only prescriptions; increasing reliance on second opinions for surgery; and increased reliance on outpatient surgery.

Question: A community/public health nurse is discussing insurance options with a healthy, young adult client who has recently lost her job. Why would the client most likely not be receptive to obtaining privately paid health insurance?
Choice 1: Health care services can be obtained at a local free clinic.
Choice 2: She prefers to spend her money on higher priority needs than insurance.
Choice 3: The monthly premiums are just too high to be affordable.
Choice 4: She has no need for insurance because she is young and healthy.
Explanation: Individuals and families may not obtain privately paid insurance because they live in a state where insurance companies are not required to offer it or, especially if they are members of a high-risk group, because they cannot afford it. For low-income and marginal middle-income individuals, the premium costs are simply unaffordable. Private insurance is usually purchased only by persons who have regular employment and an adequate income to do so. Services provided at free clinics cannot meet all of the client’s potential health care needs. It is highly recommended that all persons have health insurance because of the large expense associated with receiving care.

Question: Why was the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) not successful at making insurance more available?
Choice 1: It provided for medical savings accounts, which were not what people wanted.
Choice 2: It focused primarily on protecting the confidentiality of patient records, not insurance.
Choice 3: It was repealed shortly after its passage.
Choice 4: It did not limit what companies could charge for the insurance.
Explanation: The bill guarantees access for individuals who just left an insurance plan and requires renewal of coverage, but it does not limit the amount an insurer can charge for the insurance; therefore, the premiums may be too expensive for the majority of persons eligible to purchase insurance.

Question: A community/public health nurse is working with a low-income family that has children and is uninsured. What recommendation made by the nurse would assist the children in obtaining health care?
Choice 1: Visit a free clinic at the health department.
Choice 2: Apply for Medicare.
Choice 3: Apply for the Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP).
Choice 4: Visit the local pediatrician’s office.
Explanation: Low-income children who are not covered by other types of assistance programs may have health insurance coverage through CHIP, which took effect in 1997. Medicare is a federal program for elderly and disabled persons. A free clinic may meet short-term needs but will not help with long-term access to health care services. Visiting the local pediatrician’s office will not assist this family in obtaining health insurance, which is what is necessary when they receive health care.

Question: With regard to the effectiveness of the Medicare program, it can accurately be said that the program
Choice 1: Ensured that elderly persons received appropriate care.
Choice 2: Helped reduce health care costs.
Choice 3: Prevented elderly persons from suffering any major financial hardships.
Choice 4: Improved access to health care services for eligible persons.
Explanation: Although the program is unable to prevent elderly recipients from suffering financial destitution, reduce health care costs, or ensure that the elderly receive appropriate care, it has vastly increased health care access for clients who are eligible and has helped reduce poverty among elderly people.

Question: How are the funds obtained to pay for the Medicare program?
Choice 1: A “Medicare” tax paid by all employees who pay Social Security tax
Choice 2: A tax on wages paid by employer and employee
Choice 3: Money from the federal income tax paid by all citizens
Choice 4: Social security funds paid by employer and employee
Explanation: A 1.45% tax of a worker’s salary is paid by both employer and employee, regardless of whether the employee pays into Social Security.

Question: Research has demonstrated that which of the following relationships is true with regard to paying for care?
Choice 1: The higher the co-payment, the less health care the person seeks.
Choice 2: The higher the co-payment, the more the patient thinks the care was “worth the cost.”
Choice 3: The lower the co-payment, the more compliant patients become with the suggested treatment.
Choice 4: The lower the co-payment, the more patients feel they can always get the care later.
Explanation: There is an inverse relationship between services used and rate of payment; the higher the co-payment, the less people request service.

Question: The primary criticism that may truthfully be made of the Medicare program is that it
Choice 1: Does not meet the most serious medical needs of the population it serves.
Choice 2: Has inadequate controls on the amounts paid to health care providers.
Choice 3: Has not sufficiently reduced taxpayer cost.
Choice 4: Lacks adequate funding, and Medicare taxes continue to increase.
Explanation: Medicare has not changed substantially since it began, but benefits have been restricted as costs rise so that it does not meet the most serious medical needs of the population it serves. The greatest cost burdens are placed on poor persons because their out-of-pocket expenses reflect a larger proportion of their incomes than does the cost to persons with larger incomes.

Question: An elderly client reports that he has been told that he needs to “spend down” in order to be eligible for Medicaid. He is confused about what he needs to do in order to accomplish this task. Which of the following statements is the best response from the community/public health nurse?
Choice 1: “You will have to spend your own money to pay for the Medicaid premiums.”
Choice 2: “You will have to spend your own funds until you are eligible for Medicare.”
Choice 3: “You will have to exhaust most of your assets before receiving benefits.”
Choice 4: “You will have to meet a certain deductible amount before receiving benefits.”
Explanation: “Spending down” is the process whereby elderly persons must exhaust most of their own assets, paying medical bills until they qualify for Medicaid, the program for the poor.

Question: For which of the following clients will care not be reimbursed by Medicare?
Choice 1: A terminally ill client who is receiving hospice care
Choice 2: A client who is hospitalized for pneumonia
Choice 3: A client who requires intermittent skilled home health care
Choice 4: A client who needs long-term care in a nursing home
Explanation: Neither Medicare nor private Medigap insurance will pay for custodial nursing home care, the type of care required by most elderly nursing home residents. Medicare does provide coverage for hospice services, hospitalizations, and intermittent skilled home health care.

Question: What is the main problem with Medicare Part D?
Choice 1: The plan allows elderly persons to purchase medications from certain mail-order companies.
Choice 2: The plan covers generic, not brand-name, drugs.
Choice 3: Medicare recipients are confused by what the plan will or will not cover.
Choice 4: There is a coverage gap in which recipients have to pay full cost of drugs.
Explanation: The concern with Part D is the coverage gap, or “doughnut hole.” If an elderly person’s drug costs exceed a certain amount, then the individual pays the full cost of medications between that amount and the end of the gap. In 2012, the gap starts at $2930 and ends at $4700 (out-of-pocket personal cost of drugs of $1570, in addition to monthly premium costs).

Question: What is notable about Medicare Advantage?
Choice 1: Because it is a new program, no one has yet seen any problems with this aspect of Medicare.
Choice 2: Insurance salespeople have been very careful in explaining this program to elderly persons.
Choice 3: More insurance companies are marketing such plans to elderly persons.
Choice 4: Unless the elderly person is very healthy, the plan may cost more than the original Medicare.
Explanation: Although the program is new, problems are beginning to surface. A total of 39 states report abuses related to deceptive marketing and misrepresented benefits. When states became concerned about such practices, several companies suspended marketing to elderly persons. Subscribers are locked into the plan for 1 year, so they are unable to change policies if they discover the plan is more expensive, not less.

Question: Of the following, persons, who is most likely to receive Medicaid benefits if the family income is below the poverty level?
Choice 1: A 16-year-old child
Choice 2: A pregnant woman with a 3-year-old child
Choice 3: A single-parent family
Choice 4: A two-parent family in which the father is unemployed
Explanation: The federal government requires that benefits be extended to pregnant women and children younger than 6 years if family income is at or below the nationally set poverty level.

Question: Of the following persons, who is most likely not to receive benefits under Medicaid, regardless of financial status?
Choice 1: A 3-year-old child
Choice 2: A 21-year-old pregnant woman
Choice 3: A single-parent family
Choice 4: A two-parent family
Explanation: In general, the following needy groups are excluded: single persons and childless couples who are not elderly or disabled; most two-parent families; families with a parent who works at a low-paying job unless they have very low incomes as determined by state Temporary Assistance to Needy Families (TANF) criteria; and legal aliens who entered the United States on or after August 22, 1996 (are barred for 5 years).

Question: Which of the following populations accounts for the majority of the cost in the Medicaid program?
Choice 1: Children younger than 5
Choice 2: Elderly persons
Choice 3: Low-income families
Choice 4: Single pregnant women
Explanation: Elderly, blind, and disabled persons, who represent 21% of the participants, use 63% of the Medicaid budget.

Question: The major method used to reduce costs to third-party payers has been to
Choice 1: Change the eligibility requirements.
Choice 2: Convert reimbursement to a retrospective payment plan.
Choice 3: Require all clients to choose a managed care plan for reimbursement.
Choice 4: Set fee schedules to restrict increases in provider payment.
Explanation: Although many methods are being used to cut health care costs, the major method has been to change the eligibility requirements so that fewer people receive benefits.

Question: A community/public health nurses states that the United States has an integrated health care system. What is meant by this statement?
Choice 1: The larger for-profit managed care organizations are absorbing smaller organizations so that eventually only three to five large companies will exist.
Choice 2: Large organizations are trying to own or control a complete range of health care facilities to meet all health care needs of their enrollees.
Choice 3: Large managed care organizations are employing attorneys as employees to ensure that no malpractice suit against them can be successful.
Choice 4: Physicians are choosing to become employees to avoid paying for malpractice insurance and therefore are being absorbed into hospital systems.
Explanation: Integrated systems are a growing trend. Large companies own or control a complete range of health care facilities and provide service to a large population of consumers. Their goal is to provide all health care required by their enrollees. They save money by controlling the type of services provided.

Question: Which of the following statements most accurately summarizes the current view of health care in the United States?
Choice 1: The government should allow Americans to receive the health care they can afford.
Choice 2: The government should trust the free market system.
Choice 3: The government should assume responsibility for providing basic care to all.
Choice 4: The government should provide basic care to those who cannot care for themselves.
Explanation: According to the current system, it might be concluded that while there is strong disagreement over whether health care is a right or a privilege and whether it should be government controlled or continue with the free market system, most Americans believe that at least some care should be given to all citizens; hence, the government funds care for specific at-risk groups. The increasing concern is the lack of access to health care for many people for whom the government is not a guarantor of last resort. The new Health Care Reform Law is an attempt to expand health insurance coverage to more of the population (although it still may not be expanded to all).

Question: As part of the orientation program at a local public health department, the newly hired nurse learns about the resources that are available in the community. What is the reason for including this information?
Choice 1: So that the nurse is able to advise clients on how to obtain food stamps
Choice 2: So that the nurse is able to determine who is eligible for certain services
Choice 3: So that the nurse will be able to include other departments in providing care
Choice 4: So that the nurse will be able to refer clients to the appropriate resources
Explanation: Nurses need to know about community resources to refer families to appropriate resources for which the families may be eligible. Referral is often just a matter of matching clients to existing programs for which they qualify. This does not mean that nurses must become experts in program criteria, application processes, and benefit packages, but they should become aware of existing programs, the types of clients who are generally served by those programs, and the name and phone number of the initial contact for such programs.

Question: Which of the following actions demonstrates the community/public health nurse advocating for the community?
Choice 1: Encouraging the media to run personal interest stories on needy clients
Choice 2: Becoming an active member of a professional nursing organization
Choice 3: Offering to organize a fundraising campaign for needy families
Choice 4: Suggesting appropriate agencies where families can receive services
Explanation: To create improved health care systems, nurses must be aware that systems are subject to change. Nurses work both individually through political action and collectively as members of professional nursing associations to improve the health care system. The other actions do not demonstrate the role of nurse as advocate for the entire community.

Question: What are the primary reasons for the ongoing increase in health care costs in the United States? (Select all that apply.)
Choice 1: Changes in population demographics
Choice 2: Improved end-of-life care
Choice 3: Ongoing research studies
Choice 4: Periodic financial inflation
Choice 5: Rising expectations by consumers
Choice 6: Technologic advances
Explanation: Heavy inflation occurs periodically and affects all services, including health care. Demographics in the United States have changed; there is an increasing aging population, which has created additional demand. Finally, technologic advances have been enormous but also expensive.

Question: On what basis can Medicare be criticized? (Select all that apply.)
Choice 1: Even after age 65, many elderly citizens are not eligible for Medicare.
Choice 2: Medicare pays less than half of recipients’ health care costs, which is a major hardship for many recipients.
Choice 3: Medicare does not protect elderly people from financial destitution when they pay for needed care.
Choice 4: Most physicians and hospitals do not accept Medicare recipients.
Choice 5: Until 2007, the premiums were the same whether the recipient was very wealthy or very poor.
Choice 6: Until 2011, Medicare paid for procedures in hospitals but not in outpatient settings.
Explanation: Several major criticisms have been made of Medicare, primarily around institutional bias, service restrictions, and lack of equity. Medicare would not pay for less expensive outpatient procedures but only for inpatient hospital-based procedures until 2011. As cost sharing is an aspect of the program, the government has increased co-payments to reduce usage. Co-payments are a major hardship for a large percentage of elderly persons. Medicare pays less than half (45%) of health care costs. Justice is not served, inasmuch as both wealthy clients and poverty-stricken clients must pay the same amount for the same benefits, although in 2007 premiums for wealthy persons (income above $82,000/year) were increased. Lastly, the program was created to protect elderly persons from financial destitution. Those who have a major illness over a period of time cannot afford needed health services. Eventually they will exhaust their assets and then may be eligible for Medicaid.

Question: A public health nurse is concerned about a recent influenza outbreak in Germany. Why would the nurse be interested in a health issue occurring outside of the United States?
Choice 1: Highly infectious diseases can circle the world quickly through worldwide travel.
Choice 2: Other nations rely on the United States for guidance to address health issues.
Choice 3: According to the World Health Organization (WHO) guidelines, nurses should assist in disease control efforts.
Choice 4: Nurses have a moral obligation to keep the public safe and healthy.
Explanation: Although there are certainly ethical and moral commitments to help fellow humans, the practical reason is that it is almost impossible to isolate a contagious disease within the country of origin, since more than 2 million people cross national boundaries daily.

Question: Which factor is primarily responsible for the differences in health care needs and health care outcomes among the various countries?
Choice 1: Economic development
Choice 2: Political system
Choice 3: Social-cultural system
Choice 4: Religious affiliation
Explanation: Health is dramatically affected by poverty, which is an outcome of economic development.

Question: A public health nurse is discussing actions that countries must take in order to reduce poverty successfully. Which of the following actions is the nurse likely to suggest?
Choice 1: Adopt a democratic government for their people.
Choice 2: Create a national health care plan.
Choice 3: Give preference to women and infants.
Choice 4: Provide predictable and sustained funding.
Explanation: The health of the population in developing countries is dramatically affected by poverty. After the United Nations Millennium Summit in 2000, the governments of the 22 wealthiest donor nations agreed to commit 0.7% of their gross domestic product by the year 2015 toward accomplishment of the Millennium Development Goals. This funding is necessary in order to decrease the rates of poverty worldwide.

Question: What was the primary commitment agreed upon when the United Nations Millennium Declaration was adopted?
Choice 1: Adoption of specific environmental actions
Choice 2: Elimination of poverty
Choice 3: Enforcement of maternal and infant health standards
Choice 4: Provision of safe water and sanitation
Explanation: The global representatives committed themselves to giving a very high priority to the commitment of funding toward reducing the rates of worldwide poverty by 2015.

Question: Which of the following efforts is being led by the World Health Organization (WHO)?
Choice 1: Establishing standards for medications and vaccines
Choice 2: Providing food for all the world’s residents
Choice 3: Eliminating polio as an infectious disease
Choice 4: Ensuring safe water for all the citizens of the world
Explanation: WHO is leading the effort to establish international standards for medications and vaccines. It was founded to be “the world’s health advocate” and provides technical support and health care services to member nations, with an emphasis on poorer nations.

Question: A community/public health nurse has recently accepted a position with the United Nations International Children’s Fund (UNICEF). What will be the primary focus of the nurse working for this organization?
Choice 1: Building and staffing hospitals in undeveloped countries
Choice 2: Providing health education for mothers of children
Choice 3: Establishing clinics for surgical interventions for handicapped persons
Choice 4: Helping with economic development in undeveloped countries
Explanation: The efforts of UNICEF are concentrated in the area of maternal and child health. More recent efforts have been geared toward ensuring availability of fresh water and safe food supplies, providing health education for mothers of children, education for girls, and immunization programs aimed at reducing or eliminating vaccine-susceptible communicable diseases.

Question: A developing country has been in contact with the World Bank. What is this country accomplishing by connecting with this intergovernmental organization?
Choice 1: Ensuring that the economy is based on the U.S. dollar
Choice 2: Supporting specific projects, especially to establish new businesses
Choice 3: Requesting a loan to improve the infrastructure
Choice 4: Helping to establish a national banking system
Explanation: The World Bank funds government projects to improve a country’s infrastructure through low-interest loans to developing countries for improvements in education, health, agriculture, and natural resource management.

Question: Which of the following statements represents an example of the epidemiologic transition?
Choice 1: As economics improve, the life expectancy increases.
Choice 2: As education improves, the number of physicians and nurses increases.
Choice 3: As global funding increases, the incidence of communicable disease decreases.
Choice 4: As preventable diseases increase, the global infection rate decreases.
Explanation: The poorer the country, the more likely its citizens are to suffer from preventable diseases and early death. The epidemiologic transition refers to a change in illness pattern. Currently, a shift is being seen again as chronic diseases are replacing deaths from infectious disease worldwide.

Question: Which of the following is the leading contributor to illness and death in developing countries?
Choice 1: Inadequate sources of food
Choice 2: Unsafe water
Choice 3: Limited availability of immunizations and antibiotics
Choice 4: Lack of sanitary sewer systems
Explanation: Nearly 1 billion people (14% of the world population) do not have safe water supplies. Many diseases could be prevented if water supplies, sanitation, and hygiene were improved.

Question: A public health nurse is investigating the health of children worldwide. Which of the following sources of data should be used to determine which country has the healthiest children?
Choice 1: Percentage of mothers who breast-feed their infants
Choice 2: Rate of immunization
Choice 3: Rate of malnutrition
Choice 4: Percentages of generalist versus specialist physicians
Explanation: Undernutrition is a contributing cause to about one third of deaths in children worldwide. Stunting of growth results from long periods of malnutrition. Damage from malnutrition during fetal development and the first 2 years of life may be irreversible.

Question: Which of the following actions demonstrate where most of the international efforts have focused in relation to the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)/acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) epidemic?
Choice 1: Caring for people who are stigmatized and not wanted by anyone
Choice 2: Providing education about the cause and spread of the virus
Choice 3: Funding voluntary counseling and testing programs
Choice 4: Saving children who will be orphans with no one to care for them
Explanation: International efforts have concentrated on primary prevention. A few examples of these efforts are education about the cause and spread of the virus and advocacy of the use of condoms and other protective measures during sexual activity; improvement in the procurement, storage, and administration of blood; and advocacy efforts aimed at women and men who are at risk because they have multiple sexual partners. Voluntary counseling and testing programs would be an example of secondary prevention. Caring for people and saving children are examples of tertiary prevention.

Question: Which of the following characterizations best describes the approach to paying for health care used in the United States?
Choice 1: Decentralized, free market approach that does not provide care to all citizens
Choice 2: Central government control of all aspects of health care, which is consistent with socialist philosophy
Choice 3: Health care that is planned and paid for and in which independent practitioners are employed
Choice 4: Federal government as the entity that negotiates and funds care for persons who cannot afford it
Explanation: The U.S. health care system is based on the free market approach, capitalism, and an entrepreneurial model. All other industrialized countries have some form of national health care system that provides coverage to all, or nearly all, citizens.

Question: Which of the following descriptions is the best example of how the Bismarck model is implemented?
Choice 1: Multiple insurance providers develop options for health care delivery to the population.
Choice 2: A centralized government department controls all of health care that is provided in the country.
Choice 3: A government system plans and pays for health care delivered by private enterprise.
Choice 4: The government plans and funds care provided by its employees in government-owned health facilities.
Explanation: In the Bismarck model, funding is by insurance or subsidized by the government, and the patient has a choice of private providers. Organizing and delivering care are shared by government and private enterprise.

Question: Which of the following descriptions is the best example of how the Beveridge model is implemented?
Choice 1: A government system plans and pays for health care delivered by private enterprise.
Choice 2: Multiple insurance providers develop options for health care delivery to the population.
Choice 3: A government system plans and pays for health care delivered by private enterprise.
Choice 4: The government plans and funds care provided by its employees in government-owned health facilities.
Explanation: In the Beveridge model, in contrast to the Bismarck model, national government controls health care with national planning, organizing, financing, and delivering care to all. Most health care providers are government employees, and services are provided in government-operated health centers.

Question: A community/public health nurse is preparing a presentation for a local community group about the infant mortality rate in the United States. Which of the following information would be included in the presentation?
Choice 1: The number of women who are uninsured is higher in the United States than in other developed countries.
Choice 2: There is a lack of comprehensive planning for prenatal care in the United States.
Choice 3: The United States has one of the lowest infant mortality rates in the world.
Choice 4: Additional health care services are provided to pregnant women in the United States.
Explanation: The United States does not have comprehensive planning for prenatal care; in contrast, other countries with national health care systems do have such planning. This is a significant contributor to the infant mortality results. In 2010, the United States was ranked forty-third in infant mortality rates.

Question: According to the World Health Organization (WHO), which countries have the “best” health care in the world?
Choice 1: Australia, Great Britain, and New Zealand
Choice 2: France, Japan, and Great Britain
Choice 3: Spain, Italy, and Germany
Choice 4: United States and Canada
Explanation: Using the WHO’s five criteria, France has the best health care among developed countries, and the health care systems of Japan, Great Britain, and Germany are rated higher than that of the United States.

Question: Which of the following is the leading cause of premature death in industrialized countries?
Choice 1: Alcohol-related illnesses
Choice 2: Automobile accidents
Choice 3: Tobacco-related illnesses
Choice 4: Malnutrition
Explanation: Tobacco-related illnesses are the leading cause of premature death in industrialized countries. Tobacco use accounts for 63% of deaths in the current, global, noncommunicable disease epidemic.

Question: A community/public health nurse actively implements the recommendations from the Global Treaty on Tobacco Control. On the basis of this treaty, which of the following actions is the nurse most likely to perform?
Choice 1: Encouraging states to implement smoking bans
Choice 2: Supporting a global ban on tobacco advertisements to youth
Choice 3: Lobbying to make the production of tobacco products illegal
Choice 4: Suggesting an increase in cigarette taxes across the world
Explanation: The Global Treaty on Tobacco Control was passed at the 2003 meeting of the World Assembly. This treaty endorses a global ban on tobacco advertisement and promotion to children younger than 18 years and suggests limits to exposure to second-hand smoke. The Treaty also ends subsidies for tobacco production but does not include making its production illegal. In addition, the Treaty prohibits tax-free, duty-free sales of tobacco products but does not suggest an increase to cigarette taxes.

Question: A community/public health nurse is investigating the current health threats that are occurring at the global level. Which of the following concerns is the nurse likely to discover?
Choice 1: Shortage of health care professionals
Choice 2: New infectious diseases
Choice 3: More potent drugs
Choice 4: Terrorism
Explanation: Health problems associated with war, civil insurrection, and terrorism appear to be escalating, and no country is immune.

Question: A community/public health nurse would like to join an international professional nursing organization that supports nursing leadership and research. Which of the following organizations would best meet this criterion?
Choice 1: International Council of Nurses (ICN)
Choice 2: Sigma Theta Tau
Choice 3: The International Nursing Federation (INF)
Choice 4: World Health Organization’s Nursing Council (WHONC)
Explanation: Both Sigma Theta Tau, the international nursing honor society, and the International Council of Nurses (ICN) are global organizations. However, Sigma Theta Tau is the international honor society of nursing. This organization is dedicated to supporting nursing leadership, research, and clinical excellence.

Question: Which of the following were among the specific goals of the United Nations Millennium Declaration? (Select all that apply.)
Choice 1: Achieving universal primary education
Choice 2: Achieving agriculture efficiency and effectiveness
Choice 3: Ensuring democracy in all governments
Choice 4: Eradicating extreme poverty and hunger
Choice 5: Establishing a global partnership for development
Choice 6: Promoting gender equality and female empowerment
Explanation: The primary goal is elimination of worldwide poverty. Among the eight steps were to eradicate extreme poverty and hunger, to achieve universal primary education, to promote gender equality and empower women, to reduce child mortality, to improve maternal health, and to establish a global partnership for development.

Question: What were some of the “Top 10 Best Buys” of health interventions? (Select all that apply.)
Choice 1: Encouraging condom use and treating sexually transmitted diseases (STDs)
Choice 2: Enforcing traffic regulations and installing speed bumps
Choice 3: Giving nutrients to children and pregnant women
Choice 4: Imposing taxes on tobacco products
Choice 5: Providing insecticide-treated bed nets in malaria-endemic areas
Choice 6: Distributing prescription drugs for free to low-income persons
Explanation: If money, time, and effort are invested, the actions suggested included monitoring children’s health and vaccinating against major childhood killers, imposing taxes on tobacco products to increase their cost, mounting a coordinated attack on the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)/acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) epidemic by promoting 100% condom use in at-risk populations and providing antiretroviral treatment, providing children and pregnant women with essential nutrients, providing insecticide-treated bed nets in malaria-endemic areas, and enforcing traffic regulations and installing speed bumps at dangerous intersections to reduce traffic-related injuries.

Question: Why is tuberculosis a serious health problem? (Select all that apply.)
Choice 1: The largest numbers of new cases are occurring in the South-East Asia Region of the World Health Organization.
Choice 2: Receiving treatment for tuberculosis is a social stigma.
Choice 3: People are often co-infected with tuberculosis and human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)/acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS).
Choice 4: Many cases of tuberculosis are occurring in industrialized countries.
Choice 5: The disease is endemic in Africa.
Choice 6: The standard treatment for the disease is a short course of directly observed therapy (DOTS).
Explanation: Tuberculosis is the second leading infectious disease killer of adults worldwide, with the largest numbers of new cases occurring in the South-East Asia Region of the World Health Organization (WHO). People are often co-infected with tuberculosis and HIV/AIDS; tuberculosis case rates and deaths have increased since 1995 in African countries with the highest rates of HIV infection. Drug-resistant strains have complicated the treatment regimen for tuberculosis, and so the standard treatment has become DOTS. No social stigma is associated with this treatment plan. Many cases are occurring in developing countries, not industrialized countries (such as the United States).

Question: A community/public health nurse is working with a client who has just immigrated to the United States from Canada. The client states that the Canadian health care system has many problems. Which of the following statements would the client likely have made? (Select all that apply.)
Choice 1: “Canada does not have enough physicians.”
Choice 2: “Canada uses socialized medicine to provide health care services.”
Choice 3: “Health care costs are increasing in Canada.”
Choice 4: “Physicians working in Canada earn less money than in the United States.”
Choice 5: “The quality of health care is poor in Canada.”
Choice 6: “There are long waits to see a primary care physician in Canada.”
Explanation: The Canadian health care system is based on social insurance, not socialized medicine. Physicians have private practices. There are an adequate number of physicians. There is no wait for a primary care physician, although there may be for specialists. Physicians in Canada are paid less than physicians in the United States. The quality of health care in Canada is better than that in the United States, with a lower infant death rate and a longer life span. The costs of health care are escalating throughout the world.

Question: Which of the following is an example of an emerging disease? (Select all that apply.)
Choice 1: Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)/acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS)
Choice 2: H1N1 influenza
Choice 3: Tuberculosis
Choice 4: Severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS)
Choice 5: Avian influenza
Choice 6: Malaria
Explanation: Emerging infectious diseases are either old diseases that are rapidly increasing in incidence or geographic range or new, previously unknown conditions. SARS, H1N1 influenza, and avian influenza are all examples of emerging infectious diseases that have important implications for global politics, health systems, and international migration and travel.

Question: In which legislation can most public health documents be found?
Choice 1: County or district law
Choice 2: Federal acts
Choice 3: Local ordinances
